element_texts.text:
Lucy Hampden
Feb. 20 1850

                                                                                                                                               Hampden Feb. 20th 1850.

Dear Mother

                               It is about two hours since you went away, - is'nt it time for me to begin a letter to you? You don't know how lonesome and deserted we look and feel here. But, Mother, how very thoughtful you was to take the pair of spectacles you use most! Was'nt I vexed with myself when I found you had left one pair here? When you particularly desired me to remind you of them? And Joseph's meal - that was worse than all the rest. He'll have nothing to make bread of. I have put them all together in the firkin, as also the French Grammar - which I suppose he intended to take, - and his gun, which of course he will mourn after, if I do not send it! Guess I won't write any more now. Four o'clock P.M. What a long still day this has been! two hours more before Johnny will make his appearance. I have got a tremendous cold - head ache am so hoarse I can scarcely speak loud. My throat is exceeding sore - haven't got a yarb of any kind in the house. Though I must do something, so I fixed some Flax seed and loaf sugar -guess I'll soak mt feet tonight and be well in the morning. I fear you and Josie have both been cold today, it has been so windy, but I suppose you are safe home by this time, unless Josie had to stop to rest. Wish I could spend the evening with you all at home. I wish I had something more to write but believe I have not, so will put away my paper. Finished one of Isaac's shirts today, good night.

Feb. 22nd.. Eleven o'clock, A.M. Mr. Sammy did come last night, and has gone to Bangor this morning. John said Walter Brown and Eliab passed him on his way home from school last night, he did not ll here. I did soak my feet, drink flax seed tea and sweat vigorously, and last night Samuel brought me some slippery elm bark, but my cold and cough are yet pretty bad. He put out the clothes again this morning and they are flapping their wings in the wind as thought they would fly soon. I have just finished the last of Isaac's shirts. They set well on Samuel & I guess he will like them. I reckon I had better keep a sort of journal for Joseph's pleasure and edification now adays - won't you do so too Josie?  Where anything transpires worth telling of, clap it on paper, together with your comments etc. and when a sheet is filled, send it along, good bye for today. 
25th Johnny went this morning. I intended to finish this to send by him, but was not well enough to write. 'Tis just as well though as Charles is coming down this week. Pa & Ma Furber are coming down tomorrow, we expect, and as on that account John would have no horse wherewith to transport them to Cedar grove until they got home. I thought - best to wait and sent the meal & spectacles by Charles. I never remember to have had so bad a cold since the time Angella Bennett administered "Poke root snuff!"  Headache so bad I could scarcely open my eyes wide for three or four days. Saturday afternoon & Sunday slept most of the time! Samuel and Jane did the work. Jane has been just as good as pie - kept every thing nice as a pin - took great pride in it you know. Yesterday she baked a Turkey, cooked potatoes & onions, and made

coffee for dinner - got them all on to the table in good order safe alone, I thought she did very well. I am quite smart. This morning, have cleaned up the sitting room, and expect to go to baking this afternoon, Johnny's mam sent him three dollars to buy a fiddle box with. You know Mr.  Ricker has been at work over there. Mrs. Furber told Samuel that he said Isaac paid all Joseph's expenses at Waterford, and also that you (Mother) was very much out of health and did not pretend to do any thing at all! He ought to know better than to talk so, nevertheless don't train him and cause a fuss. I very much fear you and Josie both took cold going home, it was so windy, and Samuel said you were all chilly. Bad for you especially Mother because you did not sleep the night before. You can't think how still & lonely it does seem here, and how much I did want you to tell me what to do and miss me up for two or three days. But I am being well now. I beg you will not train Eliab too vigorously and hurt his feelings about not coming here more, perhaps he could not and ought not - his time is not his own you know. Samuel was talking about his coat yesterday - said he should have had it two years "come marrying time."
26th Do you guess how glad I was when Samuel came from Bangor today with six letters! Not all for me, to be sure - a long one from Ann, one from Isaac to Jos. & another to Eliab one from Everett to Isaac, from Dole to Joseph, & from Farrar to Joseph. I do not like it Mother, - I want your likeness.  Wherefore did you carry it away? I went to look at it same day after you were gone and found it missing.  I want it. Evening  - Pa & Ma Furber have come. Charles

gave them the bundle & is not coming down. I am very sorry, but will try to send up the firkin in the morning before he goes. I expected him, and fixed the bed all up nice on purpose. My cold is better, though I am very hoarse. Nothing new in Ann's letter to me, so I'll not send it. Much obliged for your cabbages etc. Will attend to Joseph's requests soon as I can. Everett says in his letter to Isaac "I suppose you could get me to go to Dunbarton for you if you will give me a message or anything which will serve as an excuse or reason for calling. Will you try it? I believe all the clergymen and their families in the region round about are well." Am very glad to hear so favorable an account from Milo meetings etc. especially little Lucy.  I am alone in the kitchen fire most out. Must go see the folks now - good night good night --do do do write often. Affectionately Lucy.
I don't know who opened Dole's letters, spose twas Eliab.

Lucy              Hampden               
March 2, 1850                                                                                                               Hampden March 1st 1850

March 1st Dear Mother's birthday as I well remember myself, besides being reminded of it by Jane. What a stormy day! real driving snow storm this forenoon, and fast rain this afternoon. Samuel read "Lyell" to me and fixed his boots, while I mended his coat. This P.M. he is writing to Warren while I scribble to you. I forgot to put your Inkstand in the firkin. Josie, having company, you know, and much else to think of; so I got it ready to send up "Pa," but he could not take it. Samuel says we had better get a good bottle & carry up when we go. I have never seen but three or four of the numerous inkstands you mentioned and most of those I gave to Mr. Crosby's children. There is only one here now. I wrote a little to send by Mr. Furber, but thought it not worth the trouble. Mrs. Crosby is getting better slowly. I wish to know the precise quantity of cord wanted for the Pall Cloth, from tassels I believe - write me, and I will try to get it before I go to Milo . Isaac's things are all ready. Kerchief hemmed and all. What a pity Charles did not bring his hog down sooner, when there was better sleighing and a higher price - butter too has fallen is being brought in in immense quantities, 'tis said. 
                Last night Jane was looking out the window and said there was a great star bigger than all the rest, and had longer prickers too. How I want to see you all, and Charlie too, he must cut a fine figure sawing wood. Mrs. Furber left me a skein of white yarn, so I shall not need any more Mother. Yesterday and last night had bad head and ague ache - took a little more cold I suppose. Soaked my feet and sweated, - fell better today than I have before since you went away.

March 14th, Thought I would not tear off the former part this epistle, valueless though it be, but "continue to proceed on." We arrived safely & comfortably home Sat. P.M. Good sleighing to Bangor - mostly bare ground from there to Hampden. Found Jane most sick with a cold. better now. Sabbath went to meeting in the forenoon- great sermon. Prof. Shepard, on Paul's talking to Felix & Drusilla. Stormy in afternoon - went not. Monday did big washing most three weeks. Tuesday baked pies, & in the midst of it came Eliab with a sleigh load of girls. Lissie Doe Anne Allen & Sarah Stone - surmise that the latter is the "bright particular star"- stopped about an hour, then rode down to Hampden & back home to dinner without giving me any notice thereof - just as well though. Wednes. (yesterday) did big ironing - eleven shirts etc, Isaac came  in midst of it - good boy that he was. Samuel went up to Pushaw - today he has gone to Stetson.  Isaac's packing his trunks to go Milo tomorrow - how, how I want to go too. I didn't stay half long enough before. Isaac will deliver your beloved pen handle Mother, and your lost toothpick Josie which I found in the fireplace. Also I saw the waist pattern which you desired - you will probably find it much too huge. Am sorry I have not go Almeda's things to send, but did not know of the opportunity in season to get them - will attend to it the first time I get to Bangor. I send a pr. of stockings that John left here - will you please deliver them. Do not think of more to write. good bye Affectionately Lucy.

                                                 Do write to me.

Tell Isaac to bring, he need it !!!!!
Lucy & Samuel, Hampden March 15, 1850
Dear Folks As Isaac left his trunk to go afterwards, I thought I would get the things to send with it. Have been to Bangor this afternoon through six inches of thick mud. I had no idea it was so bad.
Delaine, ten yds. 20 cts. 2.00 I think it is pretty, do you?d
linen thread   12 1/2
unbleached do.    .04
4 white spools      .20
col'd  do.              4
needles 5 papers  .25
black ribbon         10
quilled lace   12 1/2
plain do.             .08
[across amounts] These are Almeda's things. Spent the 2.70 for Almeda & the .25 Mother's left 2.95
Mother handed me .25 to get cap stuff for Almeda. Louise said she could block out a cap for me cheaper than she could sell lace in the piece for one, as they use all the time cutting out. Quilted lace 12 1/2 a piece - got a piece and 1/2, put two rows in front, one behind, don't know as I got a good ribbon enough for strings, but thought you did not want very nice. The man did not throw in any silk with the drops, - naughty, ought to. I could find no black cord, nor tassels, will sometime go to an Upholsterers & try to get tassels, and will get a skein of worsted as before for cord.

         Frillings for Albina, as I did not set it down, I could not tell how much she told me to get, but thought it was three yd's, though it seems a monstrous pattern for two aprons. Thinking a yd -, 50 cents. Guess will stuff all things into Samuel's old bag, & send with the trunk - let Isaac bring it back with him. I'll send a newspaper to Eliab about the bed ticking. good night Lucy.

Wish I could go to Milo again - seems as if I did not talk half enough about all your plans & fixings, not love any and all of you half enough when I was there. I want to go see Joseph.
Tell Joseph that Celine Clark has fixed his a/c. went Wednesday to Pushaw, don't think much of the property there. saw mill in quite good order shingle mill bad dam bad. house bad, water pervalyer?  good. land etc. poor, timber - small, hemlock and cedar would not give $800 for all Mr. Fletcher interest. wrote Fletcher a letter to day. poor search.
Went to Stetson yesterday. could do nothing with Wing. very cross, if he had know the fine to be good would have sued for damages gave up the note and passed receipts. Wingate must put up thebalance ($15.03) for damages. no sales of flour bating two bbls. to Henry S. Brown & Co. 
March 15th 1850                                                       S.W.F.
[written at bottom right across by Lucy?]  Guess Charlie will have his match to wear out these aprons. Shall I get cord & tassels of any color & you color them black or get worsted & you make the cord. I presume I can find black tassels at the Upholstery but you know what a time we had with the other. I suppose such folks at home. Things are usually made to order.
[bottom of page] no needles
[left side]  ? Bosphorus.

Dear Mother

                   I have written so lately that I don't know as I have anything to say, but as Bell is going this morning I suppose you will expect me to send a word by her. Joseph has repeatedly called for Cheever and Shirley in his letters, and though Isaac said once, wait till he came before sending them, as there is so good an opportunity, I think I will pack them.
      When Samuel gets the Life of Cromwell you mentioned from Brown's I would like to keep and read it., if 'tis not wanted elsewhere. I almost want to pack up my rug and send it by Mehitable lest I should not come up myself. I much want you to see

it. We consider it quite an indignity put upon all three of us, Mehitable, I, and the "monkey herself," to be called a horse stable carpet.

 Eliab hear that in a recent gale of wind, the Henry Crosby was cast away, but as the report has not yet been confirmed, he thinks it is untrue. 'Twould make quite a hole in his living, would it. Well, they are ready and I must stop. How much longer are you going to stay there Isaac? good morning

In haste
Lucy.
Forgot to get a Catechism will send Jane's. Cord and tassels first opportunity...

D
[upside down] Mother

Lucy Hampden
March 1850

Lucy Hampden
March 20, 1850

                                                                                                   Hampden March 20th 1850.
                               Jamie's birthday. I believe I have not written any to Milo since last Sat. and now it is Wednes. P.M! Monday forenoon while I was in the "height" of my washing, who deu you think should come? If it was'nt the veritable Charles Harlow! He wished and wished Isaac was here. For my part, I concluded Isaac would "bless his stars" that he was not. He came and introduced himself to Samuel, who was chopping wood at the door; "believed he was Mr. Metcalf's partner in business" etc. Samuel invited him in - he stopped two hours or so, took dinner, & rode up to Bangor with Samuel. He talked most all the time about Religion, querying about one thing and another etc. He does act very queer. Samuel hardly knew what to make of him. Eliab says he owes him $2.50 and would owe him much more if he would have lent it to him. Yesterday I did "break the ice" and go to Sewing Circle at William Bennett's. Enjoyed it very well. Mrs. Jewett pleasant & polite as usual. Hannah Moore "chock full" of "carrying on" about Mr. Webb & Mr. Dunmore & much jabber about cholera & everything else most. Dysentery with cramps very prevalent now. Dr. Rich says no doubt Cholera will be here again. Third Parish have held divers meetings & have given Mr. Webb a call. Offer him $850, with the privilege of being absent half the time for two years, at ten dollars per sabbath. The Augusta people previously offered 800, only, but would at any rate overbid Bangor if that would make any difference, which Webb says it would not. He has decided to go to Augusta, or rather, people say Prof. Pond has decided to have him go. They want to send a smart man from the Seminary out to Kennebec. Thinking it will have

some effect in getting the other Professorship (Prof. Smith) endorsed. First parish want third parish to get a minister from Andover, instead of having one educated here, but Prof. Shepherd said he would rather resign his professorship and become their Pastor himself, on account of the injury to the Bangor Seminary, in the eyes of the people abroad. There has been considerable excitement and feeling all around. Guess they have been so taken up with the matter, that they have forgotten all about the Milo application. Mr. Innmore has gone to Hallowell to preach until Mr. Skeele, who has received a call there from the Seminary, shall graduate next fall, unless he is desired to start for Africa before that time. Poor Dunmore wants a wife, and all the girls like him extravagantly, but are not willing to go with him. Hannah Moore is knitting him some flannel undershirts - said she tried one on to him the other day, pulled it right over his head! he is very lively as well as she. Jane is an extra good girl now adays. What a difference it does make with her, if there is any thing unusual going on around. She is steady as can be. Has hardly missed a word in Spelling, or a question in Geography for a fortnight - gets two lessons regularly every day, reads a chapter in the Old, and one in the New Testaments every forenoon, and a lesson in her reading book in afternoon. Chores, knots, sews, swings and jumps rope the rest of the time.
22nd We spent last evening at Mr. Dove's - Allvena, the same chatter box as ever. This forenoon Samuel is up in the woods, chopping, and I am "getting a boiled pot" for dinner - wish somebody would come to help eat it. 'Tis a

big dinner to get for three folks, you know. We live mostly on "bread & butter and apple sauce" these days! Samuel's favorite aliment - mine too. Makes for dishes to wash! Beans once a week, of course, Mother! How did the things suit? I want to go to Milo again - mean to by and by. Prospect now is not much business at the mill this summer.

 Jane seems as much interested reading the Bible, as you often see a child in any story - puts queer constructions on it sometimes., makes me think of Lissie Doe sometimes. Said when a little girl she read the passage "This is the heir - come let us kill him" Thought it over to herself. "This is the hair comb" - rejoicing that she has come to one thing in the Bible that she could understand! 

25th Very windy yesterday, and I not very well, so I did not go to meeting. L. brought me home Eliab's letter from Isaac. glad to hear from some of you -been wondering why you did not write. One of Prof. Shepherd's great sermons yester, afternoon - subject sin, its progressive character, results etc. brought in the Rumseller in the course of his sermon, how hardened in sin etc. "Would build house on the very skulls of those he had ruined?, mingle their bones with the frame work & cement it together with their blood, while the groans of his victims was the music of his apartments etc." I have not got it right, but that is the substance.  I have washed your bed blankets today, besides other woolen and a few white clothes, got done, and floors washed a little after twelve. To be sure Samuel "stood over me" and helped me all he could - pounded, wrung out the blankets, hung out the clothes etc. so I must not take all the credit to myself. Sewing Circle tomorrow at Mr. Lewis's. All the gentlemen that usually attend meetings as The Hall invited - great jam in the evening.

26th Storms, and I don't go to sewing circle. Am not sorry, for I took cold yesterday I don't feel very smart. Mrs. Crosby called down here this morning - first time she has been out - rather feeble yet. 

        Jane recites right off, with very little hesitation all the Catechism but the last twelve questions. - soon have it all. I think her catechism Bible readings and all make her think about being a christian. Feels sometimes as if she would go right off and be a christian, and then she don't know how" I think she does try hard lately to do right and just as I ant to have her. I want a letter from some of you. Why don't you write? I wish, if you think of it, when Isaac comes back, you would send me one set of Montgomery's works. Margaret wants to read the "Wanderer of Switzerland." I intended to have got it when I was there. We have got most half through Cheever's Lectures. Like it much. Will Almeda lend me the other Volume of Bunyan, and I will send them both home by the first opportunity., as also his Manual of Peace, which I intended to have returned before now. I am getting through the "Interior Life" - Think it  very good book. I think there is no danger of our being too perfect, and I really cannot find as that advocates any more perfection or holiness than the Bible requires. The more I read that, the more I read the Bible, and the longer I love, the more I feel that I ought to try constantly to be holy. - if 'tis right to do right at all, why not to do perfectly right - that is, to try. Yet it does seem as though so much heart evil, as well as outward wrong, could never be subdued, and "brought into subjection." "Thy grace is sufficient for thee" is certainly a strengthening promise.  I don't know as I've anything more  to write. Samuel is going to Bangor - my sheet is about full, worthless as it is, and I'll send it along, hoping he will bring back one from Milo when he come. Good bye all, Lucy.
                                                                                  Jonathan

Lucy & Samuel Hampden
April 2, 1850

                                                                                           Hampden Apr. 2nd [above 3d] 1850

Dear Mother, brethren, & Sisters, 

                                                                       Your goodly and long desired letter which should have been rec'd Saturday, through carelessness of Post Office Clerks. came not to hand until yesterday. I concluded it is Charles' birth day! You see I remember & commemorate all the birth days if I am away from home. "Tis a shocking pity Samuel is so profane, Josie, truly! Would I were at home to laugh with the rest of your "Drawing in perspective" Isaac; - or rather to take your part!  With regard to the drilling, denims, or whatever you are pleased to call it, I am sorry it does not suit, - but it is precisely the stuff that Mrs. Thaxter makes aprons of for her little boy, and I presume after washing, you would not find it too stiff. At any  rate I doubt not Charley would "find his way through it" sooner than you imagine. "Don't you think" Samuel carried me to the dentists' today, who filled four teeth - next Wednes. I go have the rest filled and three decayed roots extracted. They feel nicely tonight. He asks $2.00 a cavity. Will be an expensive job unless he makes some deduction. Said 'twould be a poor job for him & us too, as the cavities were so large, he couldn't put on a face to ask what it was worth to fill them. 
         Dr. Webster is all the talk here - seems to me I never felt so about a murderer & execution before - how dreadful it is from first to last - how much worse than Coolidge. Samuel has come in & going to reading, so I'll stop now.
    Apr. 4th Last day. Windy, & stormy some & did not go to meeting. Mrs. Crosby sent down "Hill Difficulty and other Allegories" by Geo. B. Cheever - belonging to Mrs. Mason. Have

got most through "Lectures on Pilgrim's Progress." Very good. I guess Cheever has studied Bunyan considerable. Stove moved out in the kitchen - looks empty enough in the dining room. Mrs. Crosby and Margaret, Mrs. Bartlett and her sisters Sarah Parker are expected to visit here tomorrow. Their husbands coming to ta. Compliments are hereby sent, requesting the company of Mrs. Metcalf., and as many of her family as can conveniently leave home! How the winds blows! Samuel exchanged his old watch for a large spoon, the other day he bought a mate, an 1/2 dozen tea spoons for ourself, together with two large and 1/2 doz. small ones for Olive, to be sent by her Father, for which he paid to Albert Titcomb, jeweller, the sum of eighteen dollars. 

          A large company of human beings are playing ball in the open field, not far from our house. Samuel bought me some pretty Magazine pictures 'tother day, for four cents apiece. Eliab did actually ride down here with Samuel last Sat. eve, and stay all night, going back with us in the morning. I did certainly invite Charles Harlow to call again, and a few days after when Samuel was going to Bangor, he met him almost down here, and carried him back! He want L. to hire him to work in the mill - said he and his father did not get along together very well!
          I am really sorry Isaac & Joseph cannot write to me only as "Mother says they must." Glad Almeda likes her dress.  Poor Mr. Bumps! I am glad you got the chain for Joseph - should think it would be much easier for him. That Jane I talk of, is Jane - "as if as thought to circumvent Thee" - is'nt that very plain now? I am glad Lydia Keer is a smart woman, glad her house is prettily furnished, and above all, glad she did it herself!!! I see by the papers that Mr. (Bangor) Hedge is settled over the Congregational Church

in Providence R.I. In his farewell at Bangor, he said they were not, as people called them, Unitarians - but Independent Congregationalists." Every one at liberty to believe just what he pleased. I have bought me a de laine gown, and an awful pretty calico., that Samuel was particularly pleased with. 
Apr. 6th Saturday P.M. Finished baking - pies, puddings, beans, bread, doughnuts etc. scalded preserves too. Yesterday Mr. & Mrs. Crosby Mrs. Bartlett & Sarah Parker passed the afternoon here - pretty good time - subject matter for conversation. - Dr. Webster, as usual. Many staid at home, as usual. We don't know yet, but Samuel does not expect to be at the mill - Hathorne only intends to run by day, and won't be willing to pay enough. Samuel thinks he shall get appointed Surveyor in Bangor, but don't know how things will tune? yet. Pity Isaac did not get his application sooner. Clerks are said to be very careless at the Bangor Post Office. Mehitable writes she is coming down when her Father goes, to make us a short visit. I am glad Isaac can stay with Josie so long, and I want him to, but it seems as if I ought to see him some, too. Have you seen in the Tribune a notice that Dr. Munde has bought the "Water works" at or near Northampton, Mass. and "set up for himself." Does Josie continue his baths? You don't hardly write me anything about him, how he gets along - and he never does.

                   The roads are here quite dry and dusty, though the frost is not out - ground shakes under the horses' feet in some places. 8th Apr. Prof. Shepherd preached big sermon yesterday about Prof. Webster. His text wasnot exactly "Murder will out" bit "be sure your sin will find you out," "The soul that sinneth it shall die," and two or three other similar passages. Tendency of sin to discover itself, majisty of law etc. etc. Speaking of the intense

excitement & anxiety of all classes during the trial, and to know the verdict etc. said the steam driver press groaned with its labor night and day, and the steam driver which carried the reeking sheets into every city & village of the land & even that could not satisfy, but the lightning must bear the news on its wings etc.  How it passed from lip to lip - how every heart palpitated to hear the words. Has the verdict come? What is it? Guilty? " This he spoke almost in a whisper - and how still the house was you can judge. Hall has been very full lately. He does preach big sermons. Application you can think out for your selves. Infinity greater perfection of majesty  of God's law - the final tribunal at the judgment day - when not one man only, but a world to be acquitted or condemned. The interest felt there etc. A Mr. Bolan admitted to the church yesterday by profession. Samuel & myself, & three others, by letter. I am got into a students class. Mr. Towns - with Hannah Moore  -The question was brought up whether Satan knew of Christ's divinity when he tempted him, or only considered him a superior, and uncommonly holy man. Hannah said she did'nt believe he understood his divinity, said she "I know he never'd spent his time & strength tempting God to sin." She is a case to talk, as Joseph says. I think Mrs. Jewett is one of a thousand. Mary Tower & intended is in the Seminary here. A Baptist - who would have thought it? I'd like to get acquainted with him. Guess I better go to washing -been writing while my  clothes boiled.

                                I suppose that it is decided that I shall not work for Hathorne this year he only runs the mill by day for want of stock suppose he feels poor, only offers me $25 to do more than I done last year. for $45 The Surveyor Gen. was appointed yesterday, Albert Smith, think I will have no difficulty getting deputised, then I must get employment. 

Think I will take Isaac's note when he comes down.                 

                                                                                              S.W.F.

Lucy N.F.  Hampden
May 4, 1850   
Hampden May 4th 1850.
Dear Folks all
It is Sat. morn and I ought to be about my baking. Bell is clearing away the table , when I didn't want her to, and Jane picking over beans. Want to send a letter Monday, so I must write this morning.
Nice good letters have been received from you all at sundry times lately - Apr. 17th, 24th &c. good folks. Hope you'll "continue the treatment." I want to comer to Milo dreadfully - think I shall a day or two ere long. What good times you all seem to be having there. Mother seems to be very happy about the xxxxxx excellence of her boys. With regard to Isaac's labored explanation, dissertation or whatever on health, I can only say that the amount of action of our "horse stable carpet" made neither of us sick - By the way he would honor it with a more respectable name, I know, if he should see it. it is really very handsome - every body even Mrs. Thaxter says so. I shall certainly pack it up and carry it to Milo when I go, that you may see it! I have taken cold two or three times lately - for two or three days have had lameness in side, shoulder, neck, head, "ague cheek" &c. night before last slept none till two o'clock - kicked, groaned and turned from side to side, then got up. (Samuel made a fire), and slept nicely in the sofa till morning. Better now, but have to keep bundled up. Isaac seems extremely anxious that Mother should obtain some information respecting "Antoinette Dunbarton." I will cheerfully give in such testimony as I am able - It may perhaps be called partly circumstantial, partly
written up the side: We find lots of May flowers on the hill opposite here.

positive. First the positive. In a letter "Goffstown N.H. Nov. 11th 1849" and signed 'I.L." I find the following passage "You know I never found any body that I took a fancy to. Well, there is a girl teaching school in Goffstown now, daughter of a neighboring clergyman, intelligent and intellectual, went out with the first company of Miss Beecher's teachers, one of the most modest pretty behaved little girl you ever saw. You could not help loving her just to see how good she looks. I believe if I dared to I should try to get acquainted with her. &c &c."
Again in another bearing date "18th Dec. 1847. I find the following. Speaking of the little school teacher. But then she is so good, I do like her, nobody can help it. I have got acquainted with her - have been over to her father's two or three times. He is a clergyman in the next town, a very good and pleasant man. and I like "Antoinette" better and better the more I become acquainted with her. I wonder if I were not over there last evening and my horse ran away, and I had to come home afoot five or six miles!" &c.&c. "'I.L.M." For the circumstantial I shall merely refer to a letter written by Isaac's chum, wherein he alludes in a jocose way to "families of the neighboring clergyman &c." I would call your attention to the fact that these revelations were particularly called for and requested by Isaac, for Mother, or they would never have been made. I am particularly obliged for the flower seeds - they have been planted. Am sorry Jos. was disappointed in "Hull's Laurel." Who is Charles' hired man, pray? Haven't you got a great freshet up there? Much obliged for rags, though the rug was completed when they arrived! The dark green would have been highly acceptable & useful had it come sooner. I'll bring them

back when I come. Isaac, Bell wants something to read, and I took the liberty to draw forth from your trunk "Shirley," "Lamartine" and above all "David Copperfield" - How nice that is, and how we want the rest of it. She has read most of it to me. There are a number at least of your books here. Upham, two Vols. Laurel, Rhetorical Reader, some Greek books, Kavanagh, Hactimus, Evangeline &c. "Margaret Smith" and "Whipple's Lectures" I lent to Lissie Doe. Bell wants to read them very much, but Lis has gone to Portland to spend vacation & marry Mary Shirley (bridesmaid) and I can't get there now. Catechism, cord & tassel shall be duly attended to. I must go bake - Samuel will finish. In love and haste. Lucy. The big beautiful Cactus is all dead, but Samuel bought of Brockmiller two more - one two years old with four buds, said to be handsomer than the old one - and one a year old - no buds.
We desire you if you please to send us a box of your nice new butter forthwith. Letter from Ann recently. Samuel will buy a cow soon - make no butter - sell milk to the branding house. Please send the butter by carts soon as convenient, to be left at his stopping places. Wish you could also send a Monk's hood Lily, Flax & roots at the same time. I have not been to sewing circle for two or three weeks - stormy &c. Mrs. Jewett has been quite sick - well now - Charles Jenkins better - believe I wrote you that he had several attacks of hemmorage, which reduced him very much and much and much alarmed his friends. Jane has got a new Atlas & gets along nicely with her lessons. Has got through the Catechism. Mrs. Goddard's little babe weighed 4 1/2 pounds, had fits all the time & died in two or three days - she cried I cried a great deal. I have got some acquainted with her. Our dozen biddies have laid some 20 dozen eggs

J.M. Metcalf

                  I think I owe you answers to numerous letters. Hulls Laurel you may return Dunen will exchange for other books. Theory of a future life I have not seen. Dunen had it not but told me the price and would send for it wanted. In Dealing's absence Thurston and I got new papers for the John B. and put Capt. Jellison in possession. Dealing come home feeling deeply or highly indignant determined to have Paul go in the School while we were equally determined that the would not go "in even scale etc." at length Dealing offered us $25, to say what we would give or take times1/2 down 1/2 in six months with interested we offered to give or take $425. Dealing sold. so that I had to pay $100, by reason of which I shall not be able to make any payment to you at present. I suppose that six per cent is as much as you can realize from your money if you feel it to be safe I will pay you that and be much obliged beside. The Senator will probably be finished to day. his repairs will amount to about $6,25 so that I send you the a/c of sales I have called the flour exchange for the Senator $5,50 in the trade with Hathorne it was called $5,70 bit to take $5,50 for it 3 ms without interest which was a much as it would be sold for

[left-hand side] This spring - sold about 12 doz.  - They give us now six or eight per diem.

Hampden May 11th 1850.

Dear people all

          First, how my pen did spatter writing "people"! Next, how pleased and glad to receive the letter, butter and posies. Next, for the news, - you must know I have a boarder! Capt. Stevenson's lady, who sustained some sort of a fraternal relation to "Mrs. Capt. Mark March, from Saco on the Biddeford side," that you have heard me tell of, please so earnestly to get boarded for a week, while her husband is loading his vessel at the Mill, that we took her in, though 'tis quite imagneable to me. I was quite unwell a few days before Bell went home - took cold, ague etc. but am quite well and smart now. I wanted to go to Milo next week, but cannot now unless Mrs. S. goes away in season, which I do not expect. I will do my best about a carpet next time I go to Bangor. Tell Josie I hope he was not done with malus aforethought. I see by the papers that there have been $20.00 raised in Boston for the Prof. Websters family. Mrs. Dr. Parkman headed the list with $500.00. Looks well in her, does'nt it?  13th Mond. morning Mrs. Stevenson reading in the sitting room, Mrs. Finnigan doing a fortnight's washing, Mrs. Goddard making me a call - myself cleaning up, washing cupboards & getting dinner. Samuel going to Bangor, and Jane delighting herself with Mrs.

Finnigan's gabble. Eliab was down Sat. night. Why did'nt we think to ask you to send us some of the mix horticultural beans, that I so much love. We've got some tomatoes, nasturtiums, squashes etc. guess we'll have a little garden.
[lightly-printed figures not transcribed]

May 14th 1851

J.M. Metcalf
                            Yours of the 7th inst. was duly rec' & read. I will make my book on flour a/c to agree with yours after a sufficient time has elapsed to destroy any hope of recovering the stolen amount. Who is Capt. Jellison? he is skipper of the Brandywine., further I say not except that S.D. picked him up the B. arrived in Bangor Saturday gone fifteen days, stocked of $85, is now loading with shooks, banisters shingles, freights & cover $150 to Boston. the Senator sailed to day.

On making up the interest a/c on flour I cost to May 7th and deducted interest on amount of sale, from the apposite amount, you will want to ch'g me interest from May 7th I think I will buy the Red Cow your Mother spoke of, if there appears any way of transporting her to Hampden please to improve it I may either this or some other week, be up after her. Am much obliged for your very kind consideration of me in regard to old vessels.

                                                                              S.W. F.

[postmark] BANGOR ME MAY 1?                                                       5
[faint numbers in pencil]

               J.M. Metcalf Esq.
                         Milo

[right upside down] Hampden May 11, 1850

Lucy   July 1. 1850  Hampden                                             Hampden July 1st 1850                  

                                                     Samuel has gone to Bangor, Jane to school, and I am left alone. We had a fine time coming down, only sorry we did not bring Lute. Stopped two hours at Bradford, most of which time I slept refreshingly on the hard narrow sofa. We were just in time for the stage dinner. Samuel went to the table. I did not - he brought me ham & potatoes, bread, & butter, strawberry and custard pie. I did not feel as well that day as for some previous days - was very tired at night, slept almost all day Sunday, feel quite nicely today. We got here some after five. Jane came with a fine lot of strawberries soon after, and who do you guess next? Charles Harlow, of course! Very glad to see us -very sociable etc. for half an hour or so, then wished to speak alone with Samuel, wanted to borrow five dollars and give good security! He would probably have got it if I had not previously heard of Eliab's trials. I pitied the fellow - to walk away down here to ask such a favor of an almost entire stranger, and be refused too! Albina's bread was good - and quite a blessing to us. I hope you'll think to send my green veil by Lucy. I forgot it. Mrs. Goddard is very sick again with her breast - worse than ever. They feared she would have fits yesterday. I expected it when she came up here that damp morning. I forgot to talk all I intended with Almeda about her bonnet. If I were in her place I would have a black straw, lined with black, if she prefers it to white, trimmed with crepe or ribbon just as she likes, and a plain black lace veil with broad hem - all of which would be very cheap and proper.  These I would have purchased immediately. I wear them this summer light & comfortable as

They would be. Then in the long rides & stormy weather of another winter I would ear the old, and save the new one for another summer.  Say now, will you not give directions as to price, style of trimming etc. and let me send one right up? There seemed to be so much to think about and so little time to think when I was at Milo, many things were forgotten as usual. I hardly know what Mother concluded about her parasol. It seemed all the way home as if I had hardly seen any of you. Shan't Samuel and I go keep Pa's farm, live up there with you always? I half want to - only I am not fit for a farmer's wife. Mrs. Thaxter and Lissie Doe were down Sat. afternoon. I staid stowed some split peas for dinner Sunday, and built a rice pudding - Peas real good. Toast and strawberries for supper. Eliab came down. Guess I'll go lay down now, and finish my letter after Lucy comes. Mother's account which she wished for I have taken from Samuel's day book. If she can pick out all the shoes, she will do better than I can. 'Tis just the same as your so I won't send it. I have bought 1/2 doz. more 'kerchiefs - two for Albina. Tell Almeda I did not think what I was about when I took the 3.00 for Lucy's use & behoof, as I intended to get her whatever she needed.  With her permission I will forthwith use a part of it to get her bonnet - will she not write immediately her wishes & conclusions? The bacon is good as ever, Mother, & I am cooking it for dinner this day Teusday. Pegotty is "pretty comfortable." Samuel has gone strawberrying - making a business of getting some to preserve.

       Lucy got here safe and sound last night- pretty tired from jolts and jams. Has helped me make some bread, and pies from the green strawberries & currants. Samuel, Jane & Bridget picked eight pounds yesterday, which with Samuel's assistance I preserved this forenoon - had more than I expected to get. They are not near so thick here as at Milo. And so Isaac's going away - it seems as though he must'nt, and yet I know 'tis best. I am glad he has so good an appointment. What in the world will poor Josie & Mother * all the rest of you do? All losing your father & guardian at once? The matter of Alfred Holman shall be inquired into, & information given as speedily as possible.

[top]Sweet Briar with what grows on it for Joseph. Some of you ought to give Alfred employment after he gets to Milo, had'nt you?
Dear Mother                                                                                                                                     Hampden July 9th 1850.

                                 Alfred Holman came down here to day made us a good long call and took dinner. I am very sorry it has happened so, he understood that he was wanted immediately if he went to Milo, and has lost his place where he was at work, in consequence is now out of employment. He is going to Milo tomorrow and I hope Charles or somebody will hire him, so he need not lose his time. I like him better & better - he seems really kind hearted & good, says he should really like to go and take care of Joseph if he can - seemed to feel very much for him. I hope you will not fail to get him when Isaac goes away. 'Tis not every one that would find such an interest in Joseph as he does. I think him a whole hearted fellow. You would rather have him about the house than some folks too. I should rather give considerable more to have him. when is Isaac going, where, and what to do? Why can't you write me a word about it? I was intending to go to Bangor this afternoon to get some things for Lucy etc. but Samuel is surveying at the Mill all day. Surveyed at Bangor for Treat & Hardy day before & part of yesterday, went to Old Town for Hawthorne yesterday P.M. I am smart as a steel cricket - have grown strong and well ever since I came from Milo. Mrs. Finnigan washed yesterday - most three weeks wash, you know. Lucy and I have done all the ironing excepting calicoes. to-day , I did most all, besides getting Pea Soup (which

was amazing good!) Custard pudding and warm bread for dinner. Lucy is low, but very nice and faithful about everything, which is worth more than dashing you know. She and I did a real baking of beans, pudding, apple & currant pies, bread, fried doughnuts, and got a boiled dish for dinner besides, last Sat. forenoon!  In the P.M. Jenny churned, I fixed the butter and worked over all the rest, putting in more salt. I found it would not possibly keep. Lucy is very quiet and thoughtful, much more considerate than she used to be, needs a little reminding now and then, but is very good to think of things without being told. I have the girls sleep in separate chambers, for the well-being of both, and as I judge, the particular comfort & benefit of both. To relieve Almeda's mind about Lucy' looking old womanish, tell her I have once more made it more scanty & fixed little sleeves. It is enough prettier to pay for it., did not look so well before as I expected. Lucy is a good large girl, but not a woman yet. She is in Mrs. Jewett's class in S.S.  Likes her very much. I went to meeting sabbath afternoon. Mrs. J. and Hannah Moore enquired kindly and particularly for Josie and Mother. I am going to get Lissie Boid or somebody also to cut my new calico. Think I shall get Lucy a Gingham & have it cut at the same time. I have bought two kerchiefs for Albina, which I will send then John goes home if they do not come down and there is no previous opportunity, Lucy says Almeda wants some too.  Think we make quite a business buying handkerchiefs and shoes. I have already got ten kerchiefs, and will get more for

Almeda and Lucy if they are not gone. Sidney Thaxter & wife made me a call last Friday. Strawberries are being gone here - my preserves are very nice. Eliab says so Never did I see gooseberries hang on bushes so thick as they do here. Alfred insinuated that he would do Mrs. Searles' haying if she had not already engaged someone - thinks he can work for the "Major" if no where else.

               I am going to take Lucy with me to Mrs. Crosby's some day. Brown wants Samuel to go way up somewhere where he scaled this week, guess he will go Thursday - he gave a week or more - John will keep the horse down there and come here nights. Senator loading again- gone ten days this time. Samuel will earn something with her, if he don't have work, won't he? We had about done haying! only he has been too busy to get in the hay to-day. Jane is pretty fly away at home, but as near as I can learn is a real good girl at school. She got in a phlurry of passion at Mrs. Dove's disputing about the comparative beauty of Charlie and Mrs. Bickford's baby with somebody she never saw Charlie or heard of him before - only made believe to hector her. Said Charles was like an own brother to her, she would'nt stand that etc. and finally went off in the other room and screamed just as loud as she could, till Mrs. Dove, after coaxing a good while, threatened to inform me if she did not to go her supper in just five minutes. Jane told me all about it before I saw Mrs. Dove, which looked well in the child. What a letter I have written, and only intended when I sat down, to say a few words about Alfred. Wish you'd any of you write so to me. Eli & John were here the 4th. Good bye  Affec. daught. Lucy.


[ Previous letters spelling is Lissie Doe, here her mother is referred to as Mrs. Dove]

10 July - This letter has been in Eliab's possession - forgotten to mail - a good while. I will now put in a word or two & send it because I can not spare time to write another before  goes to Old town. This morning at six o'clock. It is now five. Day before yesterday Eliab came with two great white horses and three girls - Liz Doe, Mary Pomeroy - who is on a visit at Bangor- and pretty little Miss Lunt whom I had never seen before. and took tea with me. He sent the night before to me, so I had time to prepare - had previously some mie? cake made, made some tarts real nice, some of the best [[Milk? emptings?}} bread you ever saw, strawberry preserve, & currants mingled with sugar - we all had a lively time you may imagine. I some tired of course. Yesterday good brother Temple made his appearance about 9 A.M. stopped till after ten - He & Lucy seemed almost
[postmark] BANGOR ME JULY 19                                                                                 5

                                                                     Mrs. Anna M. Metcalf
                                                                                     Milo
                                                                                                 Maine

overjoyed to see each other. I think he is a real good man. He invited us very strongly to come up to the Seminary Friday, when we go to hear Mr. Little's eulogy on Pres. Taylor. Think we shall go on Lucy's account- should like to have her visit the Seminary. Isaac only came in here fifteen or twenty minutes. I will write about it next time. I was so disappointed. Sweet Briar I had not time to press - is not in very good shape - but believe 'tis just the season now. Will try when the grass is dry if I can get another. If Almeda could see how delighted Lucy was with her cotton, she would write every week I know. In awful haste   Lucy
[upside down] Lucy Hampden July 9 1850

Lucy Hampden
July 12. 1850

                                                                                                                                                  Hampden July 12th. 1850.
                             Father came last night after John - is going home tomorrow if he does not tonight. I send four kerchiefs for Almeda and Albina. There are two more here which Lucy is going to hem & use while here, & Almeda can have them or I will keep them just as she likes - tell her to write. Lucy is quite impatient because Mother nor James have neither of them written yet. Why did they not tell me what to do about a bonnet, so that I can send it by this good opportunity. When is Isaac coming?
              I bought a small plaid pink muslin for Lucy yesterday could not find a pretty gingham. This is stout & does'nt fade - also aprons, stockings. gloves etc. Samuel got twenty pounds of beef - leg. after steak was cut off - for, 25 yesterday very fat -such lots of marrow and fatings.  - pieces of marrow half as large as my fist came tumbling out which he cut it into. We had a good steak for breakfast, s[t]enough for a dinner to Mr. Goddard - have a nice soup for dinner, and am cooking the rest, which is a great boiler full, to make mince pies! Called to see Lissie Doe yesterday. She is acquainted with Mr. Temple. The night before I gave quite an account of Milo & the country round there in a vestry meeting at the first parish, she says he is considered quite talented and an excellent scholar at the Seminary, but is exceedingly eccentric much ridiculed by some. I am thinking it will take Isaac some days to pack, he has so many things accumulated at Milo. If you get this before he comes, wish you'd

send me one or two of your good turnips- can't get any here but little this years english - don't like them. don't forget my veil. Prof. Webster's confession, Gen. Taylor's death, dreadful fire & lots of life at Philadelphia etc. you have probably heard of before now. What valuable affair the Telegraph is!

Send back Anna's letter first opportunity.

                                                            Mrs. A.M. Metcalf
                                                                                  Milo

right side and bottom upside down I have just been out in the yard and picked beautiful white rose buds, blush and hundred leaf with buds, making a most loveable boquet. I'm saving them for Samuel but I'd gladly cheat him out of them. & give them to Josie or Mother if I could. Our peas and taters are in bloom. Mrs. Crosby called night before last. Guess I'll have a nice lot of mince pies tomorrow. Wish I could send you one. Samuel does not go up river. Wish Joseph would send me some of his 'Testers' he told about to put in my book. Samuel is haying this week for Mr. Goddard who cuts the hay on this place. Lucy and Jane have gone over on the hill to look for Blueberries. Wish we had any raspberries down here. Suppose they are beginning to open at Milo. Have just finished bosoming Libe's shirt and making his collars/

Lucy & Samuel     Hampden                                                                                                     19th July
Dear Mother & folks
July 19. 1850

                                               Lucy has begun a letter to her Mother - does not make very good heading- she needs to practice - finds it very difficult to express herself she says. I try to help her, but she thinks I can't very well. Mrs. Goddard's sister is fitting her dress today. I am desirous to get it done for her to wear next sabbath, as he other one is somewhat soiled. If Almeda has a fine white skirt which she can send as well as not, perhaps she had better, to wear under her muslin. Am having it cut high outside, lining loose with adging round the tip. Almeda must it think I am extravagant - the child certainly needed another dress here. She & Mr. Temple seemed as pleased to see each other as our brother & sister. He seems to feel very much for the Milo people. I have made Lucy a small plaid, blue gingham apron, looks real pretty. I was much disappointed not to hear Mr. Little's Eulogy on the President today, but it rained. Samuel has engaged with Mr. Hathorne the same as last year. Is at Old Town lots lately, and expects to be more next week. Sat. P.M. Lucy's dress is all done. -sets beautifully. The poor girl has pretty hard work writing letters - she has been so unused to excitement that the company got her all into fidgets the other day. Jane would enjoy just such a spice every day, but Lucy would not endure it much better than I should. They did carry on. I tell Lucy she must try to learn herself to be calm under all circumstances. I had a number more things to say, but the hurry of finishing off Lucy's dress made me forget them. We are going to visit the Seminary some day. Isaac had been looking for Eliab after the stage for in till most

dark - had just started with a horse to come down here, and met him with his girls going home. So he got in with them turned about & all posted back here about nine o'clock. I had just unrigged, put on my old loose dress and laid down - didn't care though anything about it.

 Lucy had just gone to bed when they came back, said she could not compose herself. I feel happy at all, but when she read her Mother's letters, it calmed her at once. Says she is perfectly contented & likes to stay, if Almeda is willing, I should like her to stay till school is done - four weeks longer.

Lucy thinks I ought to write a few lines to Joseph. have nothing of interest to say have been at work for Hathorne last week $55 per month he has bot a stock of logs for the mill. his two purchases of logs amount to $30,00, without even seeing one of them. I got to Old Town tomorrow morning shall be there most of next week, write to us often

                                                                                                                                                   SWF

[upside down] I don't think I could possible stand it to have Jane at home with her. Shall have to send one of them away certainly. Jane is such a fly away, I have the girls both go to meetings forenoons, and I stay at home, on account of S. School. Then I go in the afternoon & take one of them. I was very sorry not to see Isaac more.

Lucy Hampden

 Aug. 1850

Dear Mother, Joseph & all
                                          Lucy seems to desire to go home, and as I do not now need her help. I am going to pack her up and put her aboard stage tomorrow. It is Sabbath night & I cannot write much - you much wished for letter came last week, but not a word about the school or sick teacher which I requested so particularly in my last letter and which Lucy was in a twister? to hear about. I send two skeins unbleached cotton (which by the way cannot be obtained so good as in old times,) and  two 45 spools for Mother 2 Albince. The tidy I feat will be rumpled - 'tis not so large as I intended to make, but will do better than none. I have got my rug (sewing on pieces) most done. I spoke with Hannah Moore today  - she is going to Hartford a week from next Thursday. I will endeavor to get the book, and call on her this week. The other things Eliab will get before he goes. Mr. Brown is going away, and he cannot as he intended, go this week. Am exceedingly obliged to Joseph for his care of my fictional book - hope he will send me something - I send Smellies Philosphy for him. Samuel says I may take Jane and go up and stay as long as I wish - he will board at Hardy's - but I do not think it will be expedient or proper, though I do want to go and stay with

dear Joseph, and write for him, and help him and love him. I want to see you all much. You inquire for my health. My health is verry good, Thank you! I am writing to Ann. Eliab has your last letter and I don't remember whether there is any thing more to say in answer or not. Paper and ink can not conveniently be sent in Lucy's bag. Eliab will take them. Do write - do write - do write often. How does Albina do, and why don't she ever write to me? How does Charles stand in taking care of Joseph? good night - Your affectionate daughter & sis, Lucy.
P.S. Letter from Isaac last week - the poor fellow seems to have much responsibility and care. I hope he won't get sick - says much about not hearing from Milo. Mond. noon. I will get 1/2 ream of paper and some ink when he gets to Bangor if there is time.

                                                                                                                                   good bye

I send enclosed ten dollars on a/c

                                                                                                                   S.W.F

                                                                                                               Mother

Lucy & Samuel  Hampden
Aug. 3. 1850

                                                                                                                            Hampden Aug. 3rd 1850.

Dear Mother and folks

                               You don't writ to me, and don't write to me and don't write to me, till I am sick and tired of not having so many letters! Some little scribblings to Eliab or Josie's business etc. and a little meagre note from Almeda, mostly to Lucy - no more for a long, long time, when I want so much to hear of every thing. No letter from Isaac yet, either. We learned from John, who came Teusday that Alfred said Joseph was certainly better - stood alone in the floor for a minute.
 Samuel is busy as busy can be in the mill, up to Old Town etc. Bennett was so little respected and consequently so much imposed upon by the mill men, that Hathorne got out of patience and turned him out of the synagogue this week - our friend Abel Hardy takes charge now. The day before Bennett left as he was passing under the step, some one poured a pail of cold water directly on him - wet his best hat and "go to snutins'" sadly. That is only one of many things that were constantly taking place. Day before yesterday Lucy and I spent the afternoon at Mrs. Crosby's. I have made seven tumblers of currant jelly - real nice - and Jane is picking the Gooseberries to preserve today. I have made Lucy's dress - she has worn it to meeting two sabbaths - my new one, and had my pink muslin and pretty blue calico made over in fashion - also made Jane's

light calico that her Mother sent her - her "bonnet with reafs," you know. We do not have much of a school, and I am satisfied that Jane would learn more at home than at school, of everything useful at least, and if your teacher has commenced again, I think Lucy had better go home immediately, as she ought to go to school - our school does not keep but a fortnight longer and I would just as lief Jane would not go another day - besides I am as strong and well now, as before I was sick, about, and could do very well with what Jane could help if she did go to school. Lucy and Jane are both good girls - Jane is much better than when school first began - only flighty - but take them both together, my patience is tried sometimes. Lucy tries to do right, and is a real good girl, but Almeda has allowed her to be so slow and puttering, that I fear she will never learn to be really smart and quick about work. It is an utter impossibility for her to hurry on any occasion. Tell Almeda from me that she had better do better with Lissie - of she does not work but an hour in a day, let her move that hour. It worries me to see any body drag round in the heat two hours ti do what might much easier be done in half an hour. We have not yet visited The Seminary, but intend to that and Hardy's just as soon as Samuel can "get time."He is much poorer than ever I saw him before - constant care and vexation with paddies and "green hands" that don't know anything. You must'nt expect me to come to Milo again this summer. I will think of you and love you much here as well as there, but can't think of breaking up your

no how - am so glad I went when I did, so as to see Isaac a little.= - how did Josie like it to have him entreat Alfred away - good chance for Alfred. I am glad for him, and probably Isaac could not get another so good in ten towns. If Joseph, our dear Joseph, is getting better any, why in the wold may I not know it from himself, or somebody that knows, instead of partly hearing of it in a round about way? It is not fair not to write more. Just a fortnight from the time our peas bloomed, we had a mass of green peas, and they have grown astonishingly, could have a mass every day, and do, almost. How different they are from those Samuel bought in the market - tasteless things. Lucy's muslin dress was cut Friday forenoon and I finished it, every loop and stitch, for her to wear to meeting Sunday, besides taking all the forenoon, my big jar full of gooseberries. What shall be done with the black currants? One mill man's name is Asa. Mr. Hardy spells it acy Acy! You remember Mr. Emerson, don't you Josie? I don't feel right about it that Prof. Webster is to be executed. Gov. Briggs is too good a man to be accessory to such an act. Mr. Temple shows himself at The Hall every sabbath forenoon! We have cucumbers and do all eat them. though I wish we would'nt! They is good. Why don't Isaac write to me? You need'nt trouble about Lucy's being green and awkward - she appears well enough, only stares a little too much. We wish you to write the next mail after receiving this whether your school is teaching. If you don't, you may expect to see Lucy home before you are

"ready for her." Sat. eve. Samuel has brought me no Cutters today, so I'll finish and send this by Monday's mail. He says he'll write a little to Josie dear, so I'll leave the rest of the page. Lucy will write next time. Do, do, do write to me. Lucy.
Samuel says I am too hard a nag to Almeda - but you know how much it all means - nobody knows better than I that Lucy is one of the best girls that ever was - amen.
To J.M. Metcalf Gentleman
I learned to night, that Omnibus is numbered with the things that were and that the Independent California bill was taken up in Senate by a majority of thirteen. I expect for the rest of the season to be much confined to the mill at least so much that it will be a waste of eyesight for you to look for us at Milo. What an overturn as turned up at the mill this week six men some of them so long here that they felt like real estate have, been discharged and Chauncy C. Bennett gone home to recruit. Schooners work slow this year the Senator has now been gone almost four weeks to Cambridge. I learned to night that Miss Hannah Moore is engaged to the Hartford association for a teacher to go to the West. S.W. and wife Lucy 
If any of you want any more shoes or handkerchiefs let us know before Lucy goes.

Lucy says there are a great many things that she wants to say to her Mother, but she cannot put them on paper - says she is going home so soon she will wait and speak them by word of mouth.

    A great Circus in Bangor last week. Our good Prof. Shepard said he went to see the Circus and was very much pleased with their movements,. What do you think of that? Explanation. They were passing by - he went to the window to see them, and was pleased with their movements because they were moving out of town! Old City Hall has been moved back - is going to be fixed over and be used temporarily for a third Parish meeting house. Prof. Shepard is going to be our Pastor. ? for Mother - 'tis no use for me to do it up, as it will get tumbled going home. Starch is very stiff, lay it on a table or bed & pull it all out.

even and let it dry so, then twill be stiff and keep in place. Mr. Crosby's 'hypo' is going off gradually. Warren Furber has a recent son. There's a darling pretty way of making drapes - new - which I will send a pattern of to Albina if I can get it before Lucy goes home - loose in front with sack to fit the form behind. Seems to me there was a deal more that I wanted to say, but can't think if it now. 
Eliab talks of going to Milo next week. If he does, guess I had better send Lucy. good bye.

Lucy & Samuel Hampden
Aug. 13 1850

                                                                                                                                                     Hampden Aug. 13th 1850.

Dear Mother

                 It is after breakfast next day after Lucy went home. I was amazing smart yesterday, and Jane was just as good as mortal could wish for. Though the poor child cried by spells all day about Lucy's going away. I expect she'll make quite a person yet notwithstanding she is so passionate and fly away at times. I did the washing, (washed a web & a piece of new cloth besides) got the clothes all out, boiled a blueberry butter pudding for dinner, made two huge loaves of smacking good blueberry cake, and two loaves of bread. Jane washed the dining room and kitchen floors as nicely as I could do it, did up the work, waited and tended it, and  - we got all done, hair combed, dressed up etc. a good while before the dinner- but - I went & laid down on the sofa after dinner & unwittingly fell asleep with nothing over me, and in this way, or by the wind blowing on me when washing out on the platform, I got cold in my head & neck, and the way head teeth and all did jump and sing! as if they enjoyed it better than I did! Samuel got up in the night made a fire and established me in the rocking chair with a comforter round me, prepared a nice dish of cocoa, if thereby I might get in a perspiration - as I was preparing to drink the same, the dish slipped in my hand, and what a piece of work!

as good luck would have it, it was not quite boiling hot, though it made me smart some, but comforter shawl and nightclothes - O my! Well I changed my clothes, got excited into a perspiration, drank what was left, wen to bed, slept nicely, and am all over it this morning. It seems lonely enough since Lucy went away - she is very quiet generally, but a good deal of company after all - more companionable  for me than Jane is. She left her sun bonnet and knitting work here. I will send them by Eliab. I had the pleasure of seeing Mrs. Wooster Parker last week in Bangor, said she had been wanting to go and see Joseph ever since he has been at Milo.
Aug. 14th Samuel brought me your letter this forenoon - good folks - well done. If you have written a large double letter any time since I was at Milo, it was undoubtedly lost somewhere, as I have never seen it. Finished my rug and ironed today. The rug is real pretty. So it is. It was considerable work, but I do not regret the time or labor, 'twice be a piece of workmanship for folks to remember Lute by when she is dead and gone, you know. Well I am glad Eliab is going up - wish I could go too. Jos. your friends - "occupation, operations & prosperity" - M. Crosby not quite through her school of 16 weeks on the Avenue road grows poor upon it too, but is much liked, and laboring to do goo. I see her occasionally at church. H.A. Moore I generally say "how do you do" to sabba' day - she has had a bad cold- starts a week from tomorrow for Hartford. Mrs. Jewett shakes hands hard, when at all. Mr. J. smiles, bows, looks glad to

see me, and every body else. E. Boyd I very seldom see or speak with, as she sits 'together side and gets out first. Turkey Savory I never heard of before, and know nothing about. J. L. Ricker smiles & makes the "salaam" when I see him, which is not often. L.D. Thurston has just gone into partnership with Samuel sending a load of ashes to a quaker somebody somewhere! Thats all I've heard about him for a long time. Ann Thurston is spending the summer with friends away - her health improved. The Dea. sings constantly and vigorously at the Hall. "Lydia" comes to meetin' every Sunday. When I come across her path, she looks out of her funny eyes, and nods her head at one. Can I give you any more satisfactory information? hey? Bancroft's Hist. U.L. Mehitable was reading. I thought I should much like to. It is my intention to go to Bangor tomorrow, purchase the desired "Lady", call and sat good bye & leave it. I wish & wish & wish that Samuel could sell Cub and buy Beck, but then I could not drive Beck, and he could not let her: Cub, you see, more than earns his keeping all the time, hardly a day but somebody is after him - sometimes so we can hardly get him to use ourself. I don't know what I will think best about it. I am writing to Ann - have had no letter from her for a long time. I do hope she will come this fall. If she would come home, and Josie dear get well, how happy we would be! I don't know really, Mother, but it would be punishing brother Dole enough to make him read your writing with good ink, unless you cross your tias and dot your ayes better than you do sometimes. Have Eliab take back the trunk. so if I should take a notion to go

to Milo, of which there is small probability, I could have someat to pack my things in. The hosen which I send (Janet's are getting too small) please color most anything but black, at your convenience. I think that birch bark is a beautiful color for stockings. If you can conveniently before winter, I wish you would knit Samuel a pair or two of gloves. He will need a pr. of coarse and one of fine. I'll knit a pr if you'll send me some yarn! Ain't I good and obliging? I have made my gooseberry preserve and 'tis nice. I wish I had something more to say, but don't see as I have, guess Samuel will write some. Jane is first the best girl -don't know how long it will last? We have no Cholera here, but Dysentery (bad form) is very prevalent.

                                                                                             Image of horse with "On horses, or asses." written across its body

Well as for horses I don't know. I ought not to sell Cub, he is worth more for Coutts than Miss Bee, and I can get the hay for a hoss of Coutts best of than any other man. I know that Rebecca would not be of so much present value as Cub but would be improving if Coutts will buy Cub and promise to pay me $70. I will buy Bee if I can pay as soon as Charles wants the money if he wants to sell for $100, perhaps a note on three months would pay his debt, if so I could buy, but if he wants cash I can't trade - we are having to repair the plant, & timber say $400, which will keep me rather short. Capt.Jellison moved to Belfast last trip and in consequence he looses more on less time every trip. Guess I must look up another Capin. Eye umed Hathorne foretene dolens tu daze thiss weke Know mowen til deth              acy 3hmensun
What do you spose has got into Samuel

Dear Mother

               Lucy? Lily?did not go today as I expected last night - she and Julia came back about 11 A.M. to start new tomorrow morning. Charles Harlow dropped in unexpectedly  to dinner - queer fellow. Capt. Stevenson caught and kissed me vigorously, whereat his better half rebuked him and he said it was not a carnal kiss, but according to scripture, greetings with a holy kiss! A monstrous great crazy beggar came in today. The first one I ever saw that I was afraid of I believe - send down for Samuel, but he was gone before he got here. If there is any pretty good grass to be attained up there, I wish some of you would call and save a few handfulls for me. Eliab said fall meadow, and blue joint I believe, had not gone to seed. I had quite a lot of various kinds, but let Mrs. Thaxter have them as she could not get more. I suppose swale and meadow grass are yet in bloom, and they are prettiest for vases, because drooping - if you find any please stand them up in an old pot or something, so that they may wilt and dry drooping, put them in a paper & send them by any convenient opportunity. Samuel Thurston introduced me to his little wife last sabbath. Tiger would'nt go with Mehitable this morning though I gave him an extra breakfast in consideration of his journey, - he seems to like living here pretty well. Jane is today offered a cent for

every morning that she will get up by five o'clock.



Mother
[upside down]Lucy Hampden

                        Sept. 1850

Lucy                Hampden
Sept. 11. 1850

                                                                                                                                Hampden Sept. 11. 1850

Dear People at home

                                  I went shopping yesterday! Purchased the one pr of hose in payment of 25 cents, which was all I could get. The other two for Eliab has to give to Mr. Temple, who is yet in Bangor. Mr. Kimball as left - what shall be done with the towel? I also got ten yds of the above mentioned sheeting for Almeda and five for Albina (just enough for a pair of chemise, and very pretty for it too I think.) should think it would be pretty also for children's nightgowns when bleached. You will find this kind all in one piece - 25 yds. For Albina five yds / 4 per yd     .32
               11 3/4 yds, 4 cents " .47
               11 "            9 cents ___99
               3/4 " linen, 50 per yd  37 1/2
                1 brown table cover       75
                1 salt cellar                    10
                                                  $3.00

I could not find any 8 cent sheeting very good. Thought this 9 cent was nice. I put in a bit like what I was making at home for Samuel - you will see it is a min. quality. Thought eleven yds would make Charles two prs of shirts. For Josie's shirts I got 6 yds of the same kind. Ten yds of ,6 1/4 and a 1/2 of, 4 for Almeda makes just a dollar, besides which, from her funds I paid the remaining , 30 besides what the stockings pd for the S. Circle. This is a jumbled up mess - don't know as you will understand it.  Charles Harlow called again yesterday

I have no doubt he is deranged - appears more and more like it. I do wish he would not come here so often. What can I do about it. His cold clammy hand makes me think of Uriah Heep in "Copperfield."

     Notwithstanding Samuel is "repairing the Senator," and is short just now, he felt it his duty to subscribe ten dollars towards purchasing an Organ for the Central Church - Second hand - Mr. Jewett says probably the handsomest one in the state - great bargain only $800. The Sewing Circle are going to get it, only the gentlemen are to help them find five hundred dollars! Have two hundred or 250. towards it now. Mr. Jewett gives 25. Mr. McDonald $80. etc. It was drefful warm the day I came down - stopped for the stage & Jane half an hour or more. Began to rain before we got quite home - rained all night and next day.  There was not a bit of rain here while I was at Milo. It is raining now (Wednes. eve) special hard. Ivor Brild says he hardly ever knew a more healthy summer - take it through. Mrs. Thaxter called yesterday. She came down to spend the day while I was gone. I called to see Lissie Doe yesterday - gone to Glenburn to help fix two brothers off to this cousin. Tell Charles in the overflowing goodness of his heart, he became naughty in sending so much of "that corn." We ate upon it with all our might (dinner of it today, but too old & be very sweet) all we could, and were obliged to give some dozen ears to Mooly today. The cheese is nice and is fast disappearing.

on previous page disappearing Hasel nuts - I remitted a proper share to Eliab. Pickle am in a fine state of preservation. I put them in brine soon as I got home, or rather Samuel did, let them be till Mond. now, when we got some sharp vinegar, soaked them a spell, put them in with spice of divers kind and alum, where they remain hard and nice as you please. I don't know whether to let them be as long as they remain hard & good, or to scald them now, and I forgot to ask Mrs. Thaxter! My Mentor you know. Had to throw away part of my good pudding one and a part apple fries, half loaf of bread etc. Samuel gave one loaf to Mc Caffety's. He did not eat anything at all hardly. I made some cream tarar biscuit Sat. night and went to bed. Mond. Jane and we looked about to see what needed care all over the house, found my jelly moulding, scraped off the top, fitted papers wet with honey? to the tumblers, tied them up again, boiled an apple pudding for dinner, besides done other cooking, churned, did my fortnights washing, washed floors and all, and got done a little after noon - rung the clothes out after tea. Yesterday baked, cleaned up house and made all tidy against Mrs. Lee comes! had two callers (Mrs. L. and Chary Harlow) did a lot of sewing I went shopping - today, rested upon it! had the Committee to set off Mrs. Emery's Thirds all over and about the house. This afternoon, Jane is a fine help. She cried a good deal Sunday, and some since. Troubled because she got put out with the children, and coming away to leave them etc. Wishes she had something to send them, to show them that she loved and thought of them. I tell her I will give her a cent a day for getting up at five oclock till she can earn

J.M. Metcalf Esq.

                                                             I did propose to see you last Week, but was prevented by a press of surveying I earned. Mr. Hathorne in twelve days surveying $51, before I hired with him Mr. Brown tho't I was not competent enough to survey. it is all working just right, The Senator is now loading with dust. Hathorne expects to contract so as keep her at the dust business. Gunnings bill is about $800, he calls her good for ten years service, all that has been done pretty nearly amounts to new taking she now stand the owners of $1860, with some interest, the Brandywine is doing a poor business. got a return from the ashes to day they fell short in Portsmouth of the measure some 450 Bushels. Thurston & I lose about $4, each instead of a profit of $20, each which we should have realized if the cargo had held out. the quakers even too big rogues for Jellison. The Feltcher and Mayo matters remain in "Status quo." Have pd Whiting, shall pay McDonnald when he asks for it; Eliab gave me a meas. of all amts which you left with him for collection I suppose he is too busy to look after them this Fall.
