I suppose it to be perfectly useless to write to any of your Creditors, perhaps by following them up close something might be collected but think it doubtful, if there is nothing, any sooner perhaps next winter I can look after some of them. If Charles' creditor of Leaven does not want his money at present perhaps I should like to keep it  a few weeks and would pay the rate which he pays. Can I keep it if I wish? please.
                                                                                                                                                   S.W.F.

[left-hand side] Mr. Goddard went blackberrying, as I told you, fourteen miles - got 4 qts - cost him $3.50! Horse & carriage & lots of days time. Profitable, wasn't it? Shall I send the cloth and things up by stage or wait for another opportunity - will ask Mrs. Lee to take that for the S. Circle if she comes here, but suppose she would not want to carry all.
[top] enough to get some things. Just saw Eliab last night - hardly spoke to him. Well, I must write to Isaac tonight so I'll leave you all for the present, good night. I have forgotten whether Almeda wished her bag filled with coarse meal to send or not.

Mond. eve Sept. 16
                                       Got my washing all done, floors washed, bedroom and all, hasses and finepane rubbed, etc. toilet made and myself set down to rest before noon - been sewing this afternoon, and evening finished previously begun letters to Ann and Olive. Samuel is dilligently perusing the Tribune, & Jane gone to bed. Eliab handed me letters yesterday which somebody brought when the store was shut - he could not find out about purchases of cloth from those I received when at Milo. You have probably before now got my letter telling what I did buy. I understood Charles cloth for two prs of shirts. Can get more .4 if you wish. I will see Eliab & get a "great many funds" as Mr. Hardy says, and get the thing you mention to send when these go. Albina will find collar cut out, and shirt yoke pattern somewhere in the bundle. Almeda's bag also I will put in. My pickles are nice. They please me much. I put them in sharp cold vinegar. did nothing more to them, and in 4 days they were real good pickles, all made - green, hard & crispy as you please - so much better than those miserable Boston things. Musical Convention commences tomorrow continues  4 days - mean to go some if Samuel can leave. Prof. I.B. Woodbury from N.Y. is head. What a piece of work they have in N.Y. with Jenny Lind. I should love to hear her, but would not pay $125. for it I think. Richard Johnston preached yesterday P.M. How clever and sad he looks, and how exactly like all the rest of them. Ann Thurston has got home

I am tired and sleepy. 'Tis 'bout nine o'clock. I'll go to bed - so good night, dear ones all - good night.
Tues. morn. I'll do up the bundle and send to Eliab today to wait for a chance to go. Samuel will get the other things and put in, and I will not go up today. Please give the 'Kerchief to Persis, and do please to write to me oftener. Love to all - good bye. Lucy.
If you are going to color yellow, this face, Mother, will you color this flannel, but don't do it on purpose on any account, as I don't care a fig. In haste. Margaret Crosby and Augusta Mann called last week - were most pleased with Mr. Temple of any of the students at Commencement, and knew nothing about him previously. How shall I keep Charles Harlow off?
[upside down] Lucy Sept. 16 1850

Sept. 30. 1850.

Dear Folks

                        Spose 'tis time for me to begin a letter to you, as I received one from you Sat. night. Our husband went to Bangor and got it and Eliab. While he was gone John came, so we had company you see. I took them all there into the larder, - had just been baking you know, beside having a dish of blanc mange, of which they are all extravagantly fond - I guess they had a good time! First frost last night, covered up our squashes & tomatoes. Samuel gone to Belfast by boat today - back in stage this afternoon to see that considerate Capt. Jellison, who has "given up the ship," sent it to Bangor, & not paid over anything. Samuel & Thurston think he'll prove a rogue, but S. will write you about it after he come home. I got my washing all out on the line before tea today. Why, I wonder did not Mrs. Lee stop here? Tell her I don't mean to go see her anymore, if she will go right by me without stopping. Perhaps she don't want me to. Samuel & I attended Musical Convention Concerts two evenings - he could not leave in the day time. One eve paid.50 - the other, John being a member of the Association, got us free tickets - real good -sung one piece forty seven pages long, in the Dulcimer. "Oratorio of Absolom." I'll send a Programme if I can. Dulcimer is a new book - some of I.N. Metcalf's tunes

in it. Two fine female singers from Hartford - soprano and alto, and Prof. I.B. Woodbury from N. York. Writes poetry, and music to match!

  When we went to get 4 cent cloth for Mother - the Coat order - They asked 4 1/2 - Everybody but Sticking asked five. I thought it could not be got so long. Had to pay 4 1/2 for mine. Much obliged for your suggestions about C.H., but I shall have no need to profit by them at present. The poor fellow is in Augusta Insane Hospital - his father went with him last week. Poor fellow. I pity him - am glad he is gone there - he may be cured.
   Thurs. Oct. 3. Samuel is going to Bangor -guess I'll finish and send this. Dea. Romulus Haskins with his lady and oldest daughter called Monday P.M. Apologized much for not calling before - have intended to call ever since I was married! I guess after all my smartings to wash Monday, I got a shocking cold! I guess too, that our vegetable marrow squashes are superb. I'll save you some seed - had some for dinner yesterday. Have gathered some Penny royal for you too - believe it does not grow there. I went to Belfast Monday - saw Jellison - got no money  - said he had money but will pay when he can. Samuel is doubtful - sold  the Brandywine to one Capt. Small of Deer Island, for $1000. to go fishing. Pays 1/2 next January & 1/2 a year from then. Meanwhile the vessel remains in their hands. If he does not make the first payment according to agreement, they will take it back. I suppose Samuel would tell you all about it much better than

I can, but I want to send this tomorrow, and fear he will not have time. Am glad Charles has paid his notes. I would not borrow again - pretty advice for me to give too, when Samuel is even now doing the same thing! We look a very little for Anna next week. Am afraid I shall not be able to keep her here long, but Mother, I do think if you and she and Almeda are all there together, you might and ought one or some of you to stay with me part of the winter. Just because I am married and can't live at home, that I cannot have the privilege of seeing any of you -Jose, you send 'em along, won't you, that's a good brother. Spent an evening at Mr. Crosby's last week. Men gone to Cattle Show, and Margaret to Boston. Mrs. Crosby about alone. Mr. Temple has not been to apologize or to give him the stockings only in ? the meeting house at a Concert. I think Eliab might to make a business of it, and go see him. Cowper, Indelible Ink etc. shall be attended to by first opportunity. John made me a bottle of Ink 'tother day. 

  What beautiful weather - warm as summer almost A fine rain last night - cleared off very warm - Allura Dove has a daughter a few weeks old. Lucy has not yet written to me. How do I write with nothing to say. In much haste as usual - good bye
                                                                                                                                    Sis Lucy.

[Postmark] BANGOR ME OCT 4
Mr. J.M. Metcalf                                              5

         Milo

[upside down] Lucy                    Hampden

                       Sept. 30
                      Oct. 4. 1850

Lucy & Samuel                   Hampden
Oct. 18 1850

                                                                                                                                      Oct. 18. I believe - 1850

Folks

                             O, dear, I am so tired of expecting & waiting for Nanni to come. Thought besure she would come yesterday. no boat today - she must come tomorrow. I suppose you in particular, Mother, will ridicule me greatly, if not burn me in clergy or effigy or something else, when I tell you "I been sick" and bint got well yet! I suppose I took cold last Monday, but am sure I don't know how or when. Felt rather foolish after washing & all the evening - and Tuesday morning got up with headache, pain in back and limbs, & for that matter all over, jumping pulse, and dysentery to boot - groaned all night with pain in back and limbs like aching fingers where my cold - been lolling on the sofa about half dressed ever since - slept tolerably last night though I feel better today. Is there such a Thing as inflamation of the Diaphragm?  I have had much severe pain & sounds right across the pit of my stomach - hurt me to cough terribly and to move "every which way." Samuel has made bread two or three times - capital too - and Jane done all the rest of the week, like a woman - every thing in the world she could do for me. & took care nicely. She is a jewell - has earned cents enough rising at 5 in the morning to get some cunning little presents for Lucy & James, little german silver thimble for Lissie, A.B.C. card for Charlie, besides a shawl pin for Albina, which will be forwarded when Ann goes. If you read serpent for superb this time you must remember that I write in my Cap, head aching. I don't know

but I have a sort of slow fever. Felt better forenoon & worse afternoons. Dysentery gone, but head & back ache & sort of sprawlless. You need not expect me to send Ann right up there. I shall keep her here a spell at any rate. It is lonesome here all day with no lady to speak to, She may go up to make a short visit! and then she or you come & live with me a spell. I think you orto - Josie, you will spare one of them part of the time won't you? Your good letter of the P- was duly rec'd. Should have answered it by today's mail if had felt well enough. Hope to let you know by Mond. that Ann has come. Lis Doe walked down here last week Wednes. after school with woolen sack, shawl, rubber boots, & without any dinner? Is not well at all - wanted to get warm she said. Had had her hair all shorn off -- wears false hair in front, & a pretty blue velvet cap on the back of her head. I went to a barber & had mine thin - glad too a 3 weeks since. It was thin 2 day & uneven - like it much now - most wish I had had it shaved. Lissie's cap looks so pretty! Mr. James Crosby died suddenly in Portland a few days since. You know he had had a heart disease a good while. His brother Timothy has been very sick a long time with Dysentery. Has to be fed with a spoon - so low they do not tell him of his brother's death. Have I heard from Hannah Moore? It has been raining for two sabbaths & I have not been to meeting. Have spoken with Mrs. Jewett but once I believe since I came from Milo -she was there writing to Hannah's & would send love. Albina's things shall be got & sent by Ann or first opportunity. I sent yesterday by William Holman, Samuel's map by mistake, instead of Joseph's & S. scoffs greatly because you turn your letters upside down so much & write in so many different places. There has nobody at all been in

have since I have been sick - don't know but it would be one of the impossible to hire a girl if I was ever so needy - however I consider Jane as good an any common one - seems as if she could hardly be the same child we had here last summer. Is Joseph able to give lessons? I very much fear he ought not. Do take care of him, if he won't himself. Rickers - I have expended a great deal of sympathy on her at least, and expect to much more. I had heard nothing of Mr. Wilson - did not know he was at Milo before now. E. saw Mr. Temple recently & gave him socks, but said he knew not what to say by way of apology & therefore said nothing - he has owt been down here. Samuel is much confined in the mill, you know - we see not many people & hear not much news. What three wonderful things Congress made out to do at last two good - on execrable, vile. Flogging Navy, slave trade in Dis. Col. and Fugitive slave. Great time in  Bangor last week - slave catcher after one of the waiters 'board the Gov. Martin crew off to Can. might just as well have staid. What will you do without Aunt & Uncle Henry? Why I shall hardly know how to go to Milo? Father Furber's folks think of leaving Milo in Feb. & taking up their abode with us 'till they start. John has made me some nice indelible ink. I'll send you a little by Ann. I formed a pretty specimen of Aster - don't know whether the same grows at Milo or not - will send it for Josie's inspection - also by Ann some pretty flower seeds. Star of Bethlehem, I believe - from Mrs. Thaxter's garden. Almeda's heifer - pity, pity, must she lose it entirely? Samuel will write you about his last trade with Thurston- Brandwine, Fletcher, accounts etc.  Well doubtless it is most night. Samuel wrote on 'tother page at noon, so I shall have to stop short. Painful back, head & Diaphragm yet - have sent a letter today - looked at my work most every day. Mrs. Crosby and Marny called here on their way home from James Crosby's funeral. What did

I suppose Joseph will wish to know about the Good Sch'r Brandywine. Well, S.W.F. and myself bargained her to Thos. Small of Deer Island for $1130. including three new sails. Re'cd inpyt 13 Bbles pickled herring $3.50 per bbl.  he gave notes 1/2 Jan. next and 1/2 in one year from then. he represented himself as having to the am't of $2000, and what we otherwise learnt of him was favorable. Last Sat. I sold to S.D. the Fletcher action $248, a note as G.W. Wingate of $69, and my own note for $65. for the Small notes $555. and owe a/c as Capt. Jellison of an $85. Think, I had rather have the Brandywine affair than the Fletcher, in dollars and cents we put one equal to the other, had a letter from father today Wm. Owen offers $200 for the Point farm in thick boots at Wholesale prices, think I will sell it. Saw Mr. Goss to day he inquired particularly for you Says he is doing quite well,  would like to sell my boots if I trade with Owen 
The new Hall is fast proceeding to an end, will be quite a respectable house. I think, Capt. Kendall as good a man as can be got for the Senator she has made two trips since Sep 10th paid $166,
[left-hand side] Margaret go to Boston  for ? "Why to see her friends in Billnicky to be sure. Did I spell it right? Letter from Poe today - glad to hear of Parson Wilson's arrival. [in pencil] Billeried

Tuesday Eve Oct 22' 1850

Dear Mother

            Dr. McRuen has been to see Lucy this afternoon and seems think very particular care must be taken of her for the present. he has ordered her to her room which she must not leave at all. now a hired girle to take care of her would aggravate instead of healing and it seems to us that either you or Almeida must to arrange at home as to come here by Stage Thursday, perhaps we are asking too much but I feel that it is of much importance that there be some one to take very special care of her. We are expecting Ann every Boat and she can be forwarded to Milo as soon as in a fit condition to go. Please to take in your knapsack, some peices of old white flannel as I can find none but red Excuse the lack of length to this epistle as I am much hurried to night                                                                    S.W.F.

The disease seems to be a severe Koff with great soreness of the whole person and I gather from what Dr. Mc said that he was afraid of the Lung fever. Lucy send Love to all (and Josie) if it isn't a Tayloriam

Samuel W.F. Hampden

Oct 22. 1850



                                     Mrs. A.M. Metcalf
                                                   Milo

Dear Mother

                   Here I am sitting up in my pillowed & blanketed chair yet. I hardly know whether to tell you I have been getting better or worse the past week. I think perhaps I have taken a little cold some way. Samuel is going to see the Dr. Mc tonight. My ravenous appetite has taken wings, and I "hant got nothing to eat." Sometimes I think I shall be a weak sister & go into consumption & then I think I shant, which last conclusion is probably the most reasonable. I am not low spirited and I don't think I'm spleeny. I guess I shall go to see Mother as soon as I get well enough. Almeda is just as good as the squash pies & custard & all the good things she makes. I am so weak is the principal trouble- bating? 

my cough. 

         Lucy wishes you to send Fitch's book by Ann - you see she is too weak to write I think she is not quite as well as when Ann went when the Dr. was here he thought the air would do her good but she has not yet been out. The air has come in too much through the paper over head when the wind blew hard and so she has taken a cold but she has been careful and I hope she will get over it but she coughs a some and we are going to see the Dr.

have Isaac come down with A and stay at the R.R. meeting and I will stay till he goes back a day or two after A comes Samuel is waiting looks like for storm so must send to night
[upside down]   Hampden Nov. 25. 1850

Hampden Dec. 3.rd 1850

To the dear ones at home - 

                                    On this bright & beautiful morning sitting here in my chair, I am permitted to write a little in short - Mr. Micawber, ahem. Well, I will being about I as usual. I am getting along nicely now - gaining strength daily, only I cannot walk. Samuel has carried me out to my meals three days - went out to breakfast this morning - also he carried me out on the piazza Sat. and yesterday, and held me there about five minutes each time - all I have been out of doors yet  - no more Irritable weather. I was poked? into the sitting room yesterday while Ann opened the window & gave my room & bed an airing. Yesterday I knitted almost an inch - first time I have had any work at all - feel enough better today to pay for it - expect to get well surprisingly now! Jane was quite unwell a day or two after Almeda went home - took some oil & is very well now - made it hard for Ann to have us both to wait upon some, and the work to do besides. Her back is weak & troubles her, but I think if Jane is well, she will get along easier in future. Jane has been so turned about for a few weeks, that she is hardly herself, but will come round again soon I think. Almeda did not seem well at all for two or three days before she went home. I am afraid she worked too hard & got too tired here. I suppose I must not write any more now. Be kissed & loved, all of you, for me. Do write to us - good bye - Lucy.

Much obliged to Almeda for being so thoughtful & prompt about the liniment - think it does me good.
Lucy  Dec. 3 1850

Hampden
Dec. 8  1850

                                                                                                           Sabbath day Dec. 8th

Dear Mother and folks

                                             Received yours by Isaac and will give suitable heed to all the infurmations  there in contained. Eliab brought Isaac down Friday eve, with his own i.e. Brown's horse. We had a nice time. had breakfast early enough next morn, to allow us half an hour's time after prayers before the stage came at 1 1/2. E. had to return in the eve because Wm. Brown could not stay alone with a boy 16. two Irish women and Mary.
                Lucy sits up neatly half the day , goes out to meals, knits, is comfortable and smart, except her weak back, she cannot walk across the room, - Samuel is ready to take her to Milo; - he may be obliged to go into the woods in a week, - will probably go, and come out once or twice before L. will be able to endure the ride; and by the way, she cannot be comfortable at Milo a single day, until you have a good and comfortable lounge, with sacking bottom or cords: Without doubt

- she will find it necessary to avoid walking much all winter. If you will measure and send in your next for the number of yards required E. could get it and send soon: Lucy and U both are of the opinion that a poor material of black would be dearest in the end, and unless you go to the expense to get damask or hair cloth, - which to bin up, yourself at home would but make a mock of it, - we think that a stout, stuff, dark patch at 12 1/2 per yard, would be the properest as well as prettiest; it might be tacked together, so as to be easily washed when necessary, which need not be for two years. If you decide upon this latter course, I will get it if desired. I am intending to go the city once I hope not more. I get along pretty well, there is some little sewing to be done for Samuel, some I want to do for myself: We eat pig, am going to, - chickens - We would gladly migrate the week after thanksgiving, if Lucy is able. Mrs. Finnigan is going to clean the pigs feet tomorrow. if she knows how - if not I shall have to, - and she is coming some day soon to

kill the chickens. It is not my practice or principle to write letters Sunday, but I want to have it ready to go, because there is a chance to send to Bangor, for tomorrow's mail. The only news I have to relate, is that John had given up his school, it was a large and knowing school, 70 scholars. he could not manage them - had no authority, - came here last night - at the close of first  week; feeling bad but not more so than his father will, I dare say. I wondered that they did not feel more misgiving about his first sally - almost expected he would fail. Samuel feels bad, has written to Isaac to take him into his employ if he can do so, which I hope he will, for John's sake, for he need the discipline knowledge and experience that business would give him, but if Isaac has not already engaged his part, I fear he will not want him however Samuel has written to day to his father to send his clothes Tues. so as to be ready to start with Alfred if S. writes for him.

                    Jane has got well is pretty smart.
                             Ann

I am going to finish my new De Laine dress today cut it myself - going to Bangor tomorrow.

        Mrs. Mc Cullis came down last night to desire Samuel to go immediately into the woods, one trip, which he cannot do for some days, and wants very much to fix us off to Milo first - so I shall make all the haste possible to get able to go. Hope to go next week - after Thanksgiving, Friday or Saturday, but I don't know. my back is very weak, but the rest of me gets strong daily. Samuel may be obliged to go once before that, even - Mill shut down last Saturday. Mrs. Finnigan coming to kill biddies today I expect - scrabble to eat them up before we go. If I can't go to Milo in one day, can take tow for it can't I?
      We think that some stout dark patch will be preperable for the lounge, as it will last a good long time, be much more easily put on, & not look so "try to do something," besides being cheaper. I think that barrels make the prettiest & easiest ends for a lounge. Charles Smith has one made so I understand - resemble our round end sofa - Ann says please not color the stockings till we come with some more. I have not rode out yet - no suitable weather & going. S. has carried me out on the piassa twice, tugs me out to have breakfast, dinner & supper - well he is stout. I frequently get up before light - six this morning. We are through "Copperfield" O, Ma! you'll read it I know. good bye- Lute

[left-hand side] I knit more or less every day -generally less.

Hampden
                                                                                                            1850

Dear Mother

                               Half sitting up and half lying abed I'll write a little. I've been nearer sick abed than anything else for about a fortnight. Last few days that Mrs. Stevenson was here, she did the work and took care of me too! How I did wish she wasn't here, but she was pretty clever. Since she went away Samuel & Jane have managed grandly, on;y Jane is yet a child you know - thoughtless, forgetful etc. School begins today - intend to have her go. 
                               The things you wanted, I intended to have got to send by Eliab certainly, but from day to day have striven and could not get able to go to Bangor. Eliab was down here to dinner yesterday, & he & Samuel concluded that you had better come down, but the more I think of it the more I think we can get along, and you ought not to leave Joseph. It will be a hard jaunt for you over the bad roads, and I shall get along. I felt better yesterday and today. Mrs. Finnigan is here washing. Skunk devoured thirteen eggs that had been set on a fortnight. Whose butter was sent, yours or Almeda's? Mooly gives good milk for which I'm glad. I don't love milk after it has been measured out & poured round into half a dozen dishes, perhaps all of 'em clean! I seem to have lost all my strength - if I walk from the bedroom out into the kitchen & back again, my legs tremble under me & my stomach feels as if there was nothing but all-gone mess? left in it. In short as Mr. Micawber would say (you know I'm sure) I am quite

indisposed. Samuel has got some medicine from Dr. Paine twice. S. means to get the Dr. himself soon I believe, but I won't let him. I don't like doctors. Mary Crosby is going to teach school. Pa is quite crazy by spells with the hypo. I want [desperately?]] you should see my rug - have half a mind to send it up by Libe. guess I'll send home your rags again, as they'll be of no particular use to me now. With them and what I had left you might make a beautiful rug. I wish you would - tis not a great job, after you get about it. borrow Mehitable's hook. I thought I should make another this spring, but shall not now, as Jane's clothes & Samuel's need my time soon as I am well enough. I made Jane a house linen sack last week, lying abed, trimmed with white braid- looks quite near & her "go to meeting" fix for this summer. I have a darling Cactus in bloom - one large flower, six inches across - been open since Thursday - begins to shut up now. We've got a little garden down on the terraces. Some posies, beans, peas, radishes, lettuce, pepper grass, tomatoes (only they would come up) Nasturtiums, cucumbers, squashes etc. Samuel has no employment, either present or prospective, but to dig in the garden & take care of me. They have a great muss at the mill & boarding house needed? them - men want him to come back - Hathorne does too, but won't pay much. I tell him 'tis a good thing that he is out of business now, but he feels rather uneasy sometimes. I think he & Isaac had better lay their heads together and set up something. I want to see Joseph or have you write more particularly.

[particularly] about him, whether he is going backwards or forwards or both. In Panic thought from his last letter that he might be better. If I had been well enough to do anything - I am sure I don't know what I should have done about getting a earful after receiving your last letter.h

              What a sight of beggars we d have here. 'Tother night a woman, very much agitated came, said they lived right in the neighborhood, told where, about half a mile above here - moved there lately, sick husband etc. Any thing would be acceptable. Samuel said he might as well give her money as food, especially as he had to cook it himself. so her gave her, 25 intending to inquire next day & if they needed, help them - but behold, on inquiry no such woman or family were to be found or heard of.
                I think E's dag? is first rate. Whiskers improve him -- detract sommat from the length of visage. Libe will tell you how I hurried to clean house, change carpets etc. for Mrs. Stevenson to come, when I had a bad cold & was not well. I guess I won't write any more - do write to me. Soon as I get well, I will get your shawl etc. Black Shirret? I believe you concluded.

Bangor May 14, 1851

                                                                                                                        Bangor May 14 - 1851

Dear Mother

                             The folks have all gone - went in the six o'clock boat this morning. Samuel also went to Old Town in the six o'clock train. You may imagine that it seems pretty still and lonesome here. I hardly know what to do with myself. I don't know how Frances is going to get along. She knows nothing about doing up linen - never did any - never coked any meal with stuffing in it, or eat any so cooked - says she can cook common food if I tell her about it. She seems very pleasant, willing to learn and wants I should tell her how I want things done, and if she does not do them right etc. It will be more care for me, than to have a more capable and experienced girl, but perhaps we shall get along well enough. Dr. Mc Ruen called all of his own accord, when he found we had moved here - was very particular in his inquiries - says he thinks I am mistaken as to the nature of my complaint - he may be mistaken he says, but he thinks it is a spinal difficulty. left me a different preparation of iron with quinine, wine etc. recommends cold bathing, to be out doors as much as possible, and especially recommended sea bathing and sea air when it comes warm weather. I don't know

what to think. he thinks I shall get well, but it will take some time. I feel in a hurry for you to get the sheep sheared, your wool picked, and all necessary matters attended to, so as to come and comfort us. Do not worry now, and think I need you greatly, only when you are ready, come. When is Isaac coming? Samuel has selected the apple trees. O, he wrote about it. I forgot - we shall send them and the other things by stage, if there is no other opportunity, before long. I got patterns and washed the gingham both peices - do not exactly like the blue, but all the other patterns faded. I think she will like the other very stout and durable certainly - only, 12 1/2 per yd. blue the same. wire cord eight cent a stick. Coronation cord, one stick six cents; please return the other form. 13 1/2 yds of the gingham - just what there was in the peice. Thread I have forgotten, will ask Samuel. I send pattern of sun bonnet - just like Jane's I think. If not right, you can alter it. Pantalettes, peices of dress etc., like Jane's old dresses, for Almerda.

                             Lissie Doe decided to go and see Ann, and go the rest of her journey alone. I sent the skirt - she purchased an elegant dress for her $1.50 per yard - mantilla of the same lace trimming, wide $1.00 per yard. I believe I have a bit of the silk which I will put in.
                              Samuel has hired a steam mill in Brewer opposite the City for $1200.00 a year- takes possession tomorrow - Jack Palmer and Ben Johnson furnish the

logs - he will write about the trade - perhaps I should not tell it right. I am sorry for one thing - he will not be able to come home to dinner usually - had hired an engineer & one mill man. I don't know how many men he has - gets them boarded for $2.25 per week. he may do well, and may fail out. Old Senator is in good plight and doing nicely. Samuel concluded it was useless to wait for a surveyor's appointment.

      Please by the first opport my black lace veil which was left. A man is waiting to take the bundle & apple trees so I must finish in great haste. I have rode out twice. Prof. Shepard & wife called just as I was eating my dinner. The poor bashful man was so confused when I wheeled my self into his presence that he advanced & retreated two or three times before he ventured to shake hands. A darling good man. Mr. & Mrs. Crawley were here to dine one day. I told Dr. Mc. about my lameness, which inclined him still more to the opinion that mine is a spinal disease. He had a similar case once when for months the part was exceedingly painful & some while it looked just as well as ever. Mine continues to trouble me slightly by spells - today it burns & almost smarts, and I notice the skin is all peeling off over the whole part. Sam'l has subscribed for the Independent. I have read Hist. of Josephine and we are reading "Great Cities by Todd author of Students Manual." Very good indeed. I want to hear from Jane very much - tell her I want to know if she is a very good girl.

1/2 pound linen thread - the same of cotton - linen 5 shillings per pound - the cotton 4/



                                           Folks at home

Bangor
                                     May, 27 1851
                                                                                                                                          Bangor May 27 - 1851.

My dear Mother

                                    Isaac arrived here rather unexpectedly last Saturday - we were looking for him and James with the cows Monday. The man is very particular - won't have cows in his pasture until June, and must be taken out every night - which makes it rather inconvenient for us, as the pastures joins our yard and we have no room in the yard to make a yard. There are some twenty cows roaming up and down street, lowering and apparently half starved, all the time - ours might have turned out with them for a few days, though I suppose it is better not. We shall expect to see Jamie or somebody else down with the Vine the last of this week. Samuel thinks he shall get a little pig, and put all the milk and cream which we cannot use, together with a sufficient quantity of meal, into the same, as with our change for making butter, and an inexperienced housemaid, it would be of little use to try to make butter. Our neighbors, many of them have cows, so there is little chance to sell milk. Isaac went from here in the Waterville stage at 4 o'clock this evening bought him a very pretty hat and vest yesterday. He read most all the time he was here, though he pretended he told

me every thing there was to tell about Milo folks. Why didn't you write particularly about Olive Sargent. I was so much surprised. Frances does better than I feared - but does not know everything. I have to watch and know how every thing goes - she is so good natured and wants to do so well, that I cannot but like her - probably on the whole, I could not expect to do better - we cannot expect to get all good things no one person. Prof. Shepard gave out his subject for sabbath before last "The one patch upon the old coat." told about putting on patches in a great many ways, and on a great many things. Said when the patch cleaves off, as it will be very apt to do, remember it is a patch of your own putting n, and beware not to call it falling from grace etc. Have you been to Brownville yet? I forgot to ask Isaac. If not, do go immediately, before Mrs. Lee she goes away. Samuel carried his coat to to the clothes cleanser's, and it came back looking as nice as a new coat almost, only the sticking plaster was not off, which was the principal trouble you know. I sent for a bottle of "Oil Soap", with which I wetted the spot, & then with a sponge & warm soft water washed it off, & behold every bit of the spot was gone. I then applied it in like manner to the big oil spot on my bedroom carpet, with a like good effect - took it every bit out - looks just as well as any part of it, and all no more than five minutes work. It is a valuable article for cleaning coat collars & ll sorts of bad spots in cotton, linen & woolen goods. 
[left-hand side] Do get the folks to write once in a while.

Wonder we never knew of it before. Ma Furber told me. Had a letter from them at Buffalo. They all went to Niagara falls. Lissie left them the day they wrote to go see Ann. Margaret Crosby walked up here last Saturday morning to see me, and back at night. The same dear girl as ever. I expect to ride down there soon as I get my new gown. I have bought a small plaid, very dark mourning gingham, fast colors, for /9 per yd. and a black all wool de laine for .50 - expect a dressmaker tomorrow to cut them. Shall have them made open before, large and loose. You have not written a word how Almeda was suited  with the girls' dresses etc. I thought she would like them. I have had my bonnet colored black, and simply a black watered silk cape behind - no other trimming. I have rode out three times, besides once in the big chaise! I wish you could see our great big Cactus posy. Isaac says, Mother, you want him to write to you when to come down here. I will save him the trouble, and tell you not at all, if it will be really very irksome and troublesome - but if not, we should be "very happy to see you" as soon as you get ready. I get along very comfortably, but I do want somebody for company besides Frances very often-  we have breakfast at six. Samuel goes right away, & does not usually come home before seven - it makes long days. My little Daisy is blooming beautifully. Samuel has got some little white marble grave tones, with "Anne" put on them.

                                                                                                                   good bye Affectionately Lucy

[left-hand side] The letter I wrote about from Concord N.H. was from Mary Towers. I only wanted to cheat Issac. If I have it written in a hurry! Don't know as you can possibly send it.

[post mark] BANGOR ME 28 MAY


                                      Mrs. Anna M. Metcalf
                                                             Milo
                                                               Maine

Bangor June 6, 1851

                                                                                                                   Bangor June 6 - 1851.

Dear Mother

                                            I'll begin a letter today to send by James when he goes home. I have just finished one to Isaac, and dispatched James to the P.O. with it. I received one from him yesterday dated at N.Y. City and mailed at Albany. He finds no prospect of employment on the Hartford & Fishkill R.R. and is going on farther - thought it probable he might be in Westfield this week and wished us to write to him there. You have probably had letters from him before now. He has purchased grave stones in Boston.
                                             I rode down to Hampden yesterday to visit at Mr. Crosby's. The same good people as ever - get some tried, but feel quite rested now. James seems to enjoy life finely here. We had a great fire Wednes. which of course was quite an exciting time for him. The largest fire there has been for some years = six dwelling houses Eastes' & Whittese's store foundry besides several shops, and with great difficulty saved the Universalist Meeting house. The lower side is black from top to bottom. Cleared all out on the lower part of Baptist hill and Exchange street. Very high wind so that roofs of houses caught fire many times way up State St. most half a mile. broke out again in the night and burnt a brick stable belonging to, and joining the Hammet house,

in one tenement of which Mrs. Griffin, sister to Mrs Dr. Shepherd of Sebec, abides. It looks desolate enough down there. I am very glad you are coming so soon Mother. I am lonesome, however, I would certainly wait until after the Conference. I am glad you did at last go to Brownville. I had my de laine dress (all wool) made large in every part & capable of being made still larger in hopes Almeda will want to buy it one of these days - it seemed necessary for me to have one, but as my thiber? is so dark, I shall not need a black one to wear till it is worn out. I send Joseph & "Charles Twelvth" for Almeda, also peices to help make pants. I think, Mother, that you had better decide to get a handsome black dress when you come down - acapine or something really nice, I have even particularly engaged a dress maker to cut it!

                                      With the help of Eliab and Samuel, I have purchased a small, very plain, mourning pin in which to keep some of Joseph's hair - am going to have it marked with his name on the back. Eliab has had two likenesses taken from the original, one of Isaac took, the other Eliab and I want to keep here, and the original is to be sent to you again. Uncle Joseph's could not be taken. One letter re'c from Buffalo and another from St. Charles, Ill.  All prospering finely - enjoying the journey much. You don't know how odd it seems to get on tight dresses again. I like it though. I think I can walk a little better.

The greatest trouble I have with Frances is that she is like Lucretia Haskell, only more so. There are some things which it is not easy, not hardly possible to tell any one, if they have not discrimination & sense of propriety enough to find it out for Themselves, perhaps could hardly understand if told. I have wished for Almeda's faculty, or Almeda herself, many times, to hint things into her! On the whole she is very desirable help - we cannot expect everything right.

                     There are two Vols. of the N.E. Farmer here, which Isaac has got bound. They look very nice & I hardly dare to send them lest some accident should happen to them, presume Charles is in no hurry for them. Success to Charlie with his "Meters," say I.  Another great fire night before last - supposed to be by an incendiary - five or six old stores at the corner of Exchange & State Streets - tow or three rum holes, which I am glad. We don't know whether to send James home afoot or put him aboard the stage.
                      Sarah Harlow calling the other day, I mentioned incidentally, that Isaac had been here recently whereat she immediately took it upon herself to blush crimson red. I don't know whether to send your trunk by James or not. I don't know of anything more to write - good bye - Affectionately
                                                                                                                                                                                    Lucy.

Mrs. Anna M. Metcalf
                                                                              Milo
                                                                                    Maine

Bangor
June 12 1851
Bangor June 12, 1851.
Dear Mamma
It is a lovely morning - the warmest, I think, we have had this summer - can you believe it - I have not had a fire this morning, and have only been to the kitchen stove once to warm my feet. I have been sitting in the front door with my knitting work, in the warm sun, an hour, and now having read in "Prescott's Conquest of Mexico" till my eyes ache, I will while away a little time writing to you, Though I don't know as I have anything particularly worth writing.
While I sat in the door, one Mr. Kellogg, a student, whom we met at Mr. Crosby's, passed by on the other side the street. He looked at me, and I at him, two or three times, till I could hardly keep from laughing. He dared not bow to me till I did to him and I felt so foolish sitting there sunning myself in such a conspicuous situation, that I could do nothing but look foolish too. He promised to come up here and sing? some day - I shall have to laugh about it when he does!
I am desirous to know how James fared and how he got home. I was really afraid he would suffer with the cold. Mr. Hathorne has bought the cow for thirty dollars. Samuel has bought a pig

six weeks old for $3.50, Our Mooly gives a pretty good mess of very good milk. I suppose James has told you about Mr. Carr, in whose pasture she lives by day. Frances milks usually.

                        Eliab has really decided to leave Mr. Brown's as soon as Frank gets home. which will probably be in a week or two. I have not seen him since he had a talk with Mr. Brown, and do not know whether he intends to engage himself somewhere else at present, or not. I should think he had better take a time to rest now for a few weeks at least. I mean to try to get him to go up after you, it will be so much easier and pleasanter than to come by stage. At any rate, whether he goes or not. I shall expect you just as soon as you have been to County Conference, and got your wool attended to!
                       Two young ladies in our neighborhood "appeared out" in the new and fashionable costume, night before last - short dresses (to the knees) and turkish pants. They did look very pretty. Samuel said so, and you know he is not usually fond of innovations. He says I may wear them! Don't you think you will conform when you get down here? I do hope the fashion will prevail universally. A very respectable young gentleman took one lady on each arm and promenaded with them.
                        My daisy is all in bloom - beautifully. I smoke it with tobacco to destroy the bugs. The good

people across the way told me of that remedy. I am quite sociably acquainted with them. I wish you would bring Charlie down with you when you come. What a deal of comfort I could get out of him!
I wish you would bring two or three dozen good fresh eggs when you come if you have them and can conveniently. We don't get fresh ones. I have got both my dresses made, like them well. We have not got a bit of a garden made yet, and I hardly think we shall do any thing about it - Samuel is so busy all the time. He has considerable surveying to do, and the Mill to attend to - now they run by night, it is a good deal of care. When he has any thing to do, he "tends right to it," too much, I tell him to text obscured the spring all the time. I tell him text obscured.
I want you should pack up, "bag & baggage" every thing you will want for a year, and then if you get uneasy, you can go back any time, you know. But till winter is the least I can let you off with. Why, I want somebody to talk to! James would'nt object to talking - not at all - but I do. Well, I have made out quite a letter, when I did not expect to write a page when I began. Charles and Albina may be laying their plans to come here with both the children about the first of sleighing. Tell Lucy to improve all her time, and learn fast, for much Samuel says she may come & stay here and go to the High School a time or two, as soon as

she will get herself fitted. I will inquire what are the necessary qualifications as soon as I have an opportunity. Good bye all - Affectionately, Lucy.
If I mistake not, this is the season for Pitcher plants, and I earnestly beg that by some means a good specimen be obtained, pressed, & brought to me - do not delay - they'll all be gone,-

[post mark] BANGOR ME JUNE 6                                          5

                                         Mrs. Anna M. Metcalf
                                                 Milo
                                                             Maine

[upside down] If you can conveniently, Mother, I wish you would pay a dollar to Dr. Kimball. You know Samuel could not make change - and his father forgot it. I wish you would bring my old Edinburgh shawl - I have nothing but  "go to meetin" to put over me when I lie down. Tell Almeda I am depending upon her to save me a great lot of her beautiful grass, be sure and dry it standing up, so that is may be drooping. I'll pay her at the rate of $20.00 per ton!

Deer Isle
               Sept. 4, 1851
                                                                                                                         Deer Isle, Sept. 4 - 1851.

Dear Mother & Brother

                                                It is most tea time. I have been waiting for Samuel to bring home some milk, as the good lady Webb had none in the house. We got along nicely - had to wait more than two hours for the Lawrence at Searsport, which did make us feel almost impatient. arrived at Deer Isle about 1/2 past one when we found carriages in waiting to take passengers to the town on N.W. Harbor, as it is called. There are a great many places in the incorporated town of Deer Isle, besides this, as for instance, S.W. Harbor, S.E. Harbor, Burnt Cove, The Landing, the Beach, Little Deer Isle, Isle of Haut etc. etc. This, however, is the principal place in the kindom. The whole town contains about 4000 inhabitants. We conclude on the whole it is a tolerable decent kind of a place - better than we expected. We have really a nice boarding place. The most neat and quiet little place that you can imagine, overlooking this "N.W. Harbor." The whole family consists of one very small and very smart woman called "Widow Webb", one boy rejoicing in the two endearing titles of Bub & Charley, (about eleven years old), one black cat with four white feet and a white nose, and one solitary Canary bird. Withal a very quiet, sober, cosy little family. We occupy the Parlor and adjoining bedroom. We judge from furniture

&c. that the woman has "seen better days." In the parlor are two really elegant but rather old fashioned bureaus with moveable glasses, two handsome card tables with rich covers, and Marseilles outer covers, a nice work table a very nice mahogany side board, a sofa, two stuffed rocking chairs & 1/2 doz. stuffed common chairs, two large handsome pictures framed. The woman is about 50 years old I should judge - her husband has been dead seven years. She seems very kind & good. We were both very tired last night - went to bed at dark and slept about twelve hours! Samuel says he feels weak today but on the whole better than yesterday. my back feels the unusual exertion of yesterday some of unclear, but I really feel as if the salt water will do me good. I bathed in it this morning. It made my skin look as red as a beet all over. The air is cool, but really refreshing. Capt. Small lives at Burnt Cove - about 4 miles from here. Samuel things of going to see him tomorrow. A big nigger on board The Governor, the book I believe, (Samuel thought he would weight two hundred) got very mad or crazy, threatened to kill himself and others, was saucy to the Capt. and withal became so furious that it took five or six men to handle him. They got him down, tied his feet together and his hands behind him, and stowed him away in the firecastle - poor fellow, I pitied him, to lie in that situation all day. The Capt. said he never knew him to have such a spell before Samuel saw him. I did not. There is a mice? near here runnings? now

which has been built 90 years. There are some very ancient looking buildings here. A real old fashioned meeting house - a congregationalist minister settled - has been here 18 or 19 years, his name is Adams. The only preaching they have in this part of the Island. Fresh fish are said to be abundant. Mackerel & some cod. Clams abound. Some say they are good every month that has an R in it, and consequently began to be eatable the first day of Sept. Others say they are at all times good. The boats are so arranged now that we can only get away from this place on Monday, except we go to Belfast, and from there by stage, which you know I can do. We shall probably remain until a week from Monday so we can hardly tell whether we receive benefit or not if we go away next Monday. It seems too bad to come right away to see so little of Eliab too. You must all take good care of yourselves. I get along as well as you can without your Pa and Ma. We shall want you to write to us - do not fail and direct to Deer Isle. That is the name of our Post Office. You had probably better write very soon after receiving this or we may not get it before we go home Friday morn - 9. A.M. Samuel does not feel so well this morning - he dipped himself in the salt water & got chilly before he got back to the house. He seems a little feverish, & did last night. If he is not gaining, we shall come next Monday. If we are ever so sick, we cannot get away before then. However, there is a Dr. here. Samuel has laid down & feels better - don't worry a bit about us. Mrs. Webb is so kind & good as can be. Aff - Lucy.

Deer Isle Me                                                       Paid 3
Sept. 5
[upside down]paid                               Mr. E. W. Metcalf   

                                                                    Bangor
                                                                            Maine

Bangor 
Sept, 18 1851

                                                                                                                           Bangor Sept. 18. 1851.

Dear Brother & Sisters

                                            It is a warm, white, dusty September day. I have got a "bad cold id by head" so I feel, to say the least, uncomfortable, but as Mrs. Loring is going to Milo tomorrow, I will write a bit of a letter. She is shopping all the time - getting all sorts of nice things. She popped in quite unexpectedly last Tuesday. Mother had gone to Mrs. Brown's to dinner, by special invitation, to meet Mrs. Lee. Mr. and Mrs. Lee came home with her and spent the night. I was invited to Mrs. Brown's too, but would'nt go because Samuel was not asked!
  Samuel is getting along nicely now - his appetite is good and he gains strength finely since he has done sweating nights. We only staid at Deer Isle five days. Samuel went to the salt water, got chilly, and brought his fever again so we had to have the doctor four or five times. So we thought best to get home just as soon as he felt able to come. I think the sea air & bathing would have benefited me if we had staid longer & I had not been so tired and anxious about him all the time. Went Wednes. & back the next Mond. Cost us $15.00 Yesterday afternoon we all went to Hampden & Mrs. Crosby's. Eliab boards at Mr. Brown's.

He has now engaged there certainly for another year. The grasses came nicely. very much obliged Almeda. Have you got your bonnet fixed yet & how much did it cost? I want to come to Milo dreadfully. but it costs so much. Samuel has worked very hard this summer & thinks he shall not realise much - so we must be economical. It costs a good deal besides the wages to hire a girl. O, if I could only be well! I have had it in my heart to write letters separately to each of you, but I don't see why you can't all read them all & do just as well. Mother keeps threatening to go home, but I don't see how I can get along without her. I send a pr. of chemise for Jane, don't know how they will fit. Mr. Tibbits is boarding here now finishing his house. I am afraid Samuel will go into the woods again & I suppose he ought to, if he has a good chance. I wish I could be well enough to get along this winter with Jane & not hire a girl. Mother says she shall go down street again one of these days. I will get baby's apron at Charley's waist. Mrs. Stat.? Harlow died last sabbath. She had been sick a long time, but her death was quite sudden at last. His fourth wife. Guess I must lie down now. good bye

                                                                                                                                                                       Lucy.

Bangor Oct. 11 1851

                                                                                                                           Bangor Oct. 11 - 1851.

Dear Mother

                                 I will begin a letter to you because I feel like it, though I have nothing particular to write. Samuel wrote that he had concluded a bargain with Mr/Harlow for the land. I guess he meant Samuel should have the land at any rate, for he came down from $508. to $400. willingly. and when Samuel told him he could'nt give more than four hundred, and should have to look further said "Well Mr. Furber, you may have the land for just what you have a mind to pay me - but did not wish to have anything said about it! He and "Tib" and myself spend our leisure time drafting now-a-days. Mr. Tibbits keeps drawing plans of divers sorts with quirks and crooks in them. He says he wants a job, and Samuel knows the expense of one of these little plain houses too well! Our neighbors, the frogs took a long leap yesterday - way over the river. In other words, Mr. Fogg has moved over the other side, on Lincoln St. Mr. Lincoln has taken the Flour and Onions, and has been paid for the same.The basket etc. said he would take next time. A letter from Charles Herman Metcalf for Eliab. Uncle & Aunt have been to Maine this fall. Why did'nt they come and see us? I wish you would not be fainthearted, but push ahead and make a lounge. We can't

possibly invent a house plan to suit us, and have a fire in the bedroom. We are almost inclined to give it up & try not to be sick in the winter. I hope you wrote to Isaac the very day after you got home - you took the newspaper peice, so I have not written. The Pennington house progresses finely. Sam-u-el was painting the fence yesterday. Frances has cleaned the front chamber. In sweeping the floor, among other rubbish, she found a dollar bill! dropped there, I suppose, by my Mother the morning she went away! The Collection last sabbath was $63.00 Mr. Tibbits has subscribed $5.00. Mrs. Page's teeth distress her terribly yet. Anne Page thinks I am very lonely & acts accordingly. Sarah Harlow's quite well. Uncle Marty's toe limps yet. 
Oct. 12 - Mr. Lincoln has just called & taken the buckets. After he took them, he asked if Mr. Furber was going to pay for hauling down those things and for hauling up the flour and onions. I told him that Mr. Furber left word at Pendleton & Ross' for them to pay the freight when the flour was taken away - he looked real saucy and said, "This is a pretty way of doing business - I guess they won't get the things till they are paid fo," and went off. Perhaps the folks at Pendleton's forgot to pay, and Samuel has not seen him to pay for hauling down the eggs, but at any rate he deserves a good talking to. I owe him a grudge for his impudence when he brought the chair. I hope you will get this letter before you inquire for the things,

so as to know how to treat him & make explanations.

  Oct. 14 Eliab & James arrived last night in the driving rain. Pendleton and Ross forgot to pay Lincoln. Eliab is going to see him today, settle with him, and then train him soundly for sassing me. The chickens are nice. I prepared them wholly myself & they are now cooking for dinner. Eliab said last night that the others stinked. I don't know what he has done with them this morning. That Christopher & his father are very provoking certainly, but I am afraid the lawsuit will cost more than it will come to before Charles is through with it. I recollect distinctly hearing Charles tell him he could not pay anything till winter, and Chase said it was all right, only if the boy wanted some little articles of clothing he should want Charles to get them. I think he mentioned a pr. of boots. The honey is nice. Samuel has taken one pr of gloves. The rest will be attended to in due season. You did not write how Albina liked her things for Charlie. I got up stairs yesterday alone - you see I am quite smart. Frances has almost given out with her wrist. When I told her // for the dress, she said she did not think it would be more than a dollar. I told her it was worth // to me besides the trouble of making, as I should have to get another next spring. I don't know whether she will take it. 

15 - The Mooly is eating meal, and James waiting to see if it will be pleasant today. Eliab saw Mr. Lincoln

yesterday and paid him a Spanish blessing. Told him he did not wish him to call here again, drunk or sober, unless treat his sister respectfully, and when he had any fault to find to go to him. He swore some and cringed some. I wish there was a good faithful sober teamster to send by. You left your hair brush, and a whole breadth of black flannel, which I fear you will need about your rug. I will put the bill in this letter, as you may want it. Am glad your back is better. Hope you will get all your work done quick, so as to come back here. I got up stairs alone yesterday and day before. Eliab has gone to Frankfort today. Samuel is saving up timber for our house - don't know as he will build next summer though.

                Noon - It has cleared off. James is about starting. Good ye - write to me all of you and come back soon Mother. The point of my new dress was so short, I priced it down - does not show a bit. 

[right-hand side] My head aches this forenoon - don't know what ails it- just took a strong cup of tea to cure it. write all. Lute

Bangor Oct. 20 - 1851.

Dear Mother

                              It is evening. Samuel has stopped out to see Mr. Tebbits fix his posts in the wood shed. Eliab has gone to hear Prof. Pond lecture before the Corban Society upon ghosts. Frances is on the old track - "May I have a sheet of paper" - writing to her Mother up stairs. A nice fire is burning, and all things are very comfortable.
                              Samuel has been recording his Mother's death in the large bible, which reminded me that the date of Willie's death is not recorded - will you please write when he died. A letter from Minn. today. Mrs. Crosby and Rufus called. None of Mr. Page's folks in today! Mrs. Brown, the Mother of the young Hampden man who was robbed of his California at Boston, died last week--has not been well since the death of her son. I want to hear how James got home.
                          I have been wearing for two days, a spine supporter which a lady Agent for King's "  " left here for me to try. I like the feeling of it much - it is a perfect support to the back & bowels, with shoulder braces connected. - keeps the spine perfectly erect, and feels beautifully, but according to Dr. Fitch's theory of pressure & warmth upon the spine being injurious, it must 

[left-hand side]E. says he has nothing to write, so I'll send this letter along. I guess you has better conclude to come & live long us this winter. Tell Albina and Almeda we will have some cheese. I don't know how much we can eat.
[top] when you went away, she astonished him by refusing, so has been quite mum on the subject! only he solemnly assured me the other day, that there was nothing in it, & charged me to say nothing more about it, and tell you to do the same!! Eliab has endorsed the above, as you see. [written across this part] E.W. Metcalf

eventually injure the spine. I sent it back tonight thinking it not best to pay ten dollars upon uncertainties. The lady said that she was so much troubled with kidney & spine complaints & prolapsis, that for eight months she had not walked at all. and Physicians told her she could live but a short time. She procured one of the supporters (invented by a lady of N.Y.) and in six weeks she walked a mile to meeting. Samuel said if she would warrant it to have as good an effect upon me, he would pay her $25 and Eliab said he would add another twenty-five.

                                 I am wonderfully smart nowadays - have been up stairs most every day lately - walked round the house to the pig pen, out through the lower gate into the street and up the steps into the house today, with Eliab's help. I am really getting along finely, when I have an opportunity. I may get only this  although? !

22 Yesterday I rode ten or twelve miles - only stopping at Mrs. Crosby's half an hour or so. Back aches some today, but soon over it I dare say. Eliab and I rode down to Hampdens corner. Today, & in the afternoon yesterday, he, like a good boy, has been reading aloud Upham's Mental Philosophy, - and occasionally, by way of amusement, playing backgammon. Mr. Tebbits is very anxious to sell his house & lots to Eliab, so that he can live near us! If I
[left-hand side] If James can come comfortably with her such as it is perhaps it had better not be fixed till she gets here  - I may contrive some new way.

Bangor Oct. 20, 1851
am as well next sabbath as for a few days past, I think of going to meeting. May I? Joseph Hill called here this morning. What a black, rough looking fellow he is - he has more heart than any other of the family I judge. Your pink bloomed the day after you went away, I think, and is a bright & beautiful pink yet.

                      You did'nt write a word about the baby - whether he was pretty, or good, or afraid of you - nor what Charlie said, nor what Almeda was doing with herself & the children, nor when Charls & Albina are coming down, nor forty more things that I want to hear about.  At Hampden Academy there are two tall ports with ropes for a swing, and an old chaise top for a seat - looks queer enough. I put a new elbow in a coat for Eliab one day - looks just as nice - the first time I ever did such a thing. John Furber fell from a waggon the other day, put his elbow out of joint and fractured the bone - better. Father says Alfred likes well. 

23 - Samuel brought me your good letter last night, for which I greatly thank you. Samuel said he gave you a five dollar bill, and then, for your greater convenience, changed it for smaller bills. It was changed on the paper with the three dollars & a half, - you will see, $8.50. I believe it is all right. About rugs, don't trouble yourself one bit about mine. I jave concluded to make a rag carpet! That is, whenever I have any rags of any description except pulled cloth, - white

cotton, calico, delaine, flannel, or what not, I intend to sew them up into balls and lay them away. It is the easiest way to dispose of them, and after a series of years, I may, without feeling the trouble, get enough for a chamber or sitting room carpet. So any thin material of any sort that nobody else wants for rugs or anything else, you may save for one. I don't like pulled cloth in a carpet - it is too hard to sew, and people say it does not wear so well, nor sweep so easy. Cotton rags are not worth much to sell, and I should put in every thing of every description " hit or miss." If it comes right, and I can muster red, black & green  enough for a stripe between my wide stripes of hit or miss, I should like it by way of variety. Lucy's old sac & mine, when we have done wearing then will help along. I am very glad you have fixed her sack. You did not write whether Almeda was going to fix her cloak. What did you trim Lucy's with? What is Lissy going to have? I think you had better send us a firkin of butter, and let me keep the firkin this winter if you have one to spare. We use a good deal of butter now, more than when we have plenty of milk, you know. Weigh out a firkin full of lumps & send by first opportunity. It is cool weather now, so it will keep - tell how much there is, and the price.

                        As for your coming here - I certainly don't wish you to spend the winter here, if you would better enjoy being there. As for my being at Milo, I think it is entirely out of the question. It is not worth while to break up unless there is a necessity for it. If I continue to gain as for a week or two past, I think you & I & Jane can get along very comfortably by hiring, washings, and you know you can bring & do any kind of work here if you wish. I want you should do just as you like. If you think you had rather stay there, try to engage Alice for me. We should all like it so much better not to have any body but our folks. I may be able to do the washing and hard work myself before winter is out! I am so smart. Eliab as not brought Susan nor said any thing about getting board for her. I conclude when he "popped the question," as you know he talked of doing,

Bangor Oct. 26, 1851

                                                                                                                                  Bangor, Oct. 26 - 1851.

Dear Mother

                                     I did intend to go to meeting half the day, but is not pleasant weather, so I stay at home, which by no means a new thing. Mr. Skeele from Hallowell preaches today. Mr. Tebbits found a dollar bill, going to church this morning. We all told him when he found money sabbath day he must give it for the good of the society when he went! Our people are trying to "get up steam" to build a meeting house next year, but they are poor, and cannot without a good deal of help. Samuel says he will give $100.00 towards it. 
                                 I have been reading some very good - excellent pieces in the two East No's of the Independent - 150 & 151 - "The heights of the christian life" from Rev. Ray Palmer's "Closet hours." I must send them to you by the first opportunity. Samuel thinks some of going to Milo in a week or two, to collect money of Owen, - he says, too, he wants to see the old place. I should think he would want to go before snow comes. How I shall want to go with him if he does. I suppose we ought to make our arrangements for winter soon, as Frances says she wants to go home by the middle or last of next month. If you conclude to come down when she goes away, how can I go to Milo and not find you there? How odd it would seem! I want to go very much, and see all the folks. If they will

all promise to come & see us here, I'll give up going this winter. Perhaps it would be quite as well for me to keep still where I am. as to be jounced about. I want to see Almeda and the children. Charles & Albina & the babies of course will come & make us a visit by & by, and I cannot see any possible reason why Almeda can't come and bring you down, and see us, or she and James come alone.

                   Samuel took one pr of your gloves - the rest were sold by the lump for 2/ a pair at Hatch & Thompson's, payable in goods. Samuel has taken a due bill for that amount, and credited you with the same, (three dollars). A letter from Isaac last night. You probably get letters from him as often as we do. he is to have $5.00 per day for a short time - he wants us all to advise with regard to his staying there.
                  Eliab has said everything necessary & I am "engaged with company" - Please decide soon about coming here & let is know. In haste
                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Lucy.

Bangor Nov. 6. 1851

                                                                                                                                                    Bangor Nov. 6, 1851.

Dear Mother

                             There is the most distant imaginable prospect that Samuel will go to Milo tomorrow, so I will write a little and have it ready to send. He want to see Mr. One, and unless he gets a letter from him today, may go. Eliab had a letter from Ann yesterday. No news except that Argyle P. Rumsey took Bliss (The name of his wife) to himself very unexpectedly to see his friends a few days since. She gives Eliab lots of good advice about "Susan" etc.etc. I have had a "pull back" for a few days - feel better today. I cannot imagine the cause, but my back gave out all at once. It was as much as I could well do to get across the room.
   Frances says she wants to go home before Thanksgiving, which you know, is the 27 - of this month. So please to hasten your decision that I may not be left without any help. Eliab thinks that unless he makes a trade with Brown to go back there, he shall go west very soon. Then, if expedient, we can turn "Tib" away, so as to have a small family. I suppose he will be more likely to let us have the house, and at reasonable rent, if he can stay here - it will be very convenient to live so near Milo "our house" is building. Please to write soon your conclusions upon all these matters. Is Albina going to send us a good lot of butter? I do so much

[left-hand side] Good bye Mother & all the rest. shall write you a long letter as soon as I can find a place at which to date it.

want to arrange matters so that I can go to Milo to Thanksgiving, but I fear it will not be expedient. I don't know but I must give up my visit to Milo till another year. I had a good visit from Mary Tower. She is a noble girl. How much I have said and thought about that ironing board, and not one word regarding its fate have I yet learned.

                         I hope Almeda will take an early opportunity to get hold of Frances after she goes home and talk with her just right. I think she is serious and inquiring, but is very ignorant. She seems very much interested in the Sabbath school, says she hates to leave it. She says she never was taught any thing on religious subjects, and never had any chance to learn this summer, says she thinks Universalist parents do very wrong to bring their children up without teaching them anything about religion. Where she worked last summer they never said a word to her about attending meeting or S. School. didn't care whether she went or not, she says she is very glad she came here to live and glad she went to S. School--never was in a family where the people were pious before etc. etc. She is a good hearted girl, good feelings and intentions, very - Mother and I came to that conclusion a great many times last summer! Well after all Mrs. Keene's folks are real clever people! It is most dark - good night.

Sat. night - Have just rec'd your letter. Sam'l

is going down street tonight, so I'll finish this and send along. Samuel has decided to give two hundred dollars for the meeting house. As Eliab says, it is a "rub and a go" with all of them. Eliab has decided to go away somewhere Monday - so soon. He hardly knows where himself I believe - perhaps to Cleveland. We have tried to persuade him to loaf this winter but he thinks he cannot. He says now I page torn perhaps he may not go. I don't believe he will page torn says if he goes away, he shall not do anything for the church. Samuel is sawing out lumber at a great rate for hen house. Mr. says if they will sell the pews he will put in a hundred dollars, but if they build a free house, not a cent. I am greatly obliged to Charles for his good turkey intentions - and shall depend on his visit this winter., the sooner the better. Frances want to go home before Thanksgiving , so you can come as soon as you get ready and have a mind to. Isaac's last letter said he was very well & hearty. I am better for two or three days - getting smart again. I do wish I could go to Milo 27 - but suppose it is not worth while. I hope you will all, Almeda and all the rest, come to see is if I don't. Should think the cheapest & easiest hoods Almeda could make would be knit hoods of comforters. Well very soon I shall be gladdened by the sight of my Mother's face. I have got a bundle

of Independent, Mother's Magazine etc. to send when there is a chance. good bye - love to all - write when you will come - In great haste. Lucy, seems as if there is something more I want to say -but can't think.

[post mark]BANGOR ME  [n.d. written across post mark] C? hance right

                                                                        Mrs. A.M. Metcalf
                                                                                  Milo
                                                                                 Maine

Bangor Nov. 16. 1851

                                                                                                                                        Nov. 16 - 1851.

Dear Mother

                                It is Monday morning just after breakfast, and just light enough for me to see to write. Frances is bustling about, sweeping, making beds etc. preparatory to going to washing. Samuel has gone to surveying. Mr. Tebbits is over at work on the "Pendle-pant's" house.
                       Three good surveyors are "out of the market" - (one gone to selling rum - the only licensed rumseller in Bangor) one moved to Boston, and one sick, so there is a great demand for surveyors, now just as the river is shutting up, and everybody is in a hurry to get their lumber surveyed and the vessels sent off. Divers people are after Samuel. The surveyor general is very anxious for Samuel to take hold and help this fall, but won't give him a commission for another year. I tell him I would'nt do a thing now in the coldest most uncomfortable part of the whole season, unless he would let one survey next year. Samuel says he could probably make six or seven dollars a day till the river freezes. So he surveys some, and stays at the mill some.                     
                     Well I am looking to see Mother, Jane and Charlie this week. What a time! Don't disappoint me now, will you? Am also expecting a letter from Eliab. In regard tp Butter. I suppose you may send us as much as you want to more or less! Samuel says we shall want fifty pounds of you want to spare it. I don't know - I suppose

we had better get somewhere enough to last through the winter and spring, as it is always higher in the spring you know. I suppose, too, that you all of course want to save yours to get the highest price. Perhaps I told you wrong about the price - it has been a shilling until lately, and Samuel got some very good firkin butter for .15 but it is now eighteen. You can let us have just what amount you please, only let us know soon whether we can depend on a supply there, so as if not to find it elsewhere.

                            I want one No. of the American Messenger delivered to Frances this winter. I will pay for it. She says it has done her a great deal of good being here, and attending S. School. This summer - after she goes home. she will have very little good reading probably, and very little good influence.  I think it would be a good plan for the children to send the South's dayspring, wellspring and any other good reading, after they have ' done with it, over into that neighborhood. Frances says they have nothing of the kind there. She says "they seem to be all good people over your way, and all bad ones our way." She says they are all ignorant, Universalists & sabbath-breakers. She says she thinks her Grandmother is a Christian, but she has lived so long among Universalists that she, Frances, sometimes thinks she is one too, though she and her daughter (Mrs. Goren? have a great many talks about it. She says her Grandmother cannot walk to meeting & they have no way to ride and if they had, she is so fleshy it is very difficult for her to

get into a waggon - and that good people never call to see her. Mr. Partridge called about ten minutes. Mr. Temple not at all. She wishes they would call and see her. What should hinder Almeda from getting acquainted with Frances (not make too much of her) and then she and Mrs. Sargent or somebody Club together and go to see Mrs. Davis. It might comfort her up, edify her and do her great good. If there is a bible class sustained, as there ought to be. This winter in Milo, I want Frances should be invited into it and instructed. She says she wished she had been brought up differently. She never knew how interesting the Bible was till this summer - she never cared anything about reading it before etc. I presume her Mother will use her influence, be it much or little, to make a Universalist of her, and if there be not some conteracting influence, she may lose what little of good impressions she has gained this summer. You had better not mention the state of things much, as our remarks may come to ears who will accuse is of merely desiring to proselyte.
