It will save me a deal of trouble and vexation, if it can be all arranged so. Perhaps to come the last of winter or early in the spring - depend upon how well I am how soon I want her. I wish you would attend to it without delay & secure her if she is a suitable person. Samuel and I really went

in a coach and two last evening to see the "seven mile mirror" - a panorama of Niagara falls, St. Lawrence river etc. Really worth seeing and I stood it nicely. Anne and Eliab went before and Jane yester afternoon. I also went to church last sabbath. I want to go to Milo dreffully. Love to Mrs. Sargent & everybody. We are greatly puzzled to know why you were at work for Mrs. Ha?.

            Anne is waiting to go down town. So I must not stop longer. Aff. Lucy.

We shall expect you immediately if the traveling is such that you can come - In haste.

Miss A.M. Metcalf

            Milo
               Maine

suitable person, Samuel and I really went

Dear Mother

    Charles is here - and dear Joseph has gone without my seeing him! Charles will tell you about it. It seems as if I could not have it so, that I must not see him again, but I suppose it is all right and best. I will try to feel so. I am so afraid he will ? injury rather than benefit by going, but I hope not. I am learning not to place great dependence on any thing. So many changes and disappointments - To be sure very few have come directly upon me, for which I ought to, and do, I hope feel thankful, but ? Joseph's case is certainly an affliction to us all. I cannot bear to think that he is gone, without my seeing him once again - but I ought not to make you call feel worse by writing so I know. We will feel comforted & hope he will get better. I was so glad & surprised to see dear Charles this morning - Now, dear Mother, sisters, all, you will come and see us where we "dwell m our own hired house" won't you? I shall depend on it. They are hurrying me - do write soon good bye affectionately Lucy.

Grandma is very sick - and Pa has got the hypo. horribly - I know they want us to move. - which we are no less anxious to do. 

[odd words only transcribed]My son we are so in the habit of thinking you are man and can ?? that I don't share half I feel of recalling to your mind the motherly ?? that I want all boys need have faults to say to you as often as I should get wisdom and with all my getting get understanding My goodness shall grown into my ??  and thine evil wither & decay after when you were a very little child you used to say you used to be then I will soon be and ever since I rec'd ??   many temptations     ????????
your journey of life without a  guide ?God is ready to  give the Helping Hand to him that ask him
more words written across with the signature  A. Furber

March 1853                                                                            Sunday Morn, 12th
Dear Mother

         I write a few lines this morning before meeting, so as to send before Wednes. Samuel is gone again up river - went last Tues. intending to be gone some days but n=met some of the men at Mattawamkeag with the bodies of two of his men that were drowned in the Millinocket Lake in going needlessly from one camp to the other Sunday night so he came back with them Wednes. started again yesterday to be gone a few days now we want much that you should come down next Thurs.  if the travelling is such that you can comfortably come in the stage - we want you here very much more for many reasons Lucy has ill turns once in a while and needs you here. yesterday after getting Sam'l off at the early ? baking bread and half a dozen pies and getting all into the oven by nine o'clock she had a turn of feeling strangely and we sent for the doctor who told her it was overstraining of the nervous system: now she won't mind me, but perhaps she would you; there are other reasons, plenty of them, why it seems to us best that you should be here as soon as you can consistently.
   As to the ribbon you wrote about I will attend to it the first opportunity to send.
                      Much love to all                    Anne

My only reason for not contradicting, in fact, Anna's statements in regard to myself, is that you are left to believe that I am pretty naughty and bad off, you will be more likely to come soon. I have been very well - heretofore - don't know what ailed me yesterday. - mostly fright I guess, because I felt a little strange - well enough this morning - but we do want you to come very much, as soon as the travelling will admit. You must know it seems very lonely here when Samuel is away. It was very sad about those two men being drowned - one an Irishman of this place - a great parade and funeral - six hacks and 28 chaises - the other a young man from Know - his cousin went home with his body last Wednesday night, with a horse & waggon which Samuel furnished here, and has not yet returned  - we cannot imagine why - keeping the horse so long will make a good deal of expense, though Samuel expects his friends will bear part of it. The whole quite an expense - three or four men, the boats & three days time down to Mattawamkeag (where Samuel met them) and back - an inauspicious commencement of their winter's operations. Samuel has now gone with ten men ( part hired for the purpose and part to remain there) to take in

supplies. This long continued warm weather makes it bad for them - they have feared they should be obliged to drive the teams out - but the weather looks more favorable now - they are not so badly off as many others. You have never written how much cotton yarn my rugs will want. What is the "little daughter" name to be? Prof. Shepard preached a fine sermon upon Maine Thanksgiving day  it is to be published . We have a new book -real good - Cheever's "Voices of Nature to her foster child the soul of man". Charles must read it some time. - In haste - good bye - Lucy -
Much love to all -always to Mrs. Sargent.
I leave it especially in your charge to engage that woman you spoke of - I have written nothing about it to Almeda. Samuel by mistake carried away the P.O. key so we can get no letters till he comes we expect him Wednesday.

Mrs. A. M. Metcalf
                           Milo
                                     Maine

Bangor June 4 1853

                                                                                                Bangor June 4 - 1853.

Dearest Mother & all dear ones,

                          I find myself writing again because my thoughts are so much with you that they want to run off the end of my pen, & send themselves in wordy shape to your eyes. I do not know what I shall do if I don't get a letter from some of you tonight. I am so anxious to know all the particulars of Lucy's sickness, its course etc. and how you all are now.
 After dinner - just as I had got so far I had to attend to the baby & before I found time to write again, Samuel came bringing your letter, & Mr. Bradeen to dinner. The letter  was dear good, what there was of it, but I want more particulars about dear Lucy. did Almeda think that studying causes her sickness? Mrs. Lee came down in the stage Thursday, called a moment supposing I had not heard of Lucy's death, but I persuaded her to spend the night & take the stage from here to Bucksport which

[left-hand side] You ought at least to send love to Maria when you write

she did with apparent pleasure. Thus far when Maria came to spend the afternoon. She has been up most every day. One day Samuel carried her to Oldtown with him. She enjoyed it much. Has had four letters from Eliab already, though he had not at his last date arrived at his place of destination. Yesterday Miss Mary Adams called. Hearing through Mr. Bennett's folks that Mrs. Lee was here, she came to invite her to their house. She sat an hour in familiar converse. I scarcely even felt so self possessed & free to act myself before in my life. Really I believe I equalled her in fluency & ease in conversation. I spoke of Lucy. She recollected her at once as my niece who attended Miss Call's school. She also remembered Joseph. Spoke particularly of his examination for admittance to the church. He differed from others on some topics, family worship etc. and expressed his opinions in a very original manner - said she formed the impression that he lived within himself very much. Mrs. Bartlett & S. Parker called today. I forgot to tell Ann that Mr.
[left-hand side] Baby has made considerable effort to look at his hands.

Packard left his regards for her. Mrs. Lee says it don't hurt baby's to give them sugar rags. Samuel brought some catnip & elder flowers at the apothecaries today. Mrs. Lee says better give him "Loot" than oil if he needs physic, as he frequently does. Catnip she says is good for the wind, soothing too & don't hurt them a bit. I don't dose him nor give him a rag if I can help it. Mrs. G. is kind and good - I like her better & better, though she is far from being judicious with Jane. She is learning the "ways of the house" and does not say "sho, sho" nor "he-aw, he-aw" near so much as she did. A recent letter from Bill says Theodore & Sarah will probably start for Maine this month. Father's leg is nothing bettered but rather grows worse. I have walked across the room a few times - have broken my supporter & dare not make any great demonstrations till it is fixed. I washed & dressed the little P.P. day before yesterday asking advice from nobody - he was good as a kitten. I made out nicely. He laughed out loud heartily today when Maria was talking

to him. We rather thought he mourned after you -was more worrysome than usual. Is generally as good a common babies I think. You know I don't think he is anything remarkable notwithstanding you have all tried to make me think he is. I am glad if I need not wear my sholls any longer, though Mrs. Lee says I ought to save the milk to feed the baby with for economy's sake. I thought you and Anna were both going to stay at Almeda's some time now. How I wish I could write a letter that would comfort her - but she well knows where to look for such sympathy & comfort as no earthly friend can give her How very appropriate Mr. Sewall's text was. Lizzie Doe has been in twice. The last time brought me a splendid boquet - fourteen tulips, sever different kinds, Jonquil, Lilacs & the dear Lily of the Valley. I wished very much the last was at Brownville to lay by dear Lucy. Shady side is really interesting & I should think might do good. I wish Anne would write to Maria. 

  I was asleep & Jane forgot to give the saddle to Mr. Livermore, so Sam'l sent it by Gould today.

Bangor May 3, 1851

                                                                                                    Bangor May 3rd 1851.

My dear people all

                              It is just after dinner, and I conclude if I am to write by Monday's mail, it is time to be about it. We journeyed very comfortably indeed, considering  - stopped at Parson Kale's to dinner. They were very kind indeed - laid down and rested nicely - nearly two hours. From there we journeyed to Lissie Doe's, where they almost per force of arms compelled us to stop to tea, though we had about decided in our own minds not to do so. Had a nice time. - laid down & rested and Lizzie brought my supper to me. Mrs. S. is there - going to Portland after helping Lissie pack. The hardest time I had was getting over the river! We arrived at this very pretty, cozy and comfortable place a little after sunset. I was, as I expected, very tired, and feel rather sleepy and pounded today. I did not really lie down but a little while, though I could do so very comfortable, but I leaned into Samuel's lap on or his shoulder considerable. He carried me all about the house this morning. I really like it better than the house in Hampden. It is a fine airy situation - perfectly convenient & comfortable below, and chambers very much prettier than at Hampden. It hardly seems like

home yet, though I presume it soon would, if I could run about the house. I have not seen Eliab yet - hope he will be up this evening. Issac, I rec'd a most excellent and very kind letter from a young lady of your acquaintance, dated at Concord New Hampshire today. I intend to answer it in a few days. She has told me the whole story about her being engaged etc. Now what do you think?

         I wish you would take the earliest opportunity to send the big chair by some careful teamster to be left at the second house below Mr. Harlow: on the opposite side. I use the big easy chair, but the castors are out of order, and it being very difficult to move, Samuel is obliged to carry me all about.
         Samuel will ascertain about the cow as soon as he can. I expect Lissie will be here some next week. I wish you could find out & write by Tuesday's mail or as soon as practicable  about the "coronation cord," as I must get Lissie or Mehitable to do my shopping before they go. 
           Isaac's letter is not in any of those books. Samuel says he certainly saw it once in one of the drawers under the glass.
          5 o'clock P.M. What do you think? Flora Tower Pond, Mary W. Tower and Mrs. Joseph Teeat have called here this afternoon. Flora married & living in Boston, and Mary who has been nearly two years at school in Woburn & Charlestown, on their way to Foxcroft to see Rebecca who is very sick - they were too late to go today & being obliged to wait till

Monday took the opportunity to call here. Mary is the same dear girl - Flora much out of health. Mary is going home to stay some time - probably preparing to be married. Samuel has gone to Hampden, Sis trimming her bonnet & Nea getting supper. I think our pickles the best I ever tasted - hard as a green cucumber.
Saturday Eve I think that I shall keep the cow this summer if I can get them pastured as I expect.- If Ch's has one to sell he better send them both down in about ten days, get some boy to drive them and I will sell his for him if he does not wish to come down.
Nothing yet certain with regard to business this season.
Sabbath noon. Eliab is here - says he is perfectly well -looks as well as I have seen him for a long time. I do miss my dear Mother very much. I feel anxious to hear about her cold - am afraid she took more standing out by the carraige, I hope you will get the wool picked and all your matters attended to before many weeks so as to come down here. S.C. Thurston has gone to Carlostine Jewett's to board. Hannah Moore has got homesick at Wisconsin - has returned to N.Y. Her brother at California died a short time since. Isaac, I shall depend upon your coming to stay a nice while with me - you never did make me much of a visit. I should think, too, you had rather be here some. so as to know what is going on. I must finish this to send to the office when the folks go to meeting. Do please all write often. Cannot Charles & Albina ever squeese out a letter to me? Affectionately Lucy.

I do feel very sorry and bad about Isaac's letter What can be done about it? Lobsters for dinner. 

Mrs. Anna M. Metcalf

            Milo
                Maine

Bangor June 13, 1853

                                                                                                                                    Bangor June 13 - 1853

Dear Mother

                     Your good letter rec'd two or three days since, very gladly. I thought you were going to stay longer at Almeda's while Anna was there. Are you going again before she comes from there? Maria has kindly offered to do your shopping (a great amount!) and Almeda's. She sent her bonnet to be colored & trimmed, and wished a veil procured also. Eliab came home last friday - made no purchases - Maria was dear good while he was gone - came almost every day; sewed some, altering a dress for me, and relieved me almost entirely of the care of baby, and for that matter Mrs. Griffith too - she kept him all the time - fed him with checkerberry, catnip and what not. She understand the matter of taking care of babies admirably I assure you. The little Percie is very good most of the time - has a worrying day once in awhile, as yesterday for instance, but is just as good as babies can be today to pay for it. I have not fed him a bit for a number of days, except occasionally a little elder blows or checkerberry for medicine. The elder flower answer nicely for physic. Mrs. Lee said they were good, so I deem it no harm to use them, although she alone of all the many I have consulted in regard to "sugar rags" agrees with Mrs. Page - O, yes,

[left-hand side]I thought you were going to stay at Almeda's with Anna, so as to fix that delaine dress right off. I forgot to give you the pieces  - will send them by Jane. & Samuel.

Mrs. Chalmers did say that with her twins she could not get along without them. I understand Mrs. Me. Ruen does not approve of them. I only give baby one when he is dressed, changed, left to lay a pillow while we eat, or otherwise abused! If I was well and whole backed he would not have one so much. I would stay away from table and take care of him. He grows very fast - his neck and wrists are full of creases. He lies sometimes from fifteen minutes to half an hour looking about and feeling of his ear. I don't keep a blanket round him now - sometimes nothing and sometimes a white handkerchief. His "navel station" don't look quite right and I am knitting some bands to cling a little closer to him - have got one done - we don't let him cry hard at any rate - always give him the rag of we cannot pacify him without. The enclosed letters from Nettie came Saturday. One today from Father . His leg is some better. Theodore and Sarah start the middle of this month for Maine. I forgot to tell you that little P.P. keeps up a spirited conversation with Col. Lee most of the time! Mrs. Griffiths says that the the girl Almeda had belongs to a thievish family - cousin or sister, I don't recollect which, to a girl who worked at Mr. Beale's home in Bangor, who stole so they were obliged to send her home. I presume it is the one Mr. Tebbetts spoke of, who abstracted his stocking etc. However my mind is easy at present about a girl for Mrs. Griffiths will

stay all summer. She is kind, capable and faithful. Her price is high but it is much better to give at this summer than to have poor help. I will put in a piece of my new dress that Maria selected for me - french calico at thirty cents a yard. Miss Raynes made a mistake in the front breadth so I was obliged to get another, and consequently have enough left to make baby a dress next summer if he should live. I do so want to go to Milo - suppose Samuel would rather go when Theodore is there, so we shall not probably go till towards the last of summer. I have written to Isaac and Nettie and to Almeda within a few days - shall write to Anna soon when Jane goes. I wish Anna would write to Maria. What does Charles do with the carraige? Do please to write very often.
Lucy thinks I should write but a little. I have had to read what she has written to avoid repetition. I think that she has pretty nearly gone over the whole ground. Eliab did not purchase the tract of land which he went to see but is negociating for another tract which I think it quite probable he may buy. Prof. Sheppard preached all day yesterday on giving, in the morning he showed the necessity of supporting Home Missionary enterprises. "Preach the Gospel to all nations beginning at Jerusalem (at home). On the afternoon the Philosophy of giving, "Give alms of such things as ye have and behold all things shall be clean unto yo." The advantages of giving from some Fixed principle rather than from impulse, he thinks every Christian should

fix some bound beyond which they will not amass wealth. each one to settle this point with his own conscience let it one thousand or ten or twenty or fifty or a hundred such a bound will have an effect to wean the affections from the pursuit of money for its own sake.

 I believe Mr. Sheppard to be right, have acted upon this conviction, have laid down a rule by which to be guided under the working of this rule I find I have in my possession to distributed this year for religious & charitable purposes $140.-- I have appropriated $48, of this to foreign missions the ballance is unappropriated. The Meeting House will (I expect) be Dedicated the last Wedns in this month, don't you want to be here?

I expect that P.P. would be glad to see you.

                                  Good Night 
                                 Samuel

Tues. noon 
I tell Samuel of Mr. Sheppard's sermon benefited me, it was worth preaching. His sermons do tell home. Samuel sat right down after meeting and planned it out, then laid it by to think of a spell - has now decided upon it. I think I shall send Jane this week friday  - possibly not till Monday. Baby laughed a little, loud, twice yesterday - how soon will it do to let him risk a bit on his feet? he want to now - he is very strong - improves in his personal appearance every day. I have dressed him three times. Don't think of anything more. good bye. Lucy
[left-hand side] Just got a letter from Anne - how sad it was about Lucy's place at Foxcroft - I can't bear to think of it. It seems to me that Almeda only ? realise the loss. Baby weighs  11 1/2 pounds.

Bangor June 27 '53

                                                                                      Bangor June 27 - 1853

Dear Mother

                   Your dear letter was gladly received Saturday night. Samuel thankfully appropriated his share, and P.P. received the kisses graciously if not gratefully. I have had a fine ride this morning, which has done me good, came home and dressed baby; (so that Mrs. Griffiths need not be hindered about the washing.) he is now sleeping quietly on the lounge. He is very good - grows better and better, though he had now and then a worrying day, as do all babies, I suppose. He frequently lies half an hour at a time looking about, laughing & crowing, fisting  & kicking. but his crowning virtue is goodness a'nights. A few nights he has not waked from bed time till 4 o'clock- seldom more than one.Yesterday afternoon I got Ann Page to stay with me so that Mrs. G. could go to meeting.- baby slept all the time so I might just as well have staid alone. i am getting along finely - walk about the house considerable - Saturday walked out to the sink and back at one stretch. Friday Samuel carried Maria and I up to Mount hope. The longest ride I have taken. The rose bushes by little "Anna's" grave are alive. Mr. Tebbets has a very handsome monument of Egyptian marble. The grounds improve very much every year. Maria's sister and cousin whom she

expected Saturday did not come, will probably be here tomorrow. I am in a state of trepidation, as they will probably be at our home some. It is "sister Hattie", too, and I expect she is "au faite" in everything. I have bought a pair of handsome tea pots and a china set according to Ann's suggestions of what I needed. Samuel brought up six britannia teapots of different kinds and Col. Lee and I selected from them! The China Samuel & I selected together down street. The stove is moved from the parlor and a fine board of a darling pretty pattern (Samuel's selection) in its place, the carpet taken up in the sitting room & put down with some new oil cloth. The place is fixed in the back room for the new cook stove, waiting for the funnel to be ready. Just when I had written so far my little birdie began to warble rather vehemently then melodiously, & I left off to put something in his bill, which, when I had done and laid him down again in a very good natural frame of mind, Mrs. Parson appeared at the door with one of her splendid baskets of flowers for me - don't know where she got them- she has none of her own this year. Those, with some Ann Page brought a day or two since, fill three vases. How beautifully they do look wish I could bestow one vase at your house and another in Brownville at a place  I wot of.

      It is afternoon. Samuel has gone to Sunkhaze - said he has thirty five miles to ride after one o'clock, and wished to get back to rehearsal this evening.

Five o'clock P.M. There has been a rainy shower in consequence of which Mr. Bartlett and Mr.  Brie of Hampden were driven in here for shelter, and here they have been for two mortal hours to my especial "discomfort." Mrs. Griffiths was all in the suds, washing floors etc., and I was forced to nurse the baby before them (as I could not carry him behind them) besides giving him a sugar rag most all the time to keep him quiet. Now they are gone, he is as clever as can be!  Why don't you send love to Mrs. Griffith? She is truly kind, considerate and Christian - some things exceptionable in every body, but I do like her very much. I am much favored in getting her - she wears well. You need 'at twit Jane about it, but how much quicker the dishes do get washed nowadays. Mrs. G makes nothing of doing Jane's work. It is really matter of astonishment to one that she is so very slow. I hope she will get up a little more energy up there - Does she do well with the children? Lizzie Doe was in last Saturday, brought me a fine bunch of flowers, which I desired her to take to Maria's as I had some already. She has been to Portland to the ? meetings-  Mrs. Crosby and Margaret went. Lissie was treated shamefully by Prescot Shepard. We have the Miss. Herald. Samuel is entitled to it for what he paid for For. Miss.  He sent for the Christian Mirror today. "Do baby's eyes grown blacker or whiter?" They grow bluer & lighteer and his hair grows browner & lighter every day. He looks quite plump and white compared with what he

did when you went away. I have written to Almeda, Anne and Nettie quite lately. I insinuated to Isaac that his birdie must be a blackbird as it was "born in Egypt? What think you of the enclosed advertisement?
Tues. morn - Baby weighs thirteen lbs lacking a quarter. A great solid fellow - we have not carried him out yet & wonderful to tell, I have not been to Mrs. Crosby's yet. Samuel wrote to Col. Lee this morning of the time for the dedication of our meeting house - he thought, when here, he should come up if he could ascertain when it would be. It is next Thursday evening -Rehearsals  of the choir most every evening - learning a new piece. Samuel carried me down to the new church last week. It is handsome - 'specially the painting - the ladies are greatly hurried making carpets etc. Some of the cushions do not fit - have to be pieced out- Mr. Cushing is in Bangor in the wool business some way - told Samuel he thought he would give Charles forty five cents for his wool. Dinner is ready - I must top. Cushing says bring wool soon as you can. Samuel  called at your old friend Paul Indley's a few days since - made an errand on purpose - he remembered you. In haste & much love. Lucy.

Bangor July 6. 1853

                                                                                                                     Bangor July 6 - 1853.

Dear Mother

               I will hastily scribble a few words this morning before breakfast because I suppose you will want to hear from us, and to do an errand.
                   Miss Pease was here yesterday; is coming today and tomorrow. She is a good dressmaker & makes short bones and biases, and makes a dress feel easy - She has improved very much in that respect since she fitted our dresses before. My dress is going to set as well as it can, but I am so big and homely that it seems almost a pity to cut up nice silk for me! She is going to make over my light silk. I see nothing now to prevent my going to meeting half of every sabbath all summer. Next week Samuel expects to be considerably at leisure, and I think of making some calls with my "new silk gown on." I have written to Ann and directed to Brownville - don't know that she will ne at Milo and so not get it very soon.
             My errand is that Maria is not very well nothing special - only spring feelings - weak air languid -says he has no strength to make her bed some mornings till she has laid down on it to rest. She thinks she is billious - says it is her 

[at top upside down] How I wish I could help you pick & eat your strawberries.

spring now - just about such weather as spring in Mass., you know. She said she was ashamed of herself so did not want me to say anything about it, but she consented to let me write to you to see if you could conveniently get cherry and round wood baskets to fix up some bitters as you used to for Eliab. He is not very well and needs some too. She told me to say it was for him. Can your get Ricker boys or somebody to get the materials. If you can, send down by stage or any way. She feels a constant weariness, sleepiness & lassitude. Don;t write to them anything about it, for she will think I have made a great matter of it. She's real good and Eliab's life is bound up in her. I saw at Hatch's the other day, some four cent sheeting - very thin - used a good deal for cheese strainers. Would Albina like some?
Thurs. morn. I must finish off my letter - didn't have time before. One hundred and eleven pews in the new church sold or rented for $2200.00 last Tuesday evening. Eleven more below and all the gallery pew to rent yet. I am getting along finely only pretty tired for a day or two with fourth of July and dress making . Why don't you please to write all of you. You are dear good though Mother about writing please continue to be so, In haste
Lucy.

Tues. June 7  

    I intended to write considerable more in this & to enclose a letter to Albina, but we hear that Mr. & Mrs. Crosby are coming here to dinner also two gentlemen, delegates to the county conference which meets with our church today & tomorrow, so I must "muggle away" my letter in short metre. Samuel & Mrs. Griffiths both went to meeting sabbath afternoon communion. Jane staid with me, with the aid a sugar rag I got along finely. I had a long talk with her, went over the whole history of her life with her and some distance into the probably future, taking quite a business view of the matter. She seemed to look at it seriously & realize more than ever before. She is now evidently trying hard, and I think really feels anxious to do well at Milo: but even if she does, there will be many trials & unpleasant things to hear from her owing o her natural disposition & temperament, which, as she says, she cannot help. 

[upside down] guess I shall send Jane next week
[top upside down] Marie is coming tomorrow to stay till Saturday. I like her more and better.

I do pity her , and was hardly aware before how much I really loved her. It makes me feel bad to send her away so. I am afraid I have not borne with her so much as I ought. My conversation with her was very serious, but perfectly kind. I went over the whole ground, why we took her into the family, her conduct throughout, what we had reason to expect of her, the interest we had all taken in her, how much more she would have been loved by all if she had been a different child, and that she might yet gain & retain the love and good wishes of all, but I "put it" to her decidedly that she had hot her living to earn, that if she did well she could probably remain in the family for a while at least & in many respects make it easier & pleasanter for herself than to go among strangers, etc. etc. I talked to her "well I could, tear in my eye." But how I am spending my time when I should be resting & getting ready for company. In haste, with love, Lucy.
[written across letter] Thedore

Bangor July 12, 1853  Where is Charles Wool?

                                                                                                                                                     Bangor July 12 - 1853.

Dear Sister Anna

                                              In haste I scribble a few words to tell you about the schools. Baby dear is asleep & I want to do numerous things before he wakes. I suspect you will not soon get my last letter, as I directed to Brownville, & it probably reached there about the time you went to Milo. I have been to ride this morning - have been almost every day for a long time - got my new dress done & went to meeting Sunday. Miss Pease staid three days - I wish people could go to meeting & wear calico loose dresses & feel comfortable. The school term closes this week - so you will hardly be able to attend examinations - there is not usually any public examinations except in the Spring, but I understand there is to be this time. If you had known it sooner should you have come? I saw Lissie Doe this morning - think she won't write, you are coming so soon. she went to Old Town with Samuel one day. Samuel called to see Col. Webster on business - spoke of Mother - he said he had very often heard his wife speak of Anna Stevens. How busier you & Mother are going to be - wish I could help you - will try when you come, but every days brings just as much as I can get along with - if baby was not good as he can be don't know what I should do.He really begins to know considerable. Am intending

to take him over to Maria's visiting tomorrow! The whooping cough is all about in this neighborhood & all in the city. I must be careful of him. We, (Sam'l, Maria and I) went to see the Siamese twins last week. Margaret Crosby is very low - had failed rapidly for a few days past. They have Dr. McRuen now - he says it is undoubtedly a case of consumption & will prove fatal. We were down there a few days since to call. She is so weak we did not think best to go down for strawberries as we intended. Company is too exciting for her. I am on tiptoe to go to Milo -seems as if I must go before you and Mother leave, but I feel as if Samuel must be gratified in being there with Theodorre. However letters from Minnesota recently received, lead us to suppose they will be here by the fifteenth. They come before you go. We are expecting a letter, or themselves, every day. Maria is better - They were here last night, We have some drefful hot days. In intense haste.

                                                                                                                                    Lucy.

Samuel had a tooth broken twice yesterday attempting to extract it -- roots left in yet - does not ache any now. Mrs. Pushaws (Egery) died quite suddenly Sunday night do not know what her disease was buried this forenoon. Our last letter from Isaac June 13th.

Bangor July 19 53

                                                                                                                                                      Bangor July 19 - 1853

Dear Sister Anna

                                     After receiving your letter of last Saturday, we about decided to go to Milo tomorrow (Wednes) but the next news was the burning of the Chicago school house-, the letter containing which, you have undoubtedly received: We now conclude that you will not probably feel in so much hurry about starting, and as we are daily expecting Theodore, and also as it will be more convenient for Samuel to go next week, we shall wait and go Monday, unless we receive letters from you that you still adhere to your plan of coming Monday; in which case I shall probably not go at all this summer, for various reasons. Please write by first mail your conclusions. Theodore & Sarah will undoubtedly be here this week and we do not like to be away when they come. If we go before they come Samuel would want to go again, which would be inconvenient. Isn't it singular about the school house? Lissie says there is a Jonah. We rode up to see her last night - she says she don't know anything what to think, but once in a while bursts into a hearty laugh. I think she feels a good deal & laughs to keep from crying! She thinks it best by all means to go, according to Mr. Carpenter's invitation. (I did not see the letter

and Eliab did not half read it so as to tell us about it). I imagine that you would not fancy the idea of quartering yourself upon him so ling so much as Lissie seemed to - I think she is anxious to go, then she is willing to do most any way. She is very anxious to see you - wishes you could come down the last of this week. Her sister Louise and her husband are coming this week, so Lissie will be at Glenham a few days now. I have thought fast what you would conclude & how you and Mother & all would talk about the matter. - (wish I was there this minute) I suppose you would start (unless you decide to give it all up and conclude that it is on purpose for you to get time to finish some of your other labors) about as you had intended, make a good visit at Westfield, go and see what Mrs. Hopkins wants of you, and unless you concluded to give yourself to her, (or to somebody else upon her recommendation!) proceed to Chicago, ready for whatever situation there might be, if you liked it. Or do you think better to write to Miss Bright before you decided upon anything & see what opening there is with her. Sarah Harlow was in two hours with her work the other day - said she thought Carrie Prescott would go for the teacher Miss Bright spoke of. I am in such a hurry to hear what you think & am going to do - hope we shall get a letter from you today. The Cherry symp received safe and sound -Maria was over yesterday

day afternoon. "Sister Hattie" has been sick ever since she got home - quite discouraged about herself. Mrs. Griffith can only stay till next month, & I want to find a good girl as soon as I can. Won't you find out, if convenient, what about the color girls? I shall try for Frances if I go to Milo next week. I am ready to fly to see you all -wish we were going tomorrow - don't fail to write your conclusions and whether I shall get Mother's gingham to bring with me - we shall stay only two or three days, Do not hear yet from Isaac. Don't forget to write in your next if you have had letters lately - our last was dated the 13th of June. Dr. McRuen says there is no hope for Margaret -says the left lung is entirely gone - that she has kept up so long, she will probably sink rapidly. We shall try to ride down there tomorrow morning. Her poor father & Mother, I don't know what I can say to them.

              Samuel has just weighed Percie- eleven weeks old last night - weighs almost fifteen pounds. Ir. Me. called the other day - he says if we both keep on growing we shall be good large folks by and by. I want to write to Almeda & to Isaac but don't get any time - and my head & eyes trouble me a good deal - my head had ached almost all the time since I came down stairs - is very sensitive to cold. The Dr. has prepared some pills

for my head and salve for my eyes - guess it helps them some. I don't get time to do much - have not touched my light silk dress yet, which Miss Pease almost finished - should have kept her to finish it but she was engaged. It takes Mrs.G. all the time to do the work - she frequently does not take the baby at all till five or six o'clock at night - she is very good, kind and faithful, but slow. Has been hemming the ruffle to your chemise today - guess she will get time to finish the rest. How I do want to fly to Milo! Do let me have a letter by Thursday if not tonight. Baby's just as good. In great haste - good bye.

                                                                                                  Lucy.

Bangor Sept. 4 - 1853.

Dear Mother

                         Your most welcome letter was received two or three days since. I thank you much for writing so soon. I do hope you will write very often. I suppose you want to know everything that happens while you are gone, so I will scrible away as fast as I can. Thursday seemed rather a lonely day after you started. In the afternoon I got up stairs - the rooms, above and below, looked desolate enough. Friday morning at six Theodore and Sarah left in the Skohegan stage, and then the house looked more empty than ever. Friday afternoon Mrs. Vinal with her little fretting girl, nineteen months old, called. Saturday Mr. Noel & Mr. Wallace, two students came in to tea by Samuel's invitation. Mr. Noel as sent in  our pen you know, and Mr. Wallace is a very sociable little Scotchman, not long from the "auld countrie." Sabbath was communion. I went to church in the afternoon. An

[left-hand side] ? from my youth up there to go to Aunt Conant's & see Aunt Conant was the acme of felicity, notwithstanding the disappointment I there experienced in the matter of a brown bread cake once upon a time. Don't fail to go to Dunbarton. Ask Maria to write to me. Affectionately-daughter- Lucy.

infant baptized - we should have carried ours bit I did not feel well enough. Monday P.M. came Mr. Sewall to stay with us through commencement. Tuesday morning in the boat came his wife, who has been on a three week's visit to Topsham. The commencement exercises were very interesting. I only heard President Hitchcock from Amherst College the last afternoon address the Rhetorical Society? He is very interesting and good. Shows that he is a great man by not using great words! Samuel attended most all the meetings. Old Father Sawyer was here - preached Thursday evening - spoke an hour and twenty-five minutes! Samuel got all tired out - He is ninety-eight years old. Wednes. evening I went with Mr. & Mrs. Sewall & Samuel to the great annual tea party, meeting of the Alumni ( and every body else that is invited) as the Seminary. I staid about an hour, leaving baby with Isabel & got introduced to Rev. Mr. Jones of Minot, Me. who, as I learned, is the author of the little piece of poetry, "How big was Alexander,

Pa?" It was the thirty fourth Anniversary of the Seminary - four of the first class that graduated from it were there of whom Mr. Jones, was one & Mr. Toppan, Mr. Stephen Thurston & Mr. Chapin the others. Mr. Jones told me he had been in Milo -taught school in Sebec & walked to Milo to drink of the celebrated mineral spring in the west part of Milo. Friday night a Mr. Given from Isaac's place took tea here - he brought a letter from Isaac - nothing special in it except a lock of his baby's hair, which I will enclose om this - he wrote just to introduce Mr. G. to us. Yesterday by stage came Lizzie. I wrote Almeda that she had better come, as the schools begin tomorrow & I feared she might not get in unless here at the commencement of the term. I felt almost wearied out the last of the week, but yesterday and day before, I gave baby to Isabel's charge as much as I could, and feel nicely seated now. I imagine you find use for your thin dresses if you have as warm weather as we have had for a few days past. It

Bangor Sept. 4, 1853
has been, and is still excessively warm. I have got baby's carraige & covered it with green plaid gingham, so we amuse him a good deal by drawing him about. He is highly delighted with it.
Mond. morn Sept. 5 - Yesterday P.M. and last night the hottest weather we have had this season. Samuel slept in the lounge most of the night. Baby and I without any covering on the bed. Towards morning a high wind arose. clouds flying, doors and blinds slamming - cool and pleasant this morning. Lissie has to school - I got Nancy Raynes to go with her -shall get her some things this week - Isabel had plenty of time to help me make then, & Lissie can amuse baby meanwhile. Ann Page is going to bud a white rose and Queen of the Prairie into my running rose. Wish I could think of anything more to say - don't see as I can, only much love to all. One firkin is filled with pickles & we are filling another - will send some to Charles if we don't want them all. I hope you and all will enjoy yourselves abundantly there together - and wish I could be with you. It has always been an impression of

Bangor Sept. 8 1853

                                                                                   Bangor Sept, 8 - 1853.

Dear Mother

                         I have nothing at all to write , as I sent a letter but two or three days since, but I received a letter day before yesterday from Anna with a request that I would forward it to you - knowing that you must feel anxious to hear from her, I send immediately. There has been nothing new since I wrote excepting a severe thunder storm yesterday with wind and blackness, which leaves a clearer, purer, cooler atmosphere than before -

"Forty men" - more or less - have "bound themselves an oath" - that is pledged themselves to take turns watching by night to see that no liquor is tender from vessels, or transported from place to place in the city. Samuel & Eliab are among the number. Eliab & Mr. Persons tracked five or six barrels from one floor to another most all night & at length got hold of it towards morning - some five or six hundred dollars worth - they did not see it carried at all, but tracked it by a peculiarity in the horses' feet - the enemies are so much ensorced? that I fear it is dangerous business - baby is in my arms & won't let me write & with much love - goodbye - Lucy

Bangor Oct. 20 55

                                                                                                                               Bangor Oct. 20 - 1853.

Dear Mother

                 Your good letter was welcomed yesterday noon. Maria was here all day, and Eliab to dinner, - Lizzie has just gone to school and baby to sleep, so I embrace this opportunity of quiet to write all the letters I have time to before I am interrupted, - commencing, of course, with yours.
                 In the first place, don't you think this paper is too nice to write "to you" on? Well, if it is, 'tis not my fault. I sent by Samuel for some common small sheets and he got this - he said it was only a trifle higher priced & nicer paper. In the next place, I am thoroughly provoked with Mr. Morrell for his mean unaccommodatingness - it is outrageous & abominable. I remember how very hard the wind blew that day. His wife you know is a cousin to Mrs. Griffith, and I ascribe that and his refusing to bring the shoe, to his

[left-hand side] he said it was inappropriate to "beg our daily bread in blank verse." Every one should strive to fix the attention & follow the train of thought - "call back the wandering soul & hold it sternly till it would delightfully stay." I wish I could write you a great deal of it. we have not heard from Anna again. I must try to write to her today. Maria cannot pattern her velvet at Hartford so she will get Ladies cloth for a cloak. I have actually washed baby's petticoat - the second one he has had washed in his life. Have got one flannel dress almost done. The one ? for our church has come. It is being set up this week. Mrs. Chas. Crosby sent up for Lizzie to come to spend the afternoon with her.

wrath on account of my having a few words with Mrs. Griffith. Then I was so provoked I could hardly refrain from speaking, when you left here, that none of the young people nor gentleman in the stage had politeness enough to offer you a back seat. Poor Lizzie sat down very disconsolate with tears in her eyes after you went away. She had a bad cold for a few days - did not seem at all well & I kept her at home three days and dosed her with thoroughwort syrup. Her appetite was not at all good, - I have her carry luncheons to school, but all the girls tease for the so there is not much comfort in it - "give me a taste," give me a taste," She is nicely now - This fine weather is enough to cure anybody. The big new ship is launched today. Samuel & I and Lizzie are going. Day before yesterday just at night, Samuel found eight bags of liquor, hid under his wharf at the mill. It was so near night, there was not good time to get a warrant, so he forthwith hired a team and had it brought over home. There was a social gathering at the vestry n the evening, where
[left-hand side]little girl last Wednesday. Miss Pitcher called yesterday - says she don't see as she can get along without Lizzie- wants me to intercede

The story was told occasioning no little merriment. He wrote an advertisement for next morning's paper, but after we got home that night about ten o'clock two Irishmen came (so smooth and good, you can't think) claiming it. Samuel told them it was safe for the present - he did not know what would be done with it, read them a lecture on the evil of having anything to do with it etc. They besought him not to let "them fellers" have it! He "didn't promise" either way. Yesterday he sent it to the watch house - will probably be poured out. I got your thimbles when I went for Sally's flannel - will send them by first opportunity. Why did you leave my old comb? I do not want it at all. In the evening of the day you went, Mr. Wallace called bringing another student, Mr. Allen, with him. Maria and I went with Nelly last Saturday down to see Margaret. She is failing rapidly - her Mothers sees it, and says she has felt that it must be so all summer, but could not bear to have it mentioned, and says she knows it is foolish & wrong, but she don't want anybody to speak of it now. Poor
[left-hand side] with her Mother to let her stay till spring- says she is getting along so nicely 'tis a pity to leave. I don't know but she had better. I will

woman - she has a great deal to bear. Mr.Crosby is very bad with the hypo again & partly brought on, I think, by anxiety for Margaret - but it all comes so hard on Mrs. Crosby. She says she finds a great deal to contend with in her own heart. Margaret was lying in bed just as sweet & patient as ever --they have a bed down stairs now. She is very weak. If it were not for baby, how I would love to go down & stay two or three days with her. The social gathering was appointed sabbath day by Mr. Shepard all on his own responsibility - said nothing to nobody beforehand - he says in Mr. Kirks' church they have them once a month all the time. He and his wife were there talking with everybody. I really enjoyed it much - came across Mr. Humphrey & two or three students who were acquainted with Isaac. Mr. S preached a most excellent sermon on worship last sabbath - he took up prayer particularly - is to preach on song next sabbath. He  said the minister had the responsibility of taking the lead, and a great one too, but every one should throw his portion inot the "swelling column of desire." speaking of oratorical precision & nicety  - in prayer, 
[left-hand side] cost no more for clothing. She is all fitted out. I am so glad you think  Mrs. Ruibal is innocent. Tell Binia to write to me - love to all- good bye- Affec.  Do write often yourself. If Albina does not perfectly like her dress, I will take it, but want to know soon about it.

Bangor Nov. 1 53

                                                                                                                                            Bangor Nov. 1 - 1853

Dear Mother

                      Your good long letter was yesterday received. Much, very much, obliged. Wish I could get as long and particular a one every week. But about Jane - I feel ever sad. I can hardly keep from crying every time I think of her - poor, unhappy girl! What will become of her? Samuel says if he could only spare the time, he would take her right to Dover, find her mother and leave her there. As for going to Mrs. Anstris, I don't know, but it seems to me if she is ever coming back to our family at all, to live with any of us, she will not be any better for going away & carrying on just as she pleases all winter. I don't know, I don;t know, what can be done with & for this poor child. I invited Maria to take her yesterday! Her sympathies were so much roused for a poor little spanish girl in 

[left-hand side and top] and tree, with tow-boats, ropes and hundreds of men - liners, sc? and what not, all to no purpose - the ways were not sufficiently greased. Samuel said. It went off next day but none of us saw it. Owing to neglect in the builders of our church, the large beams 65 feet long were not properly tied together & jarred by the tremendous wind of last Monday night, one beam sprung off two inches letting for flooring timbers & plastering door. Injured many pews & had it been in time of service must have killed many people. It was a sad accident.

Cuba that we heard about lately - she said if she had been in this country she should have taken her in a moment - her only fear was of the Spanish temper. In that respect I imagine she would not go beyond Jane. When I read of "Juliet" in "Retribution," I thought the character & temper was one drawn, bit I don't know but there are some as ? wild & ungovernable as hers was represented. 

 I have forgotten whether I wrote you in my other letter about my turn over. Maria & I were going to make some calls alone with Nelly. I started from here to go after Maria, got down as far as tje Mail road bridge when hearing a noise of wheels & shouting, I looked back and saw a double team, driverless, running down the hill. I drove up on the side walk & got out of the way as much as I could, but they came against the back wheel of my waggon, throwing it round half across the street & turning it  over; as it turned, I "stepped out," and then found myself standing upright in

[left-hand side] we meet in the vestry while the house is repaired. Our new Organ - a pure white, with gilding is set up. The sermon on sacred song has been preached.
[upside down] your mind to come back here by and by.

the street, uninjured, with my parasol over my head, as calm & unconcerned as you please. I could'nt help laughing. I suppose if I had been half killed I should have kept my parasol safe; and in its proper place over my head! Well, some gentleman came to the rescue, helped me in, I went after Mallie & after some deliberation we went on our way and made six calls. It bent the apletru & lost the whip. I was not injured at all, but somewhat jarred, so that my back & general feelings have not been quite so comfortable since - getting over it though - I put on one of Aunt Conant's  plasters, which does me good - please tell her so I thank her for them when you write.

 Yesterday Mallie & I went shopping with Nelly, & over after Samuel at night. I was gone from baby three hours & a half - longer than I intended, but he did not so much as whimper once. He is just about as good as a baby can be generally - has a worrying day once in a while, but frequently sits in his

[left-hand side] It was good. We were down to see Margaret again Saturday evening - she is very low - I should not be surprised at any time to hear of her death - she's
[top upside down] I want you should begin immediately to make up

carraige from an hour to an hour and a half at a time. good as can be. He is better nights than when you were here - his two little white teeth peep out cunningly when he laughs. He says "mam, mam," a good deal, and once or twice "pap, pap." I have made his little flannel dresses & got them on - look very pretty. I button holed them, top, bottom ^ sleeves - 'tis but little work - only think he will be six months old tomorrow. I am glad to hear such smart accounts from little Mary. I want to see her. Tell Charles & Albina they must think of nothing else, but coming down here this winter. I had letters from Isaac yesterday, & from Almeda few days since. You have probably heard from her before now that she does not go to Du Quoin, am so sorry & grieve for Isaac's Mother. How disappointed they will be. You must write part of every letter at least so that I can show it. Maria has a spark of women's curiosity amounting almost to a live coal & she want to see the letters - she is sincerely good & kind I think.

   The big ship did'nt launch that day - they tried

[left-hand side and top] sweetly calm, patient & happy. Mr. C. is very miserable with hypo. I am glad Albina likes her dress.  Lizzie is very anxious to go home as soon as the team does. I am inclined to think she had better. I fear so much confinement to her book will injure her eyes. It seems to me they are tired more of the time than they used to be. Do write often to your Affec. daughter, Lucy.

Bangor Nov. 10 1853

                                                                                                  Bangor Nov.10 - 1853

Dear Mother

                          I will write a bit to you this morning, not because I owe a letter but because I so much want to get one from you. It is cold and windy, though bright and sunny. Samuel is at the mill, Lizzie at school, the darling Percie asleep, Isabel chopping mince meat and John Sheady banking the house. By the way, the last named person seems to be very clever and bright, is fifteen years old, came from Ireland three years ago, father dead, supports his mother who lives in Brewer and is unable to work much herself. He has been to school, can read & has studied arithmetic some. Such an one if willing to go there, would he just what Charles needs on the farm, but I suppose most prefer to job about the city somewhere. He will probably be here, hoeing, digging onions, sawing

wood etc. about a month. Lizzie gets along finely in her studies, but I am satisfied it is not best for her to continue here studying another term now. She gets nervous & run down studying. I let her stay at home half a day or a day quite often now - she would graduate this term if she should stay.

             We had a letter from Anna a few days since, also the same day, by mail a double daguerreotype, herself and Mr. Elijah de Witt. I am in coniptions to send it to you, but suppose it is not worth while to pay 24 cents more for postage on it. Samuel will probably go to Milo before a great while. Letter from Isaac to Eliab yesterday urging him, and particularly Charles, to come immediately out there. I presume Charles has, ere this received one to the same effect.  If he concludes so to do, he must get Mr Sargent to take care of house, and barn. Albina must board at her father's, or else come down here, and you, of course, post forthwith to Bangor. Eliab and Maria

had just about decided to go to Illinois for the winter before this last letter came. I really begin to fear that they will go. Of course I want them to if it is best for them, but it will seem lonesome without them. E. feels somewhat discouraged, I imagine - thunks he has not done very well in his business this year. I imagine it would be hard times for Maria out there, but Samuel says it would be good for her. She does not want to go, but says Eliab shall not got alone. If they go it will certainly be your bounden duty (and comfort, I hope) to come here, won't it? Just think - Samuel gone, and Isabel and I all alone here with baby. I shall "make a wish" with baby in my arms, for Milo, if you don't. 
What shall be done with Jane? 'Tis my constant worryment - I guess the folks had better take her out to Illinois. Issac thinks so well of her had'nt he better bring her up the rest of the way? We have most all tried our hand at it except him. Baby sits

alone in good earnest. He is just as good natured from morning till night, as can be. He laughs prolonged ha, ha's when we play with him; is so fond of a frolic as you please. His flannel dresses are very becoming to him. Has no more teeth yet. Eliab & Maria are coming to Thanksgiving. Mr. & Mrs. de Witt have an invitation too. We should also be most happy to have Mrs. Metcalf and Mr. & Mrs. Rich join the party. Have not heard from Margaret Crosby for some days.. I have got a new de laine dress, mot half so pretty as Albina's - Like it less and less after making up. I have trimmed my summer straw bonnet with my old velvet bonnet - it looks finely. Maria is going to get a ladies' cloth for cloak, as she could not pattern her velvet & could'nt find broadcloth of the right shade - she is very particular. If they go to Illinois she will hardly need any. What a letter I have written all about nothing, & in no time, almost.

                                            Affectionately - daughter Lucy.

Bangor Nov. 21 - 1853

Dear Mother 

                     large X across words from "The refuse sheet to "gone to Old Town." The refuse sheet must go to somebody, and I am naughty enough to send it to you. It is early - six o'clock - baby sleeps and so does Lissie. We have eaten breakfast and Isabel is washing the dishes: Samuel has "gone to Old Town" - so I have a few moments before it is light to write a little. Two good letters from you have arrived in town lately  - one to Eliab & one to me. I had written to you just before receiving yours. In regard to this great hubbub and ado about Charles and Eliab going to Illinois - I don't know, I am sure - Issac wrote urgently to E. to have him persuade Charles to go. Maria said it was naughty and Eliab should have nothing to do with persuading him away from his family. I can hardly see how Milo in general, and Cedar Grove in particular, will get along, survive and prosper without

his presence. I presume the journey & the getting out into the world would be a benefit and a pleasure to him, but whether the pecuniary benefit alone, would be a sufficient inducement, and compensation for the evils of various kinds necessarily attendant on his absence from home, I am not so clear. I suppose Isaac yearns to see some of his kindred, and would do anything in season, or out of it, to get them there with him. Charles of course knows best about it. If he only won't get the ague, or some other western fever which will trouble him after he comes back, I won't object! What does Albina think of it? If he should go, what would the family do; remain in status quo, or scatter? Let us know in season to provide in some way for Jane. E. and Maria have talked considerably about going, but I think are rather getting off the notion now. She don't want to go, and it would really be a most tedious & fatiguing journey there at this season, & equally so returning in the spring. I think if he goes, she had much

better remain here or at Easthampton. She seems to be anticipating a good deal of comfort boarding here this winter. I hope she will find it, but fear she will be disappointed, They spent Thanksgiving here. Several other fraternal individuals were invited, besides one maternal person, but they made not their appearance.  

    We have had two or three short, hasty letters from Anna, and last week Mallie has two little sheets, & half another, full. She seems full of care and business. I shall give her a hint on the "grovelling" use of the "muckrake."  I imagine she will be as intent on her household cares as ever I was. She seem to delight much in her petit daughter. The reason they did not go to Du Quoin was that Mr. de Witt lost his valise & had not changes of raiment, but I thought within myself that he might have purchased more already made and proceeded on his way. She seems very happy indeed, and I hope she may be so always. Lizzie Thaxter had had two or three attacks of bleeding at the lungs - is now sick at her sister's,

Bangor Nov. 21. 1853

in Glenburn. It is hard for them both. I have not seen her since you were here I expect constantly to hear that Margaret is freed from earth. We have been down several times lately. I wonder she has lived so long - a constant diarrhea, attended with much pain, for three or four weeks, dyspepsia so that every mouthful, even of water, distresses her; and in addition, the gravel and the piles - constant coughing & raising, while her throat, mouth and lips are so sore they often bleed. She has suffered exceedingly, but is so patient, and thankful for everything that is done for her - wonders why people are so kind to her. Her father is very unreconciled. He moves her when she needs to be moved, and he sees her so wasted, it is very hard for him to bear it. I never saw a person so emaciated. She was very anxious to have me cut off her hair, but I did not go down for some days, & her mother did it - I was glad. Mrs. C. says they talk together of her death with perfect freedom & precisely as if she was going on a journey. Margaret says "We will

Bangor Nov. 21 1853                                                                                                                                                                           5
take comfort while we are together, Ma."

    We have not yet for into the meeting house. The weather is so damp, the paint does not dry very well. Prof. Shepard and his wife called here last week. I inquired something about the meeting  house - he shook his head and said he knew nothing about it - his wife laughed and said they had never been able to get him near it since the accident. He said he did not want to see it. Lissie Page has petitioned for a seat in our pew - she wants to go to that meeting. I have not for my cloak or dress made yet, thought my dress is fitted ready to make. Well, 'tis broad light, & I must hasten myself. Percie has not yet waked - he is a charming good boy at all times & seasons. If I am away in the evening, and he wakes, he never cries - he is as earnest a little fellow as you please - has not got his third tooth, yet! I think he will creep before long. How he does scream, spring, laugh and crow when he sees Samuel coming. We had a letter from Ellen Brown last week with check

6
and a commission to purchase a sofa for her.
Monday evening - 21st Margaret has gone - she died very peacefully and easily yesterday afternoon. Samuel has been down there today. The funeral is to be tomorrow - we shall try to get though the travelling is extremely bad, She retained her consciousness to the last moments tried to kiss her mother after she was quite cold.

  We have just has letters from Isaac - he was keeping house the day he wrote, with a cold; kind of Neuralgia in the back of his neck and head. Eliab took a letter from the Office this morning from him to you, which will be enclosed in this if Samuel can see him tomorrow & get it; otherwise he will forward it soon. Why does not Nettie gain strength Isaac thinks it is nourishing the baby. If so, had she not better wean it? They say it sits alone a little- Percie learned himself. I never took any pains with him - had always let him sit : in his carriage, till, one

7
morning I chanced to put him on the floor and there he remained most half the forenoon in an upright position. He is remarkably stiff in his hop joints now always when we put him down. Lissie says he has the rheumatism! She is nice & well now. I felt some concerned about her for a while after you came away, but she is very well now. I really don't know what to think about her staying. I have written all the pros & cons to Almeda. Almeda's letters seem very sad.
              You recollect Henry Ward Beecher's funny statement in the Independent, about his private affairs - letting his farm to his brother in law etc. etc. and volunteering to give any other information if wanted - recently there has been a short letter published stating that a certain man was very anxious, & his wife no less so, to ascertain if the brother in law he spoke of was his wife's brother or his sister's husband? He replied in a few words, "I married his sister seventeen years ago & have been glad of it ever since." Samuel saw a man

8

the other day who says Beecher certainly did repeat two or three times one hot morning in his pulpit, as was stated, the words "It is d-d hot this morning;" - but - then went on & said "these words I heard repeated eighteen times on my way to church this morning, by persons calling themselves gentlemen, many of whom are now in this house, etc. etc. "proceeding to give them a faithful lecture on propriety. Such things will do only for Henry Ward Beecher, and I doubt if he does not do more hurt than good by them - they will be garbled by repetition.

     We have exchanged baby's carriage for a larger one with rockers & wheels both. I find a cradle a great convenience. Well 'tis after nine. Samuel is snorting in the rocking chair, baby begins to stretch & make wakeful demonstrations & I must stop - how fast I have written, my writing will testify. Love to all - do write often.
                                                                                                                                                                                          to daughter Lucy.

Thurs. P.M.

Dear Sister Mrs. Hopkin's letter just arrived. I hasten to write a word to put with it before Sam'l goes that it may go by tomorrow's mail. Eliab (Esq. Metcalf) opened it. What in the world does Mrs. Hopkins want of you - will try to get gingham in a day or two for Mother. Samuel's waggon is broken - has to send away off for an axletree, so I don't ride much for a day or two. It is very hot & dry - we want to go to Milo. We expect Theodore & Sarah this week.  E. and Mr. almost concluded to go to Milo today and take you by surprise. Be'nt you all glad they did'nt? I rode over yester morning & spent an hour with Maria & saw all her pretty things, of which there are man. Hattie brought some more when she came, & an elegant toilet
[top] We have not heard from Isaac  for a long time last letter dated 13 - June - do you hear?

[left side] August '53
cushion received a day or two since which has lain in the express office here since the first of May - a wedding present not done in season & forwarded afterwards - much handsomer than the other. Baby prospers finely -weighs a little more than 14 lbs. yesterday. Is just as good as a baby can be - lies & crows & meditates half or three quarters of an hour frequently - sleeps a nap. I nurse him and lay him down till he is hungry and sleepy again - but he is by no mean a dumpish fellow -loves to frolic & play dearly. I think he knows his father. Wish I could help you a lot about all your matters, but my head & eyes trouble me constantly. I have now pills for one & am going to have salve for the other. In haste & love- Lucy.

Bangor Dec. 4, 1853

                                                                                                                                                        Bangor Dec. 4 - 1853

Dear Mother and Sister

                     It is Sabbath evening, and I write in haste because we thought it desirable  that you should get a letter by tomorrow's mail. You will be surprised to learn that Charles is yet in Bangor. Mr. Livermore probably told you all about the river being frozen, the uncertainty about the boats, and that C. had just left in the Waterville stage.
                     It was extremely bad going - many passengers, - they had two carraiges, Gilman in one, C. in the other  - had proceeded but a few miles (to Newburg, eight miles from Hampden,) when the stage in which C. was, broke the axle; consequently the passengers were obliged to walk awhile which detained them some, thus allowing the other stage, which Mr. Gilman started in, to overtake them, - when Charles learned

that Mr. G. had been taken with violent cholic and left in a tavern two miles back. Of course Charles let the stage go on and went back to take care of him. This was Thursday night, you recollect. Mr. G. was quite unwell when they started - really not fit to go had had no passage of the bowels then for four days, continued to grown sicker - no medicine had any effect - sent for a physician, who gave powerful medicine to no purpose. He died this morning a little before four o'clock. Charles was with him ll the time - up most of the time for three nights- wrote to us once to tell us where he was etc. Eliab and Mr. Caulkins started this morning at Charles' request, to go to Newburg, met C. on the way coming up here, hired a man to bring him - he has slept all the afternoon - is now talking & making arrangements with Mr. Caulkin, Samuel & Eliab about going after his remains. We have had a broken sabbath. Charles think his cold is better. Eliab had some cough candy which helped him. He will

probably stay here a day or two to get recruited and rested. O! how sad for Mr. Gilman's poor children! How we should all be Thankful that Charles, our dear Charles, is spared. But for God's Sparing mercy, he might have been taken & this heavy sorrow have been for us. I shall try to write often. Be comforted, Albina about Charles' being away - you know I can sympathize with you a little. I will send you a pretty and good piece of poetry that I found the other day, next time I write. Do write often, and make haste, Mother, to be ready to come down and stay here. Charles will write before he leaves here. E. and M. came here to board last week.

                                                                    In haste and love
                                                                              Lucy.

Elbridge Rider, Charles, E. and M. and Miss Pease two days making our cloak, all happened along here at the same time, so I had not a moment to write by Mr. Livermore, only to put together the bundle as hastily as possible- if I forget anything write to me of it.

Bangor Dec. 1853
nicely rested before he went - he almost decided to go monday night in the stage, but finally waited till tuesday morn & was well he did, for the stage broke down monday night & injured some of the passengers. I want to hear all about Mr. Gilman's children. Am greatly obliged for the playthings Charlie sent. Percie likes them much. If I get it done in season, I will send him and Josie something in return. Mallie is going to write some. Eliab has a comforter on his knee. I want Albina 
Dear Mother

                   Your letter I received last evening one hour or two before Samuel came home. How did you get such a cold? That "great washing" is the secret of it, I know. I do think Mother,  that you wrong yourself and trouble your children by so doing, to make haste and make a good visit at Brownville and then come down here so that I can take care of you and keep you from washing. I expect Albina tries her best, but can do no good.

[left-hand side] love to Albina - tell her I shall write to her very soon. Aff.- Lucy.

to be persuaded to take care of yourself. I wish I knew what to send that would do you any good. If you are getting over your sickness, you do not need medicine so much as tonics & rest. I have made some cinnamon cordial, the only thing I could think of. The gum arabic will be good for soreness in throat and stomach & the spirit a little tonic. Also a few figs, which you can simmer in the cordial if you like. Prof. Shepard is quite sick with Pleurisy fever - taken suddenly last Saturday night. Has watchers. Charles got

same first half as two letters previous
Bangor Dec. 1853
nicely rested before he went - he almost decided to go monday night in the stage, but finally waited till tuesday morn & was well he did, for the stage broke down monday night & injured some of the passengers. I want to hear all about Mr. Gilman's children. Am greatly obliged for the playthings Charlie sent. Percie likes them much. If I get it done in season, I will send him and Josie something in return. Mallie is going to write some. Eliab has a comforter on his knee. I want Albina new part from here on should plan in some way so that she might leave part of the children with her mother, or get one of the girls to stay there, and bring part with her, when come down with Samuel sometime. It is such a capital chance to go back & forth, we ought to improve it. I want to see little Mary very much. Charles said Percie was the heaviest the moment he took him. He seemed to take a good deal of comfort hugging & kissing him - because he could not get at his own. I

suppose! Mallie and I have really been very much hurried for two or three weeks  - did you ever hear of me when I was not? Our cloaks and dresses were quite an undertaking -especially mine with baby to take care of - then the church carpets have taken her time and strength, as well as many others'. Baby was quite sick a few days last week as Samuel probably told you. I did not know anything what to do for him - we were up some with him two nights - the first time since I first came down stairs. I am just going about shortening his dresses. It seems too bad to cut his pretty flannels off. What splendid weather we have. I have not heard from Anna nor Isaac very recently - have been so busy I could not find time to write to them. Charles had not decided whether he should go to Elyria. Tell Almeda that Lizzie seems to think she wants to go home very much, but is willing to wait till sleighing so her mother can come after her. Do set? Almeda about making a lounge while you are there, and do be ready to come to Bangor soon - make Almeda a good visit first- much
[left-hand side] Every thing is high. I could find no linsay worth buying for less than .25, but thought it would last as long as two uninspiring calicos & save washing & making one.
[top upside down] Could'nt get my things ready for the children & will send them next time.

Bangor Feb. 15 - 1854.

Dear Mother

                           Samuel is at the desk, so I will begin writing in my lap. Percie is asleep and I must improve my opportunity. He has been pretty goodnatured, but until yesterday has seemed very much stuffed with phelgm, and hoarse by spells, so that I have not dared to put him down. Sabbath day we put a bandage on his neck & gave him some of his medicine, fearing the croup. I think if I am careful now he will get entirely over it. You say I am too careful, but just as sure as I try to be careless a bit, he takes cold. He had grown poor. The cow came lat night. I hope he will thrive on good new milk. Though for several days he has not taken any  - won't swallow a bit of any kind of food, but is very tenacious of titty! The cow gives a nice mess of milk. Mr. Jordan will take the mornings' milk every day and allow five cents a quart, which is better than we expected to do with it. He has taken back the little cans too. I wish you would send the milk quart next time Samuel comes. The eggs were very acceptable, but Isabel put them in with the others before I had counted them. I had a nice long letter of four pages from Charles

[left-hand side and top] going will give some offence; but if we begin where can we end? Eliab is anxious that we should go, on account of the recent troubles:but would this justify us, if we disapprove of parties? Dinner is almost ready, and I wish you could have some of our tongues and sounds--they are so good. Augusta Bartlett and Mary Crosby called here a few evenings since. We some expect Mrs. Crosby to spend a day with us this week. We are at quite a loss to know what to do about inviting Mr. Harlow's family here now that you have left. Of course Mr. Harlow would not enjoy it at all. Shall we wait till you return? Love to all - Good bye, Your loving daughter - Maria.

two or three days since, all to myself. I intend to answer it very soon. I hope? Nettie & baby are better.

   It is a church fast today - a meeting this afternoon. It seems so good to have Samuel at home a few days. You can't think. Did you mean to leave your Alapine dress- I saw it hanging in the dark clothes soon. I really don't dare to think how lonely & miserable I do by night, all alone with baby. I have worried about you, lest you should get entirely sick going home, being weary when you started & getting wearied again there; Besides, Eliab said you had a cold. I was drefful sorry you did not get any tongues & sounds and brown bread, - will send some to pay for it.
