I have finished Lizzie's stocking & Maria & I together have got the sewing circle stockings about half done. Mr. Tebbets came up and staid all night - was ever so good. Mr. Robert Haskins died last Saturday. E. and M. went to the funeral Monday - a carraige to Mount Hope was provided for them. Mr. H. bequeathed a;; his public documents, such as surveys of Minn. & Utah territories, etc. to Eliab! About 25 bound volumes I believe. Quite a show in a library, though not of much real value to Eliab.
               Eliab and Maria are invited to a big party

Bangor Feb. 15 1854
at Walter Brown's tomorrow evening - are not going. M. says it is against her principles to attend parties & she will not begin. Mrs. Martin and Ada were in here most all the afternoon Monday. The child is almost three years old. Her Mother would tell her to do something, then coax her, & when she would not do it. say right before her, "children will always do as they have a mind to." A fine specimen of parental authority in these days. Charlie Hodgkins came with the cow - he says Mr. & Mrs. Sargent are both worse, and Josie better. I hope we shall get a letter from you today noon. I fear a fever will go hard with Mr. Sargent, he has been so much out of health before. Eliab received a letter from Uncle Peletiah yesterday, which I will send.

       Fen. 16 - P.M. I finish this to send by tomorrow's mail instead of waiting to send by Samuel, as I suppose you will be anxious to hear from us. Percie has just gone to sleep. He seems pretty well, but his croupiness is apt to come on unless I am very careful of him. I have written a long letter to Charles and Maria has actually indited and sent the long talked of letter to Anna today. We hear that Mr. Brown's folks have sent out five hundred invitations for this evening. As you have gone there I can't see any possible reason why Albina can't

come down with Samuel.If you don't conclude to come back yourself, I really think you ought to. Give much love to Mr. & Mrs. Sargent. I wish I could do anything for them. Mr. Brown proposed to Samuel to be City Marshall today - Dear me! I would'nt have him for anything if I could help it. The stage from Milo here just gone down. I hope Samuel will bring back a letter from you when he goes to carry this. I wish Albina would write too. She is in debt to me one long letter certainly. I want to hear about your cold. Why did you not keep the socks if you haven't any? How very precise & business like Maria's writing looks below compared with mine. We shall probably let Mr. Jordan have about six qts of milk per day. That will help pay the cow's keeping finely - good bye 

                                                                                                                                     With much love
                                                                                                                                      daughter- Lucy.

Dear Mother

                     By permission I have stolen a little corner of Lucy's sheet, to tell you how lonely we all feel since you left. There is an aching void, and how shall it be filled? I was quite amused with Eliab, as we sat down to tea after he and Samuel came on Saturday, why, where is Mother? he said, without once thinking that he was the very one who carried you away from us. We are still hoping that you will come soon and finish out the visit you had only commenced. Do you think I need feel under any obligation to attend dancing parties? Perhaps our not

Bangor Feb. 23 , 1854

                                                                                                                 Bangot Feb. 23 - 1854

Dear Mother

                  Eliab is waiting to go down town, so I can only stop to say a few words. He just brought up a letter from Charles, which I suppose you will want to see, as I should not probably write today - Your letter to Eliab, received yesterday did us much good, and made us feel bad some too, fearing you are low-spirited. Don't let James and Jane trouble you. I am grieved about them both. I think Sam'l had better make every effort to find a place for Jane. I had a letter from Ann a few days since which I will enclose, also a few envelopes enough to last till Samuel goes up again, when I will send more. Eliab got them for you. We expected Mrs. Palmer to spend the day yesterday, but instead, Mr. & Mrs. Crosby came to dine and Julia Parker to spend the afternoon, all unexpectedly - Julia is a very pleasant girl - good, rather loquacious like her Mother, but the good sense of her father to go with her loquacity. Don't we enjoy our cow? Dr. Paine gave me medicine to relieve Percie's bowels & make his teething easier - has a very sensible & immediate effect - he took a little cold yesterday - the change of air going into the parlor, and a storm coming on too. Eliab is hurrying me so I cannot

tell what I want to write. Am sorry Mary is so troublesome. My love and sympathy to Mr. and Mrs. Sargent. Do write & ask Albina to write too.

                                                                                In great haste.
                                                                                                       Daughter Lucy.

Eliab and Maria will write soon - they say "you speak on your own responsibility," but I guess they will - good bye.

Bangor March 5 54   Lucy March 54

                                                                                                                                         Bangor March 6 - 1854

Dear Mother

                                I did intend to write you a long letter, to send by Samuel, but the time has sped away - it is five o'clock and Samuel starts tomorrow morning. I have been unusually hurried (and that is saying a good deal, you know) for a few days, as Samuel bought a whole pig, which gave me some work to do, and as Isabel was going with Samuel, I wanted to get done last week Then Friday Lizzie Thaxter came to spend the day - her husband to tea: besides my usual work & baby - Percie is somewhat troublesome, crying for me nowadays. If I leave the room a moment, he is almost sure to cry; I carry him with me frequently because he will cry if I leave him. He is getting to feed nicely now - that is, he drinks new milk twice a day, and nibbles a crust of bread occasionally. He would eat a good deal if we carried him to the table. Mallie and I are just beginning the "Shepard shirts." She is also working some little slippers for the "Corban." I called at Mrs. Thaxter's with Percie a few days since. She had a fine little boy (William Hooper) two months old - ever so much black hair. She took Chloroform

and get along beautifully. She seems domestic and happy as need be. O hardly know what we are going to do while Isabel is gone. I can hardly get along some days now; however, I presume we shall manage some way. Eliab will not come home to dinner much.

        I think you must all have had a hard time at Milo- all sick together. I want very much to hear how your cold is and how the children are. I should think Albina would be almost worn out. I am in a great hurry - baby is worrying - Mallie will write some - i suppose Samuel will tell you the news and how many wonderful things Percie can do. We had letters from Isaac & Nettie a few days since - no special news. In haste, with much love to Albina and all.
                                                                                                                                                         Lucy.

Father, John and Bell are all going to be married, before long - Father to a widow lady residing at St. Paul, forty five years old.

Bangor March 15 1854  Lucy March 1854

                                                                                                                                                             Bangor March 15 - 1854.

Dear Mother

                                 It is eight o'clock in the evening. Percie has just gone to sleep. Elia and Mallie are seated on either side the Bagatelle before the fire; the former reading a newspaper, the latter finishing off the "Corban" work, which has been a sad eye-sore and drug this long time. We hope to commence the "Shepard shirts,"(that is cutting them out) tomorrow. Percie had been rather troublesome days and restless nights lately - his sixth tooth is just coming through. I only nursed him twelve times last night. He is good only when I know his teeth pain him; but he is just learning to stand and requires a good deal of attention, as you know. He has not had a bad bump yet, though he fell out of the cradle this morning. I was sitting close by it, and he fell partly on me. We have both had a pretty hard time since Isabel went away. There was a good deal to do of fixing up fresh meat etc. (more than I expected when Isabel went away, because of the continued warm weather) and myself being perhaps a little too anxious to get it all done immediately, (which, however, was rather necessary) I "overdid," and consequently got partially "overrot" ; so that Mallie has taken almost the whole charge for several days. My complaint has troubled me more than for many months before. I feared for a

day or two that I should have to give entirely up and send for somebody to take care of the baby, but am very much better today. Mallie had tripped round the house, taking care of every thing, even to making brine to put on the pork barrel etc. etc. She'll make quite a notable little housekeeper. We came very near losing some of our fresh meat, but by corning the fattest spare-ribs and laboring dilligently at the table, we managed to save it all. I have made sausages and brawn.

             Well, I guess you will conclude that I think of nothing but I. We have all thought and talked much of you all at Milo and wondered why we have not heard more and oftener from you. Your last letter told us you were all about sick, but all getting better. I wish you would write oftener some of you. I wrote last evening to Anna and to Isaac. Ought to write to Father Furber - a congratulatory letter, but think I will wait till Samuel comes home to help me. He was married the sixth of last month to a widow lady of St. Paul, a Mrs. Ford, aged 45. I had a short bit of a dear letter from Samuel yesterday. I did expect him home by this time, but he writes that he cannot be here before Saturday. I have written to him to bring Isabel without fail. I suppose was wild to let her go without having some body else to stay while she was gone; but don't tell Mrs. Sargent so; I don't want her to get to thinking that she is necessary

to me, though in truth, she is a most excellent girl, and I am only afraid she will not stay so long as I want her. Eliab and Maria were invited to tea and spend the evening at Mr. Harlow's last week, to meet Mr. & Mrs. Charles Thaxter, Mr. & Mrs. Wakefield, Mrs. Blood, Mr. & Mrs. Thatcher etc. etc. - quite a party of people. I got Nancy Raynes to stay with me meanwhile. Lucy Stone has been creating quite an excitement here by her lectures. There is a number; the first, "The appropriate sphere of woman;"second, "legal rights of women"; third "slavery". People generally were pleased, particularly with the first. Crowded houses; they said she really talked like a sensible woman - her manner graceful and quiet, voice clear, full, and pleasant, and dress appropriate & simple - partially bloomer. I have written to Isaac about it. We wanted much to hear her, but I could not, of course, and it was not convenient for E. and M.

            Eliab goes to a great many Temperance meetings-- too many for his health, I tell him, and consequently too many for his duty. Perhaps I am not a competent judge, however. Since Samuel went away there has come an invitation for him, "with ladies," to attend a "military and civic ball at the Bangor house", to be held sometime soon; four dollars a ticket. He paid five dollars for the military company, which

judging for present appearances, I fear he will regret doing, but I don't know. The last lecture of the Mercantile course is to be tomorrow evening by Dr. O.W. Holmes. Would'nt I like to hear it? There have been prayer meetings ever Wednes. afternoon for two or three weeks in our vestry - very interesting. I went once with Samuel when he was at home last - have not been to a prayer meeting before since long before I was sick at Hampden. I had rather go any time than to hear a sermon on the sabbath. The bell is ringing for nine - I have been interrupted once to take Percie up and get him to sleep since I commenced writing. Eliab ad Mallie are both on the lounge, "heads and points," one or both of them snoring. Percie begins to need governing considerable. He acts so roguish & cunning about his disobedience and mischief that Mallie laughs & that makes me sometimes. Are you going to Brownville again before sleighing is gone? I should think you would if you don't come to Bangor, which we awfully want you should do, only dare not ask you! How did you like your cheese? Why don't Albina write to me? I have written this drefful quick & must stop - a loving good night to you

                                                                                                                                                        daughter Lucy.

Bangor March 27 18534 Lucy March 1854

                                                                                                                                                  Bangor, March 27 - 1854

My dear Mother

                   It is monday evening.Samuel has gone down street. Mallie is on the lounge, Percie sleeping in the cradle by my side, Isabel in the kitchen cutting our apple; Eliab is away: of his precise whereabouts at present we are not informed - (just here Mallie laughed so nervously loud that baby woke up: it is now five minutes of nine, so I fear my letter will not be very long.) Mallie had a letter from him today, which but for the severe storm, which detained the mail, would have arrived some days since - that was dated in Boston; he was going to leave immediately for New Haven and Bridgeport, Conn. on business - he has had an offer of a very good situation at Ne Haven recently; Samuel is hoping that he will not engage himself any where positively before he returns, as there is an excellent opportunity for them to go into business together here. Samuel will tell you all about it. We expect Eliab home now every day.  I suppose you expected a letter from some of us last week. I thought, until Thursday night, that Samuel would go to Milo friday, and waited to write by hum, then he thought of going today & has now concluded to go tomorrow. We are getting along about as usual. baby is good, but has a bad cold now. I have had a cold all winter,

[left-hand side] Will you please send me by Samuel your Abbott's "Young Churchman". I want very much to have Isabel read it. Samuel will tell you how Percie begins to talk.

and lately my complaint troubles me more than before since baby was three or four weeks old. I shall not begin to wean him till Samuel is all through in the woods., so that he can help me nights.  Mallie gets along pretty well, only she is nervous and sometimes has the "high sterics". I wish you were here, or somebody else that knows what to do with her; I am sure I don't. She went to meeting all day yesterday and got too tired. I went, for  wonder, last evening, to hear Prof. Shepard lecture - his subject, the skepticism & infidelity of the times & evidences of the truths of the Bible. I wish I could remember & had time to write you a whole parcel of it. He said there was something merely absurd and ridiculous in the idea of a creature who had just crawled out of nonentity, and the pins of whose swaddling bands had hardly been laid aside, looking up and asking, "Is this Bible time?" You can imagine his look & answer. He said that infidels nowadays did not go to the Bible for their objections, but to the same state, vile compost heap where people had gone for ages; They went straight by the pure and holy book, shuffling, as they went, to discover some foul morsel, and peering about in the darkness till they found a little congenial carrion etc. etc. He made a "clean sweep," as the saying is, of Naturalism,

Pantheism, Spiritualism, Infidelity and all the rest classed them all together. It is said that Spiritualism is gaining ground very fast, though people are more silent than heretofore. Mallie sent Ann Page a sewing bird one day, which brought her up here, as we expected, not long after, but she said nothing of Spiritualism to us. Mr. Battles attend the circles as they call them.Mr Packard has preached half the day at our church for several sabbaths, I have not heard him yet. People like him very well; think him quite an original. Lizzie Thaxter came in this afternoon a little while - unbosomed herself freely. Her trials are hard to be borne as regards Mrs. Webster and her family. Then she is constantly and deeply anxious in regard to her husband. He was for a long time skeptical, you know, but has for months, as she think, been a sincere and earnest seeker after the truth and is yet in darkness. He is at time very much distressed, & all his old doubt come over him again. His anxiety at times affect his spirits & health, so that he has no appetite for food. Her boarding place is in many respects unpleasant. Mrs. Webster has been at Boston two months, away from her family, learning to use a sewing machine, whereby to pretend to earn her own living. Lizzie has had to attend to her house every day, and

has now, to save trouble, taken up her abode there to remain till Mrs.W. returns. She is a strange, selfish, heartless woman- Lizzie is convinced now that her real character is precisely what Anna and I always told her it was.  Thaxter is a fine, noble-hearted fellow, I pity  him and Lizzie too. My sympathies are really roused for them & my indignation equally so toward Mrs. Webster.I never saw Lizzie feel so miserable as today. Abby Thaxter spent the day here last week, the same sweet, lovely girl. I know of none anywhere who will compare with her. I called and spent an hour with Percie at Mrs. Thaxter's when Samuel was at home before. Miss Blaizdill worked here two days last week, dressmaking, for Mallie & me. It is almost ten. Mallie and Isabel have gone to bed, my fire has gone to sleep, Samuel has not yet arrived - my feet are cold, eye aching & will stop. The Gum Arabic will make a quart of cordial. I should think; sugar & cinnamon to suit your taste, & wine or brandy enough to keep it & take off the flat taste. I am taking it for my benefit, have also one of Aunt Conant's plasters, which I think is beneficial. Please write often and particularly about everything, especially your own health. With much love - Your affectionate daughter Lucy.

Bangor Apr. 8 - 1854

Dear Mother

                I have intended for some days to write to you, but kept delaying so as to write the decisions of the husbands in regard to business.
                Eliab wrote a few lines hastily the other evening because baby would not let me as I intended - he has had several excellent situations offered him lately, particularly those at N. Haven and Pottsdam, N. York, but as this also seemed favorable, Samuel rather desired it and it was Mallie's choice, he decided to remain here. I suppose it is rather a large trade for them, but they hope to get along comfortably with it. Eliab is going to Boston again Monday to purchase goods. He had just got out business cards, hired a stove & wharf and put up a big sign as a shingle dealer. Our neighbor, Mr. Martin is out of a clerkship and they think some of employing him. Eliab & especially Mallie, want very much to keep house, & as Eliab considers himself located

[left-hand side and top] day or two since, desiring him to find her a school - would prefer an annual one - he spoke to the Committee here, but there were no vacancies - I suppose wages are higher here than there, then a "prospect is not without honor," you know. Rebecca Raynes (the dress maker was married a few days since by the city clerk at four o'clock P.M.. Her husband took tea with her & at seven the same evening started for the west to be gone several weeks. How did you succeed in making your cinnamon cordial? How is Mr. Sargent and would not that be good for him? Tell Albina Bell Furber is to be married the middle of this month. What is the conclusion about

now, I see no objection to it.I should not be surprised if he yet traded with Mr. Tebbett. He says with this business the distance would not be so great an objection as when standing about all day looking for shingles. If they do keep house, the sisters at home will break up immediately. Mallie will have "lots of things" from there of every description, to keep house with, & Mary will come and stay with her. Samuel will see the house - hay and grain are so high the expense will be great - he will not have much use for it & the labor of keeping horse, carriage & harness clean as they must be here is not a little - he says he would rather walk usually & hire a horse when necessary than to do it. This is a dear pretty creature & I hate to have it go. Mallie is asleep on the lounge, Percie taking his afternoon nap in the cradle, Isabel up stairs and the fire most out. I have written to Anna today and intend to write to Charles if I have time. I devoted the day to writing letters, that is so much of it as Percie could spare. He improves very fast, both in
[left-hand side] Jane? Is she going to Almeda's? Does she want Lissie to come here? If she does, she would have to go to private school - the school she would belong is too far for her to walk. Do please write often. - And ask Almeda to also.

knowledge and strength tries to do everything he sees us do, - is drefful roguish & cunning about pulling off his shoes & doing other forbidden acts. he tries to say Mother, birdie, and drop when he drops his playthings. He walks by things all about & has not had one bad bump yet. I did not encourage him to stand till he began of his own accord to pull himself up - I think he is all the stronger for it. He requires a great many steps & a good deal of strength. I have been quite miserable lately with my old ailments -. If I do not feel better before many days, I shall send and get a nurse to take all the care of baby & wait upon me so that I can keep entirely still & have a chance to get well. I have been as bad as I ever was, only with more health and strength, in general. to keep me up. Lifting Percie so much keeps me from getting over it. However, I have fixed me some cordial & bathe faithfully in cold water. I am in hopes to get over it before long. I have got the trunk ready to send, but the going is so bad Samuel thinks Mr. Gould will not be down again at present.
[left-hand side] I want to write to Albina, and Almeda too, but have not time today. Percie has waked & is calling me - good bye - Affectionately - Lucy.

Lucy April 1854
Shall I send the trunk by stage or wait for some other opportunity? I began to take out Anna's things, as I supposed you did not want them sent, but could not tell what to send & what to leave, so I left them all in - have put in my skirt and quilt - if it is perfectly convenient I should like them quilted, but it is not a bit of matter. I can get them done in the course of the summer here. I have sent you one Independent, for you to read "That old Primer" piece. I don't know where the others came from I am sure. would you like to have the Miss. Herald sent? I want to send you a Colonization Society Report. I imagine you all had a pretty serious time in the big snow storms - what a quantity of snow we have had. The ground is beginning to look quite bare here, except some large drifts. We had letters from Charles and Nettie lately. Isaac was at St. Louis. Mallie's brother Spencer is very sick. She fears every day to hear that he is worse. What do you think of Charles staying till June? Can he get a good man at Milo? Eliab had a very pretty letter from Ardelia Dickinson a 
[left-hand side] Percie will kiss my check quite cunningly - he sends one to grandmother. I guess - gave me one when I told him about it,

Bangor April 18 1854 Lucy April '54 

                                                                                                                                                          Bangor Apr. 18 -1854

Dear Mother

                            It is Eliab's birth day, as perhaps you recollect.Samuel thinks of going to Milo tomorrow so I will write a bit to send by him. The enclosed biddy piece please return by him. The book I promised to Charlie last winter as soon as he could read. I would keep it as a kind of reward & let him read & see the pictures when he has been good. I think there are some very sweet little hymns for a child to learn. The tamarind stories will perhaps please the children. Mallie feels a little hurt, I fear, because you have not written to her particularly, especially as she sent the figs & helped send the collar! She told Eliab she was afraid you were offended with her, but you mustn't say a word as if I had mentioned it to you: only write her soon. She feels particular about such things you know. They are just deciding to buy the Tebbets house. Mallie will write you about it. If they go to keeping house, the family at Easthampton will break up immediately, so that Mallie can have things from there, and Mary will make her permanent home in Bangor.I guess she will have a good many things from there, nice ones too. We have had letters from Anna and Isaac lately, & presume you have also. Poor Nettie has been sick again. I very much fear that if she does not hasten from that climate, she will go into a decline. Isaac wrote

that they should start the first of May, that he should come to New Hampshire with Nettie, but should not be able to come to Maine. do you believe he can do it? How hard it will be for him to do without wife and baby this summer, won't it? Anna did not say a word about their time for starting East. In your trunk I have put my quilt and skirt to quilt, but you know I am in no hurry for them and please do not touch them unless perfectly convenient. I will put in what wadding I have - guess there will be enough for the skirt; if you quilt the other, please get batting from the village, as it is not worth while to send from here. I want to hear everything about Sally & "Sally's baby", how you like them, how much & on what terms she works, where they sleep etc. etc. How Jane felt about going away and everything else - Please do, Albina, write. I was quite miserable a few days, then a little better, and now rather poorly again. We tried to find somebody to come here, but could not, Fear of b-d b-gs us all that prevents me from sending for Maria Ricker to come & stay a while. I think it would be a good thing for her & save me a good deal - with the care of Percie, I don't seem to get any chance to get well. However, soon E. and M. will go away probably, & then Isabel can have more time to help me. Maria R. would not do at all for Mallie. She must have somebody to get breakfast alone, do up starched things, wash & iron nice articles, etc. etc. She expects now to have Gramma from Easthampton. If convenient, please send the rag carpeting when Samuel comes. also the two No.s of Mother's Magazine. I must lie down - Mallie will write - Love to everybody - Your affectionate daughter -
[left-hand side] We have "Powers of the world to come" which we will send you as soon as we have read it.

Bangor Apr. 22, 1854

Dear Mother

                 I will write a few words to send by monday's mail, merely on business. The Tebbetts house cannot be had, much to Eliab's and Mallie's disappointment, and they cannot go back to Mr. Palmer's to board. There is no suitable home either for rent or for sale, and they can find no other boarding place, so of course they must stay here, and we must all accommodate ourselves to circumstances and do the best we can. Property of all kinds is going up at a rapid rate: rents, house lots and houses are increasing in value. That is, prices are raised, every day. Well, they will be here probably all through whatever may take place, summer and fall. I am really very poorly. The complaint has never troubled me so much before. I was weak, and had the injury to my back along with it before, but this has never been so bad; it never troubled me nights before. Now I feel the pain and weakness when in bed, as if I could not get up again. I do walk into the bedroom and kitchen because I cannot help it, and of course have to lift and take care of Percie more or less as best I can, but I am so afraid I shall get fairly down on my back, I don't know what to do. I feel debilitated & strengthless, and must have somebody to relieve me from the care of Percie immediately. I thought when they expected to go away so soon, I would try to worry along till they left and then Isabel could

[left-hand side] ness and ever so much further. The chief trouble is she is extremely nervous. Please write soon all about yourself and everything, how Walter manages & prospers,  what you hear from Anna & Isaac etc.etc. If Maria can come, please send her speedily. Good bye- Love L-Albina & Sally-  lovingly, Lucy.

help me more. I wish you would see if Maria Ricker can come immediately & if possible do have her come without company such as I mentioned in my last. Of course Isabel can do the housework. All I want of Maria is to stay in the room with me and please Percie, or take him out doors etc. I will try to learn her to sew. etc. and I really think it might be a benefit to the child. Her work will not be hard & I should think her wages ought to be light. I send for Dr. Paine the day before yesterday. He left me medicine which he thought would relieve me, but says care is the chief thing. Says I must not lift baby. I told him I could'nt help it. He said I must wean him immediately, as nursing aggravated the trouble, so I began yesterday. We get along pretty well with him. Mallie and Isabel get him to sleep. I think the breast-pipe which I have to use aggravates more than nursing, but I suppose I shall not have to use it many days. I am going to send for Mrs. Harlow to come in and tell me how to manage by and by. I have written a long and dolorous story about I, but I know you would want to know just how we are. In truth, I never felt so lowpogy before. I had been so well & taken so much comfort in being so, & had anticipated so much in being able to go out in the garden & round with baby this summer it almost seems as if I could'nt bear it. But perhaps when he is fairly weaned and the spring weather has gone, I shall feel better. Sam'l has concluded not to sell the horse. He and Eliab together will keep him, so we shall have more rides. Mallie is quite smart & well - walked to meeting & back last sabbath, and yesterday down to Mrs. Palmer's
[left-hand side] I expect the carpenters will begin on the bedroom next week. If you don't want the rag carpet, send it when Maria comes.

Bangor April 25 '54

                                                                                                                                                 Bangor Apr.25 - 1854

Dear Mother

                       "You need not send that corn." I hope this letter will reach you before you have spoken to Mr. Ricker's people. Lizzie Thaxter has an orphan niece fourteen years old, who is, in a sense, on her hands. She is a very lovely disposition, pleasant girl, has been living in Bangor as a second girl sometime, understands her place and duties & would probably be much more serviceable to me than M. Ricker, besides I can have her today, which is more favorable. Lizzie is going away soon & feels very anxious to find her a good place. We shall give her fifty cents - a week, I suppose. Lizzie has a great many trials of one kind and another.
                        Samuel has never liked the plan of getting Maria here very well. I hardly know whether on account of peculiarities in the family, or her eye, or the trouble of it. I have felt a little better yesterday & today. Percie is very good about going to sleep -seems to think that when he is laid down he must shut his eyes & sleep immediately - slept all night before last without waking, but worries & whines a good deal days, I intend to have Esther keep him out doors a good deal.
                                                                                                          In haste, with love,
                                                                                                                     Lucy.

Bangor April 29 54 Lucy April '54

                                                                                                                                     Bangor Apr.29 - 1854

Dear Mother

                     I should not write again so soon as we have sent to many missives lately, were it not for the fear that you will worry about us if I do not. Things have managed queerly about my getting anybody to help me, and we finally concluded that it was not right to have any more help! So Maria has taken a good deal of care of baby and we have got along without. In the first place we sent for Mrs. Bates, a regular nurse, but she had just engaged herself elsewhere, then for a good little scotch girl of Mr. Harlow's recommending, who could not come then, next for a girl we heard of through Mr. Pages' people whose grandmother said she might come, but who never made her appearance; next for M.Richer, but just as we had dispatched the Letter, Lizzie Doe heard of our necessities and felt so distressed that the chance was lost for her orphan niece, that I forthwith sent another letter countermanding orders, as you know. Next day instead of her coming here to stay as I expected, she came with a note from Lizzie, saying that her mother was not well and wanted the granddaughter. She was extremely sorry and said that she might stay with me notwithstanding

if I said so, or at least till I could write again for the Milo girl, but we had had so much fuss that Maria said she has rather take still more care of Percie for a while than to have any body come. Then you know two girls are apt to make trouble together. Baby is about weaned now, I feel considerably better than I did, partly owing to Dr. Paine's medicine I think & partly to weaning the baby. I think with care we shall get along nicely now. Percie is very good nights - several nights he has not waked to ask for food at all when he does, he drinks his milk & goes immediately to sleep, but days he worries most all the time. He has grown poor very much within a fortnight is not so strong to stand as some day ago; He has been very costive indeed, since I began to wean him- I am giving him now some of Dr. Paine's little powders, which begin to help him. Please don't worry about us. I dare say we shall all do nicely in a little while. It would have been the extreme of comfort if you could have been here the past three weeks, but I know it is not best. I would not have you fail of making Almeda a good long visit this spring for anything. Do make yourself happy & at home there and comfort her ever so much & be comforted yourself. Also write me from there how Jane

manages & prospers. I really do not think it is Almeda's duty to try her own patience overmuch, or run the risk of injuring Lizzie for the sake of having her there. I shall try to write to Jane soon. A vessel with corn and flour was sunk by the ice going out, at Hampden this week - has been towed up to Bangor. Samuel & Eliab have bought some seven hundred bushels of the damaged corn, which they hope to sell profitably, especially if the weather is such that it will dry soon. Letter from Isaac & Nettie yesterday. Nettie is better - I wish she had some help about getting ready to come - fear she is not able to make the necessary preparations alone.

first half of this is from 2 pages back
E. and M. have both had letters from you within a few days. There are but a few white spots to be seen on the ground here. Our terrace is perfectly green.How is your lame shoulder? How did Charlie like his book? How is Mr. Sargent? My love to him. Who will do his work for him this summer? How sad about the horses. Do write all about Walter's proceedings - how the house looks after painting, etc. etc.  If possible, do have Walter fix up about the shed etc. and dig up the terrace so things can grow there. good bye, with much love to all
daughter Lucy.

Bangor May 6 - 1854

Dear Mother

                        A few words in haste this Saturday morning to ask if you have any more butter to spare, either last year's or this spring's make., or if you can get any good in the neighborhood at Mrs. Sargent's, Dolan's,or anywhere. If you or Almeda have any we would like a small box as soon as it can be sent by stage. I shall write to Almeda about it. Butter is very high and it is almost impossible to get any good here now. I shall write to Almeda too, and if she and Albina both send a box, it will not come amiss. If there is more than we want, it can go right into the store. Samuel and Eliab have got a splendid store. The largest and best arranged store, wharf and counting room in the city. Their counting room in particular is very pleasant. Very high, with large windows coming almost to the floor on three sides, a large, handsome and convenient desk, clock, looking glass, table of books, papers etc. They will have to negotiate some, as Sam'l says in order to meet their notes, for a while, but think it is a good business, and an excellent situation, and that they can carry it through safely. But they are so busy, particularly now,

[left-hand side and top] her good letter received a day or two since, with yours, but I have got an amount of work to do before Anna gets hers, of all sorts. There is so much necessary work here that must be done. Baby sleeps all night without food. Why do you always have do poorish there. Your last letter I could not possibly send in the evening - had to give it up till morning then could not decipher the whole, though I think I found out the meaning of all. Cannot any better be obtained there? I must mend Samuel's coat before dinner. good bye  - love to all Aff. daughter Lucy No matter whether little or more butter is sent, it will go to the store if we don't want it all.

Bangor May 6, 1854
just as their new stock of goods is coming in - vessels unloading etc. most all of the time. 

 Bay is fairly weaned - does not teaze me at all now - he has another tooth and feels better since. I think I feel much better for weaning him. It was too much of a tax on my spring strength. Tiny powders have helped me too. I feel much better, but dare not do much. I have dusted the room two or three times, and put away things a little in the morning etc. Mallie is smart as can be, helps me about Percie a good deal - she has walked to meeting several times lately, up from down town etc. I believe I wrote you that S. and E. together have decided to keep the horse - have him kept at a stable to save time and trouble - take him and after he has had his dinner, to bring them to theirs, and keep him out till after tea; so they usually walk down in the morning and up at night, only when they are very tired, "Tim" brings them home. A short, hurried note from Anna says she expects to be here the first week in June. Our garden fence is very lengthed out - the bedroom will be served ditto next week. I have a bundle of Independents ready to send next time Mr. Gould comes down - chiefly for the children's pieces to read to Charlie. How did he like his book? Tell Albina I mean to write soon to her in answer to

Bangor May 9 54 Lucy May '54

                                                                                                                                                          Bangor May 9 -1854

Dear Mother

                We saw Mr. Gould go down this morning & Samuel is going to ask him to call as he goes home, so I will scribble a few words and do up my papers to send by him. The buff French calico for little Mary a dress, (Percie has one just like it), the other for "Sally's baby." It is common width and she will need more than two breadths, I should think. The collar for Albina, I intended to get her one when I next went down street, but  I want to send today, so I'll out in this of mine. It has never been done up, but needs to be now. It is probably handsomer than the new one would have been if I had got it! You know this was a bargain when I got it; just like the one Mallie got for Anna. The Independents for the sake of stories for Charlie. I think I must have Maria Richer. I have tried to do without as long as I well can. I am some better than a while ago, but not well enough to do what I am daily obliged to do. I am afraid it will be troublesome business having two girls, but I don't see as I can help it. I wish you would start her off immediately if she can come. Should be glad if she could get here tomorrow. I do hope she will be steady & try to do well. I suppose fifty cents a 

[left-hand side and top] just please say to Mrs.Richer, I will give Maria .50 a week & say nothing about what is expected of her except chiefly to take care of baby, for I want to be at liberty to call on her for what I choose. If there had been nothing said to Isabel about three in the family, an easy place etc., it would have been better.

week would be about right to give her. That is what the Doe girl was coming for & she, having worked here, would certainly be worth as much as a green girl. Percie worries a good deal more than before he was weaned. I suppose his Mother's milk had an effect to keep him good natured! I have to give him a good deal of cracked wheat and molasses to keep his bowels in order, and I am a little suspicious that the wheat is too coarse fodder for such a little chicken. Do you know? If Maria comes I do not want to engage her for any time, as perhaps I shall only want her a few weeks, & perhaps I may want to train her in and keep her to take Isabel's place when she goes away. I don't know when that will be. She is a Farris, and make it manifest once in a while. Don't say one word to Mrs. Sargent about her staying or leaving or anything about it.If Almeda wanted Lizzie to come, & she would be contented, there would be nothing hard for her to do, but I suppose she wants her at home. For me it is hard to lead baby by this two hands, or stoop every few minutes, as somebody must, to pick up something, or run and get him dry dipes and milk, but for a well back it would not be. He weighs but 21 pounds -- 1 months, 2 3. He looks very thin compared with last winter. I weigh only 113 pounds. What cold weather we have had - seems a little warmer today. Shall try to write to Albina soon. Much love

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Lucy.

Bangor June 5 1854

                                                                                                                                                                                Bangor June 5 - 1854

Dear Mother

                          In haste I write you a few lines because it seems a long time since I ave written and I don't know whether to direct to Milo or Brownville. Isabel went away Thursday. I have another girl engaged to come next day, but on engaging found her character was not good and have been without, except while Katy McLaughlin, who helps nicely about the care of Baby. But we are in a bad fix and must have help. Percie had a touch of croup the night after Isabel went away, so that had added to the care. He took cold when Katy had him out. I expected a girl today, (Irish) but she has not come.
                         We think now of doing without till we go to Milo ad trying to hunt up one there or at Brownville. Nettie and I have some idea of going up before Anna comes, as I cannot go there; (there will be fatigue & excitement enough without) perhaps last of this week or first of next, if  Samuel cam leave to go with us. I think you may expect us. Mallie and Eliab will keep house. How does Almeda's lounge prosper? I will tell you about Isabel when I come. If we have not had "confusion worse confounded " here  lately - Bedroom fixing so we had to sleep

up stairs (we got back into it saturday)
Isabel going off. Isaac & Nettie coming so unexpectedly, house cleaning by Mrs. McLaughlin and Percie with the worst cold he has ever had, besides the confusion & noise consequent on having two babies. You will have a nice long time to stay at Brownville, Anna's visit is so long delayed. We have not heard whether Hattie has the measles or not, nor when she now intends to start. Well I must not stay longer - much love to Almeda & all. 

       We will give nine shillings a week to a good girl through the summer. Company and Mallie's being here and all, will make more work. I shall keep Katy here till after Anna has been here. Nettie had a girl to take care of Carrie and do her work, but still the more there are in a family the more work there is to do. Please inquire vigorously on Brownville, Williamsburgh & elsewhere. Perhaps better not in Milo as girls feel too well acquainted. 
                                                                                                                                                      In haste
                                                                                                                                                                   Lucy

[left-hand side] Lucy Bangor June 1854
How & when will Almeda have her sugar sent. Shall we send it by stage?

Bangor June 5 1854

                                                                                                                                       Bangor June 5 - 1854

Dear Sister Albina

                              In haste I write a few words to tell you that probably - if all is well, Nettie, Sam'l and I, with two babies and a woman to take care of them will make an appearance at the door of your hospitable mansion the latter part of this week or the first of next. We think on every account, it would be foolish to try to go all together when Anna comes. You would not know what to do with us when we got there, and then it will be as much as I can do to take care of them when here; I shall want the time while they are gone to Milo to rest. I have written to Mother at Brownville, but perhaps she is at Milo before now. Please send what rag carpeting you don't want by first opportunity - In haste
                                                                                                                                                                        Sister Lucy.

Lucy Bangor June 29 '54

                                                                                                                               Bangor June 29-1854

Dear Mother & Sister

                                   It is a dear day just warm enough & just cold enough - four o'clock P.M. I have hardly sat down before today - Mallie is taking a bath and a nap up stairs (she has not been so well as usual for a few days, & if there was anybody to do it, would I think be waited upon, & in reality - ought to be, instead of trying to do for me.) Nettie is sleeping in the parlor on the sofa with Carry in the carriage by her side, Percie has just gone to sleep in the bedroom. Sabra & Mary have gone strawberrying. My back and all about me does ache bit I am troubled because we have not written before, so I will try to send a little tomorrow. We have had queer times since we came

[left-hand side] got to settle for eggs, butter etc. when at Milo. Percie is in my lap struggling & fretting good bye Aff. Lucy.

from Milo - both babies got out of their bias? as the woman said - Percie has been really sick as Nettie wrote you - very feverish & restless night & day -he won't willingly stay with anybody but me, but Mary is a perfect nobody & I have had to see to everything, do her work after her etc. She cannot cook at all, even to make a loaf of eatable bread,  cannot do starched things, about half washes, very slack about all her work, have to wash more than half the dishes over before using them, and she is if possible more awkward & uncouth & coarse than Mrs.Cat? In disposition & temper very like Jane, prepared at all times for a saucy word to anybody - independent & bold - takes evident pride in talking to Sabra before me so as to show that she don't care for me -she is the strangest specimen

of humanity  - that I ever happened to meet with, Hobbs people not excepted. She is bright & smart. We have had a hard disagreeable time - about half the time she laughs & talks loud enough to be hears all over the house with Sabra & then cries with homesickness. If I could have spared time, I should have had one or two good cry's myself within a week - however, we hope, better times are coming. We expect a girl from Hampden tomorrow, only sixteen yrs old, but is at least pleasant & honest - don't know how capable she is - expect Anna a week from today. If Percie had not been better today, I should have written for you to come next stag of you could for I had got just tired out. Mr. Gould could not take the things the first of the week. I shall send them tomorrow.I forgot to get any tacks, will put in part of a paper

which we have. Mr. & Mrs. Lee spent a night here last week. Mr. & Mrs. Hurd dined here same day - they live in Exeter now -Mr. Sewall dined here today - attending State Conference. I have worried some about sundry scythes overhead in Milo back house, which I feared might some day fall on children's heads, but which I forgot to speak about. I hope my next letter will be as full of comfort & good news as this is of perplexities & distresses.  Mallie & Percie are getting better, & a good girl coming, so we'll hope for the best . We sent Katy home, because two girls are such a trial & because Sarah Harlow said that her Mother was not honest. They have tried her. Bell Furber's card for Albina - Make haste & get your carpet down.I fear I don't send back my carpet enough to do anything with, but it takes more than I thought for my room. I forgot [contines on page 1 of this letter]

Mother  

                    Anna has written a little to to Milo. I presume she told you when arrived etc. etc. I have intended to write ? since she came, but when she goes to Milo, she will tell you, how hurried and ? we have been - Mary staid a ? her trunk could not go the day she  ? so we took the liberty to open it and  ? two or three quires of paper, some  ?, a paper of sugar, some cake etc. etc.  ? wrote a letter & put it in her trunk  ? frightened her not a little and  ? forth an exceedingly humble, peni tent? letter by the next mail. Anna has written a little to send to Milo. I presume she told you when she arrived etc. etc. I have intended to write ever since she came, but when she goes to Milo, she will tell you, how hurried and worried we have been - Mary staid a week - her trunk could not go the day she did, so we took the liberty to open it and found two or three quires of paper, some books, a paper of sugar, some cake etc. etc. Samuel wrote a letter & put in her trunk which frightened her not a little and drew  forth an exceedingly humble, penitent letter by the next mail. There came a girl from Hampden, pleasant & good as need be, but knowing nothing about work, only fifteen yrs old - her price was 9/ per week, but when she went away would take but 7 / s -  new one came today, Irish, twenty four years old, stout, pleasant & capable - I hope we

can keep her a while. We have all be to Old Town today for a ride. It is nearly nine -we are all tired, but I thought I must say a few words to Mother. Carry does not seem very well tonight. Nettie has decided not to wait for Anna but to go next Monday to Dunbarton. Last evening Mr. & Mrs. Shepard, their oldest daughter & Mr. Egbert Smythe, (who now preaches 1/2 time for us,) took tea here, tomorrow we feel obliged to invite Mr. Harlow's family & Mrs. Blood -we wanted to wait till you came, but have been nowhere hardly with Nettie & had no company & wanted to have them before she went home. We hired washing & ironing this week. Nettie send much love - says she feels wicked to go away without seeing you more, as she expected. I hope to have a little good time now I have got a girl that can keep the fire going without my telling her every time to put it a stick ?
Well I am tired - much love - good bye

                                             Lucy

Bangor March 14, 1855.

Dear Mother , Nettie and all

                             A letter to either of you is the same as to all, especially if I write pretty often. Was very, very much obliged for the good last letter from Mother & Nettie. Particularly, Mother, for the account of your Exeter excursion. I am sure I should'nt think you would ever consider yourself a nobody again! I shall preserve the letter with great care. I hope you have written the whole story to Anna, as I alluded to it when I wrote, saying you had probably told her about it. O, Nettie, why did you not send the collar right to Anna. I did not think you were going to send it  here, as you finished it there. Very greatly obliged - what eversomuch shall I do for you> Would you believe it - Samuel and I made ten calls yester afternoon- It was a splendid day, he got a chaise so it did not tire me to get in & out so

[left hand side and top] dollars in all - John P. Hale is to lecture here this week. I went to hear him. Garrison lectured last week three evenings. One free lecture. Is'nt it too bad Nettie that the lectures should stop just before you came, begin as soon as you went away. Well my sheet seems to be full do write often all of you to Lucy.   Angela has a beautiful babe- have you seen it?

much - then some of the houses were so near together (on this street) that I walked and two people were not at home. Mrs. Palmer's, Wingate's, Bennett's - Angella there - Wells'. Holden;s, Whittier's, Wellington's, Chalmer's. Chases', and the long talker of Wiggins'. Got home about six, greatly relieved in mind, but wearied in body. Yester morn, Sammie & Hattie Eby took Percy & Gertie in the large carriage, down to the store to be weighed - Percie 26 lbs, and Gertie 14 1/2 . Percie has grown hard & solid very fast lately, but his bowels remain just so irregular -is'nt it singular? The scarlet fever & throat distemper prevail very much now. I hope to keep P. from it - don't know as I ought to send him out - it goes in the air, does'nt it? Ellen went to a wake last night - looks as if she "wailed, greatly," and I presume she did. Samuel was gone to singing school in the evening and I got Eliab & Maria to come and stay

with me.Maria is getting all her summer things for baby done before her sisters go. Hattie is scolloping little aprons all round and embroidering shirt sleeves. They think going in a fortnight. I hardly see how Mallie will get along when they are gone, at least till Joanna gets here. Sam'l has had a talk with Mr. Jewett about Edwin. They do not intend to keep him, and he does not want to stay - is bent on going to seed again. I fear he is a bad boy. I pity his poor Mother. Mrs. Bradford Harlow was sadly distressed at finding you were all gone - said she had had unexpected company and everything to prevent her sending for is. Mrs. Haskins was very sorry not to  have called - even Aunt Natty expressed regrets that she did not invite us over there. I do really wish, Mother, that you had taken a longer time to stay at Exeter. But perhaps it will be convenient to go again sometime soon.

We sympathize deeply with Isaac's big toe! He ought to be more careful. I am glad you are going to walk there fine spring mornings - it will do you both good. Percie talks a great l more than when you went away - will say the whole of "Now I lay me," after me, quite respectably - begins to put words together. When we are going away, he begins to kiss us half an hour beforehand, and cries if his father forgets to kiss him before he goes out. The great trouble with him is he is so whining and babyish. I wish he was as manly as Mayo. He says Mayo pretty well. I ask him where Mayo is - he says "Mi." and then goes on to say "Ma- ma-ma" (grandmother) "Nenny" and tries to say Isaac. Samuel has got him a little rocking chair. I think Josie has the right of it in regard to Mary's being a man! Did I tell you that Prof. Shepard called while I was at Mallie's the other day - I was very sorry not to see him. Mr. Wallace, the Scotchman, preacher last sabbath forenoon.I have had another letter from Mrs. Whittelsey. She & the publisher do not agree about the money I sent. Mrs. Harlow has got the

Lucy 
March 31 1855

                                                                                                                                           Bangor Mar. 31 - 1855

Dear Mother

                                  In spite of Issac's lecture about using small sheets, I have dared to take one again, but do not intend to overfill it. Your letters were received with gladness Tuesday - the same day I sent my last to you. Our trout dinner came off nicely - the gentleman & lady seemed to enjoy themselves very respectably. Mallie was up that afternoon, has not been since. The baby has been quite unwell. She applied to Dr. Mc Ruen for something to cure the baby's face & he gave some salve, which Dr. Payne, (for whom they sent in a day or two) said had stuck to her lungs, and that there was great danger of lung fever. I think Mallie & I get Homeopathy & Allopathy queerly mixed up - Am fraid we shall get all the sons of Esculapius offended with us by & by - I think I shall remain "persuaded of Dr. Mitchell", William Corsby told Sam'l a day or two since

that he intended starting for Minn. in a week or two. When are you coming back here Isaac? We want to see you all - you did not stay at Brownville so long as I expected. I conclude that betokens a speedy return to Bangor. Jane is here yet thoughtless, heedless as ever - seems light-hearted & happy & laughing & "carrying on"with Ellen. Ellen is very womanly - just right with her. We have not heard from N.H. yet. Wonder how the Manchester strike will affect other factories. They are having a great time there. I am confidently expecting a letter from Milo tonight. We had long letters from Olive and Sarah yesterday. Olive has been sick a good while - premature confinement -five or six months advanced so far from well now. She wrote an unusually long letter - send love to Mother, Chas. & Albina - wished they would write to her, has often thought of writing to them - but three little children, the oldest sickly, large farm & dairy, workmen, boarders

usually from sixteen to twenty in the family - with poor help or none at all; finds it hard to get time for letter writing. No help but a little girl of thirteen for a long time. Percie says "away" very cunningly, and keeps saying it most all the time. Papa is "away" & Lilla is away etc. etc. He does out in the kitchen twenty times a day, shutting the door & saying "by. by.Mamma". Have you rec'd any printer accounts of the "Exeter school Convention?" It is out in famous? printed sheets. Ella Raynes sent one to her people & I saw it. Sam'l has inquired at the Office where they were printed, but there are none obtainable. I am going to send to Ella for a supply - should think we should have some from the powers that be, in Exeter. I don't like it of them, such neglect! In regard to you or Lissie coming here - you know I should always be glad to have you here all the time, when you can feel happy to be so, but I don't want Almeda nor any of the

rest feeling hard because you stay here so much - and if you would enjoy yourself any better in the country than here, the coming summer, by all means stay there. Your own comfort & happiness is the thing for you to attend to in preference to anything else, unless in case of sickness in the family, - then I suppose whoever was sick, would feel as of they must have you. I did want you should stay longer at Almeda's on her account. As for Lizzie, if Almeda is willing to let her come, I should like to have her - if I find she makes too much work, I can but send her home again - should like to try it, at least. Percy grows less & less trouble, but when it gets a little warmer weather I shall want him out doors a good deal and Lizzie can care for him then. I will do as well for her as my time & strength will allow; if you conclude to come back too, you will help train her in the way she should go! As for yourself, do please consider which place you had rather be in during the summer & act accordingly, if it is to go from one to the

Ellen told her never to speak of that to any one. One night she said to her, "Would'nt it be a dreadful thing of I should follow in my mother's steps?" Such things amuse Ellen so she has to come and tell me. Mrs.Harlow has just got a "box and book" Homeopathic, and is laboring to bring me over to the faith. Now if I lived at Milo, I should have no trouble at all, but could just have good careful Dr. K! How I was grieved to get no letter from Milo Saturday. Am sure I shall not be disappointed tonight. There is a social gathering at the vestry tonight - am sorry you are not here, Nettie, to go - you would enjoy it. I want to go, but don't quite like to leave Jane & Ellen, so shall not -

Apr. 3rd My letter was written with intent to send it Monday, but did not mail it Sat. eve hoping to get a letter from you, & Sabbath day it was so very stormy that I did not go down with it - then Mond. noon we missed the stage. I have made Jane's linsey dress over into a skirt. It seemed most too bad, as if there had been a little new left, it might have been made over into a good

dress, and she needs it badly enough. Her two calicoes are outgrown & entirely worn out, her old delaine not worth fixing - she has only her new calico and delaine besides  a roan kerseymere, which I have just got her, thinking it would do her as much service on the whole as anything she could have. She has on two quilts, perfectly filthy and in rags. I am going to have her

wash and mend them- but the most trying thing of all is - she has got the itch, and never told us a word about it till she had been here a week - slept with Ellen, handled Percie etc. Ellen was very indignant - she burst out as soon as she knew it, "I'll lick the girl, if she has given me the itch." "She'll not sleep with me another night." I did feel provoked with her for not telling about it when she first came. We have heard nothing from N.H. yet in regard to a place for her. Sam'l says, by all means have her dress comfortable & suitable before she goes away, Mrs. Lee told Ellen, unsolicited, all about her parentage & told Ellen that she told Mrs. Babb

Lucy  April 1855
but wait till I saw you - but Samuel said I had better tell you all about it.I have feared that it might come to this sometime, but I could not have believed it so soon. We got your letter Sat. night. Samuel took the letter which you sent, with him & if he does not succeed in finding a place in a factory at G. Falls or Dover, will try to find her father, Mother or grandparents & compel them, if possible, to take her. If they reuse, said he should "throw her across the town of Dover and leave her." I feel no little anxiety to know the result of his journey. If we get fairly rid of her, shall we not feel relieved, and yet uncomfortable thoughts of her will always intrude themselves upon us. Do you believe we shall ever take another Hobbs to bring up? Hattie and Mary expect to go this week - they would have gone today had Mary been well enough. If Sam'l should go to Norfolk (which I do not expect) perhaps we should make one family either here or at Eliab's, as she would be alone so much and S. would be away three weeks probably. He did not feel particularly elated this morning in prospect of his journey to N.H. I can assure you.While I think of it, let me ask you to send your paper about the Exeter convention to Aunt Conant when you write - would'nt do her a bunch of good. Ella Raynes sent me some, so you can have another. I am going to send one to Anna when I write again. Was'nt it queer, Nettie, when your letter arrived, containing the Lucy lines, it found me writing the enclosed. You will say, & with truth, that good taste is sacrificed to ridiculosity, but when I had arrived at a certain pitch of sublimity, it so fell out that I took a sudden leap down to the ridiculous! Only just don't be offended with me, please, and say I made sport of your boy, 'cause I did'nt! He is a nice little fellow and

I love him ever so much and want to see him badly - give him a rousing hug and kiss from Aunt Lucy. Should'nt I have enjoyed peeping out to see the little martyr when undergoing the cleansing operation that Mother spoke of. Am glad he and Mary enjoy so much together. I do echo in my heart your wish that we could consistently go to Milo while you are there - how I should love to see all the children together - you have never said a word of the reason why you spent so little time at Brownville, when you had predetermined to make a long visit there. I wrote to Almeda last week.Isaac can't say I have'nt taken large sheets this time, can he? Percie is a precious good boy these days.
April 10 I am going down to Eliab's to spend the day leaving Percie with Ellen. Am a little afraid he will be troubled about it= he mourns for Samuel some but I shall come home early. Sammie came up to stay last night- I had given up his coming - & we had just gone to bed when he arrived - he was up & off before I was awake this morning. Don't you imagine it seemed lonesome, as Ellen says, here yesterday? I think it did - I wish Lizzie was here now - good bye - I must be ready to go - E. is coming for me - Do write often -Sam'l is not going to Norfolk, so I expect him next Thursday. Be'nt I glad?

                                                                                                              Affec.
                                                                                                                        Lucy

Lucy
April 18 55

                                                                                                                                      Bangor Apr. 18 - 1855

Dear Charles & Albina

                     It is almost night, but I'll try and get off a bit of a letter to you before dark.  I did intend to write so as to send it by today's mail, but Maria and the baby were up here all day, and we had so much talking to do, as usual, that we did little else.
                    We confidently expected Isaac and Nettie yesterday - are now expecting them tomorrow. Eliab sent up a letter for Isaac today, which we suppose will start him - away- I know nothing about it, however, only that it was from Col. Mason. We are hoping to see Mother with them, but she has not written a word of her intentions. I think Mother ought to spend her time just where she pleases, don't you? I am sure I

[left-hand side and top] thing more in especial to write- Am very sorry Albina about the chicken wings, but the animals came when we had just bought a whole mutton & half a pig & dared not bring them home, so he sold them, & he never noticed the wings. Do please all write to me. Lovingly sis Lucy. I could not write the filthy story once again about Jane to Almeda - won't you send her the letter I wrote you or tell her all about it when you see her.

should love to have her stay here all the time, did I not know that there are several others who feel just so, and who would justly consider me selfish if I wished to have her here always. She always seems to enjoy herself better at Milo in the summer. but she might come down with them, so as to be with them the little time they stay, and go back again whenever she feels like it. This we are expecting she will do. You will feel slightly lonesome when they come away, as I did when they left here. Maria's sisters left last Monday, so she is quite alone now, as her brother is in the store. All hands are busy enough just now - The ice went out Sat. night, Monday morning their goods arrived & the unloading, arranging & marking gives them hardly eating or breathing time for a few days. They chartered a vessel

to bring all their spring goods at once thus saving considerable expense of freightage, besides much care and labor. Jewett remains with store and does much better than he did  a while ago. Mr. Ross (their silent partner) rejoices in the acquisition of a pair of twins, two days old - a girl and boy. They like him better & better. One of the frank, sincere sort, yet very shrewd - always favors a poor or unfortunate man, in a trade, even to his own injury. Well, the chief item of my letter I have not touched upon - the disposal of Jane - our "family skeleton." I wrote particularly to Mother while Samuel was gone - he got her a place in a weave room at Dover, inquired out the Hobbs people, talked with her aunt, a stiff, precise maiden lady, and got her boarded in her grandfather's  house,- himself, & this maiden aunt

being the family, as I understand it. Her mother has married & moved away, her grandmother died - the Aunt knew about Jane, the grandfather never did & don't now. They never intend to own her, but let her board there till they could find her another place. The aunt seemed to be a very good sort of person - began lecturing Jane with some severity of manner almost immediately, about all girls that boarded with her being obliged to keep good company etc. Samuel then told her she had been a wayward troublesome uneasy girl always, but said nothing of any bad conduct. I don't believe Jane will have been there a week before she tells her grandfather who she is! She is to have from half a doll. to a dollar a week besides board while learning - according to how she does. The journey cost Sam'l 16 dollars, besides something before she went away - he said he considered it a good bargain at that! though it does seem too bad. I rather grudged the expense - I wanted the money for a new gown! Don't think of any

Lucy April 1855
other very to weeks. I will warrant you a welcome as often as you show your face at either home! You see I did not crowd, Isaac, but afforded myself another piece of paper! Mrs. Dr. Mann, and her pretty daughter Augusta, called yesterday. Yesterday and today I have wholly made (except trimming the cape) a delaine dress for Jane, and a talma cape, of Lyonese. I cut the cape myself too. You will say "Why do you do it? Let her do it herself" - You nor I either would not let her go away uncomfortably nor indecently clad, and I verily think it would take her a month-steady labor - to make a dress alone. Mr. Pierpont lectured last night & night before - Mechanics - no tickets to be had,

  I think it a fine thing, Nettie, that

you have an Ajax who is so good a jack at all trades, ironing and all. I don't wonder poor little Mayo feels badly at going to be alone - I only wonder he is so good as he is, posted about in so many strange places. I put P.P. to bed at five now usually - he seldom naps in the day. I want to hear that Mayo is better than when you wrote - you said he was feverish & ailing. Percie has played more with "Nonny" yesterday & today than ever before in his life - disposes him in a proper position, on Peter, now and then. I do want a nice letter from Charles & Albina & mean to write particularly  to them soon - All the letters come to them too, but it seems more natural to direct my speech to those I have seen last and who write oftenest to me. Sammy did write a nice letter to our brother de Witt, his consequence of my coaxing! goodbye Lute.
